questions.text: Which of the following aneuploidies is most likely to be missed in prenatal neonatal screening? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klinefelter's Syndrome

 

Klinefelter's Syndrome is most likely to be missed in prenatal neonatal screening. Standard prenatal screening protocols primarily target trisomies 21, 18, and 13, as well as Turner's syndrome. The highly effective first trimester combined screening (nuchal translucency with serum markers β-hCG and PAPP-A) and cell-free DNA testing are designed to detect these specific conditions. Klinefelter's Syndrome (47, XXY) is not prominently featured in the standard screening algorithms discussed in prenatal care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome): This is actually the most commonly screened aneuploidy. The detection rate is extremely high - 99% with cell-free DNA testing and 85-92% with combined first trimester screening. First trimester screening shows increased β-hCG, decreased PAPP-A, and increased nuchal translucency in Down syndrome

.

Option B. Trisomy 18 (Edwards' syndrome): This is specifically included in standard screening protocols. It presents with decreased β-hCG and decreased PAPP-A in first trimester screening, with a high detection rate using combined screening approaches.

 

Option C. Turner's Syndrome (Monosomy X): This is reliably detected through nuchal thickness screening. Monosomy X (45,XO) is the "single most frequent specific chromosomal anomaly" comprising 9-13% of chromosomal abnormalities detected in spontaneous abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While prenatal screening programs effectively detect the common trisomies (21, 18, 13) and Turner syndrome through combined approaches, Klinefelter's Syndrome is less emphasized in standard screening protocols, making it more likely to be missed in routine prenatal screening.

choices.text: Descent, engagement, internal rotation, flexion, external rotation
Descent, engagement, internal rotation, flexion, external rotation+
Engagement, Descent, Flexion, Internal, Rotation, Extension, External Rotation, Expulsion
Engagement, descent, external rotation, internal rotation, flexion

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of the cardinal movements of labor? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Engagement, Descent, Flexion, Internal Rotation, Extension, External Rotation, Expulsion

 

The cardinal movements of labor follow a specific sequence that allows the fetus to navigate through the maternal pelvis. These movements begin with engagement when the biparietal diameter crosses the pelvic brim, followed by descent which is a continuous process facilitated by myometrial pressure, bearing down efforts, and fetal body extension. Flexion reduces the presenting diameter from 11.5 cm (occipitofrontal) to 9.5 cm (suboccipitobregmatic). Internal rotation then occurs at the pelvic floor, followed by extension for delivery of the head. After the head delivers, restitution and external rotation occur to align the head with the shoulders, followed by expulsion of the shoulders and trunk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descent, engagement, internal rotation, flexion, external rotation: This sequence is incorrect because engagement precedes descent in normal labor. Additionally, this option is missing extension and expulsion, which are critical parts of the delivery process.

 

Option B. Descent, engagement, internal rotation, flexion, external rotation+: Similar to option A, this incorrectly places descent before engagement. The correct understanding is that the fetal head must engage before continued descent can occur.

 

Option D. Engagement, descent, external rotation, internal rotation, flexion: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before internal rotation. External rotation follows the delivery of the head and represents alignment of the head with the shoulders, while internal rotation occurs within the pelvis before the head delivers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cardinal movements of labor follow the sequence best remembered by the mnemonic "Every – Engagement, Darn – Descent, Fool – Flexion, In – Internal rotation, Egypt – Extension, Royally – Restitution, Eats – External rotation, Eggs – Expulsion," which ensures proper navigation of the fetus through the birth canal.

questions.text: All of the following parameters have a Bishop’s Score of 3 except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Soft Consistency

 

The question asks for the parameter that does NOT have a Bishop's Score of 3. Reviewing the Bishop's scoring system, cervical consistency rated as "Soft" is assigned a score of 2, not 3. The other parameters listed in the options (5+ dilatation, +2 station, and >80% effacement) all correctly receive a score of 3 according to the Bishop's scoring system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5+ Dilatation: The Bishop's score assigns 5+ cm dilatation a score of 3, making this statement correct.

 

Option C. +2 head station: The Bishop's score assigns station +1,+2 a score of 3, making this statement correct.

 

Option D. >80 percent Effacement: The Bishop's score assigns effacement ≥80% a score of 3, making this statement correct.

 

Visual Support

 

The Bishop's score parameters:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Bishop's scoring system, cervical consistency is scored differently than other parameters, with "Soft" receiving a maximum score of 2, unlike dilatation, effacement, and station which can receive scores of 3.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to TOLAC? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prior classical hysterotomy

 

Hysterotomy means incision on the uterus, prior classical hysterotomy (classical cesarean section) is an absolute contraindication to TOLAC (Trial of Labor After Cesarean). "Previous classical or inverted T-shaped uterine incision" is specifically listed as a contraindication for TOLAC. Classical cesarean scars have a significantly higher risk of rupture (2.5%) compared to lower segment transverse scars (0.5-1.0%). Classical scars are weak because they have difficult apposition of the thick muscle layer, form pockets containing blood that's replaced by fibrous tissue, and they stretch at right angles to the scar during subsequent pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prior Kerr hysterotomy: This is incorrect. Option B refers to a lower segment transverse cesarean section. Patients with "One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar" may be considered for TOLAC with proper selection criteria. Lower segment scars heal better because the thin cut margins facilitate perfect apposition, this part remains inert during healing, and the scar stretches along the line of the scar in future pregnancies.

 

Option C. Prior Kronig hysterotomy: This is incorrect. Kronig hysterectomy refers to a lower segment vertical incision. While not ideal, it doesn't fall under absolute contraindications. Low vertical incisions have a rupture risk of 0.8-1.1%, which is comparable to the low transverse incision (0.5-1.0%).

 

Option D. All of the above: This is incorrect because only the classical hysterotomy (option A) is an absolute contraindication.

 

Educational Objective: Classical cesarean scars have a significantly higher risk of rupture (2-5%) during both pregnancy and labor compared to lower segment scars (0.2-1.5%), making prior classical hysterotomy an absolute contraindication to TOLAC.

questions.text: A patient with an anterior placenta and a posterior succenturiate lobe on ultrasound is at risk of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vasa previa

 

Vasa previa occurs when fetal blood vessels traverse the membranes over the cervical os, unprotected by Wharton's jelly. This condition commonly occurs with placenta succenturiata, where a smaller accessory lobe is separated from the main placental mass. The vessels connecting the main placenta to the succenturiate lobe must traverse the membranes, placing them at risk of compression or rupture. If these vessels run over the cervical os in front of the presenting part, vasa previa occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: While possible with any placental configuration, placenta previa is defined by placental tissue covering or being near the internal os, not specifically associated with succenturiate lobes. The risk relates to placental location, not accessory lobes.

 

Option B. Placental abruption: Premature separation of a normally implanted placenta. Not directly related to succenturiate lobes but rather to conditions like hypertension, trauma, or placental abnormalities like circumvallate placenta.

 

Option D. Preterm labor: While preterm labor can occur with various placental abnormalities, it's not specifically associated with succenturiate lobes. Vasa previa is the major concern due to potential fetal exsanguination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a succenturiate lobe is identified, careful evaluation for vasa previa is crucial as rupture can lead to rapid fetal exsanguination, with diagnosis confirmed by detecting fetal hemoglobin in vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: Crying of a fetus in utero is called: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vagitus uterinus

 

Vagitus uterinus refers to the rare phenomenon of audible crying of a fetus while still in the uterus. This occurs when air enters the uterine cavity, allowing the fetus to initiate respiratory efforts and produce vocalization before delivery. This is an extremely rare occurrence and typically happens only under unusual circumstances where air has access to the intrauterine environment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagitus vaginalis: This term describes crying of the infant when the head is in the vaginal canal but before complete delivery, not while still in the uterus.

 

Option C. Utero vaginalis: This is not a recognized medical term related to fetal vocalization or respiratory efforts.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as vagitus uterinus is the proper medical term for intrauterine crying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus represents an extremely rare phenomenon requiring the unusual circumstance of air entering the uterine cavity, allowing the fetus to initiate respiratory efforts while still in utero.

questions.text: A Registered Medical Professional (RMP) is qualified to perform an MTP in the first trimester if he has assisted in the following number of MTPs: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 25

 

A Registered Medical Practitioner (RMP) must have assisted in at least 25 MTPs in an authorized center to be qualified to perform MTPs independently. This requirement is part of the MTP Act which defines who can legally perform medical termination of pregnancy procedures. This is one of three qualifying criteria along with having a diploma/degree in Obs & Gyn or completing 6 months house surgeon training in Obs & Gyn.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5: This number is too low and does not meet the minimum requirement established by the MTP Act for practical experience.

 

Option B. 15: While closer to the required number, this falls short of the minimum 25 assisted procedures needed for qualification.

 

Option D. 50: This exceeds the minimum requirement specified in the MTP Act. While additional experience is beneficial, only 25 assisted procedures are legally required.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The MTP Act requires an RMP to have assisted in at least 25 MTPs in an authorized center as one of the key criteria to ensure adequate procedural experience before performing independent procedures.

questions.text: Modified Biophysical Profile is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NST + AFI

 

Modified Biophysical Profile consists of Non-Stress Test (NST) and ultrasonographically determined Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI). The modified BPP is used as a quicker alternative to the full BPP which requires more time (30 mins) to assess all five parameters on ultrasound. AFI is a reflection of chronic fetal compromise while NST reflects acute changes in the fetus, making this combination effective for monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. NST + Fetal Tone - This combination represents only 2 of the 5 components of a full BPP but does not constitute the modified BPP. Fetal tone is assessed by observing "≥1 episode of active extension with return of flexion or opening and closing of hand."
  • Option B. Fetal Tone + AFI - This combination is incorrect as the modified BPP specifically includes NST rather than fetal tone. The NST is essential for detecting acute changes in fetal status.
  • Option D. NST + Fetal Tone + AFI - This includes more parameters than the defined modified BPP. The modified BPP was specifically developed to be quicker than the full BPP, using only two parameters rather than multiple components.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modified BPP combines NST (which reflects acute fetal status) with AFI (which reflects chronic status) to provide a quicker assessment of fetal wellbeing than the full 5-component BPP.

questions.text: The most common Mullerian anomaly is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Septate Uterus

 

Septate uterus is the most common mullerian anomaly, representing approximately 35% of all Müllerian anomalies. This condition occurs when the two Müllerian ducts are fused together but there is persistence of the septum between them, which can be either partial (subseptate) or complete. It is typically associated with poor reproductive outcomes including infertility, recurrent abortions, and mid-trimester pregnancy losses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine Agenesis: Uterine agenesis (MRKH syndrome) is characterized by absent uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes and partial vagina. While significant, it is not the most common Müllerian anomaly.

 

Option B. Unicornuate Uterus: Unicornuate uterus represents only about 10% of Müllerian anomalies. It results from failure of development of one Müllerian duct, often presenting with a rudimentary horn that may cause complications like ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option C. Bicornuate Uterus: Bicornuate uterus accounts for approximately 26% of Müllerian anomalies. It involves varying degrees of fusion of the muscle walls of the two ducts, but is still not as common as the septate uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septate uterus is the most common Müllerian anomaly and is associated with significant reproductive complications, with hysteroscopic septoplasty being the treatment of choice for patients with recurrent pregnancy losses.

questions.text: Which of the following vertex positions is the least common during childbirth? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left Occipitoposterior (LOP)

 

When examining vertex position frequencies during childbirth, we must consider pelvic anatomy and its influence on fetal positioning. In normal labor, the fetal head typically enters the pelvic brim through the available transverse diameter in approximately 70% of cases, with the remainder occurring through oblique diameters. The anatomical configuration favors certain positions over others. Left occipitoanterior is more common than right occipitoanterior due to the effect of the rectum on the right side of the pelvis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A) Left Occipitoanterior (LOA): This is actually one of the most common positions in labor as it follows the natural pelvic anatomy. The left oblique diameter provides better accommodation for the fetal head during engagement and descent.

 

Option C) Right Occipitoanterior (ROA): While less common than LOA due to rectal encroachment on the right side, ROA still occurs with reasonable frequency during labor as anterior positions generally predominate.

 

Option D) Right Occipitoposterior (ROP): Posterior positions are generally less favorable than anterior positions but may still occur. The frequency of ROP depends on various maternal-fetal factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relative frequency of vertex positions is influenced by pelvic anatomy, particularly how structures like the rectum affect available space. Anterior positions generally predominate over posterior positions, with LOA specifically being more common than ROA.

choices.text: Diastolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg
Systolic blood pressure less than 160 mm Hg
Proteinuria less than 2 grams in 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is indicative of severe, rather than mild or non-severe, pre-eclampsia? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mild intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)

 

Fetal growth restriction is specifically listed as an indicator of severe pre-eclampsia. IUGR represents significant placental insufficiency and endothelial dysfunction, which are hallmarks of severe pre-eclampsia pathophysiology. Even mild IUGR indicates compromised placental perfusion and reflects the systemic vascular pathology that characterizes severe pre-eclampsia rather than its milder form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diastolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg: This is incorrect because severe pre-eclampsia is characterized by diastolic BP ≥110 mm Hg. A diastolic BP less than 100 mm Hg would be consistent with mild or non-severe pre-eclampsia, not meeting the threshold for classification as severe.

 

Option B. Systolic blood pressure less than 160 mm Hg: This is incorrect because severe pre-eclampsia is characterized by systolic BP ≥160 mm Hg. A systolic BP less than 160 mm Hg would be consistent with mild or non-severe pre-eclampsia, failing to meet the criteria for severe disease.

 

Option D. Proteinuria less than 2 grams in 24 hours: This is incorrect because proteinuria is no longer used as a marker for severity in current classification systems for pre-eclampsia. The degree of proteinuria alone cannot be used to distinguish between severe and non-severe pre-eclampsia in modern obstetric practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal growth restriction (even if mild)  is an important indicator of severe pre-eclampsia that reflects significant placental pathology, whereas blood pressure values below the severe thresholds (160/110 mmHg) and the degree of proteinuria are not reliable indicators of severity in current classification.

questions.text: What is the optimal peak negative pressure to be achieved during vacuum-assisted delivery? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.8 kg/cm²

 

The optimal peak negative pressure to be achieved during vacuum-assisted delivery is 0.8 kg/cm² (608 mm Hg). This pressure is created gradually at a rate of 0.1 kg/cm² per minute over about 10 minutes. Some practitioners may use a rapid negative pressure technique, starting with 0.2 kg/cm² induced slowly over at least 2 minutes, and then increasing to the effective vacuum of 0.8 kg/cm². This level of pressure creates sufficient suction to form the artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) needed for proper traction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1.2 kg/cm²: This pressure is too high and exceeds the recommended peak negative pressure for vacuum extraction. Using excessive pressure would substantially increase the risk of fetal trauma including cephalhematoma, subgaleal hemorrhage, and intracranial bleeding.

 

Option B. 0.2 kg/cm²: This represents only the initial pressure used at the beginning of the procedure. It is insufficient for effective traction and delivery. This low pressure would not create adequate chignon formation or provide sufficient traction force.

 

Option D. 1 kg/cm²: This pressure exceeds the recommended peak negative pressure of 0.8 kg/cm². Higher pressure increases the risk of cup detachment ("pop-offs") and various fetal scalp injuries, without providing additional benefits for delivery.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The optimal peak negative pressure for vacuum-assisted delivery is 0.8 kg/cm² (608 mm Hg), which provides the ideal balance between sufficient traction force and minimal risk of maternal and fetal complications.

questions.text: In what proportion of cases is a complete vesicular mole found to be associated with Theca lutein cysts? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Between 20% and 30%

 

Theca lutein cysts are a common finding in complete vesicular mole cases, occurring in approximately 25-30% of patients. These ovarian cysts form due to excessive production of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which stimulates the ovaries. In complete molar pregnancy, the significantly elevated hCG levels lead to ovarian hyperstimulation, resulting in these characteristic bilateral cysts which regress spontaneously within 2 months after expulsion of the mole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Less than 5%: This percentage is significantly lower than the actual occurrence. This figure is closer to the rate at which partial moles progress to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (1-5%).

 

Option B. Between 5% and 15%: This range is too low for complete molar pregnancies. The actual incidence is higher at 25-30%.

 

Option D. Between 50% and 60%: This percentage is higher than what is specifically mentioned for complete moles. While overall in hydatidiform moles, bilateral lutein cysts may be present in "about 50%," the more specific figure for complete moles is 25-30%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complete molar pregnancies are associated with theca lutein cysts in approximately 25-30% of cases due to excessive hCG production, which provides an important clinical sign when evaluating suspected gestational trophoblastic disease.

questions.text: What condition describes the prolapse of the upper two-thirds of the anterior vaginal wall? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystocele

 

Cystocele specifically refers to the laxity and descent of the upper two-thirds of the anterior vaginal wall. The bladder base is closely related to this area, resulting in herniation of the bladder through the lax anterior wall. This represents a specific type of anterior wall prolapse where the bladder protrudes through the weakened vaginal tissues, creating a bulge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethrocele: This refers to laxity of the lower-third of the anterior vaginal wall, where the urethra herniates through the defect. Urethrocele often appears with cystocele, forming a cystourethrocele.

 

Option C. Rectocele: This is a posterior vaginal wall defect, not anterior. It involves laxity of the middle-third of the posterior vaginal wall and the adjacent rectovaginal septum, resulting in herniation of the rectum through the lax area.

 

Option D. Enterocele: This involves the upper-third of the posterior vaginal wall, not the anterior wall. It represents herniation of the pouch of Douglas, which may contain omentum or even loops of small bowel.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cystocele specifically involves the upper two-thirds of the anterior vaginal wall with bladder herniation, while other types of prolapse affect different anatomical compartments of the vagina.

questions.text: The Gardasil vaccine provides protection against which types of human papillomavirus (HPV)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18

 

Gardasil is a quadrivalent HPV vaccine that protects against four HPV types: 6, 11, 16, and 18. HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk types associated with cervical cancer, while types 6 and 11 cause genital warts. This quadrivalent formulation provides protection against both cancer-causing strains and those responsible for genital warts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: HPV types 16 and 18: This describes Cervarix, which is a bivalent vaccine covering only the high-risk oncogenic HPV types 16 and 18. Gardasil provides broader coverage by including types 6 and 11 as well.

 

Option B: HPV types 6 and 11: This is incomplete as it only includes the HPV types associated with genital warts (low-risk types). Gardasil also includes the high-risk oncogenic types 16 and 18.

 

Option D: HPV types 16, 18, 31, and 33: This combination does not match any currently available HPV vaccine. The newer Gardasil 9 is a nonavalent vaccine that includes types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58, but the original Gardasil is quadrivalent (6, 11, 16, 18).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gardasil is a quadrivalent HPV vaccine that protects against both low-risk HPV types (6, 11) that cause genital warts and high-risk HPV types (16, 18) that cause cervical cancer, providing broader protection than bivalent vaccines.

questions.text: Among the following options, which one is considered a presumptive sign of early pregnancy? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Softening of the cervix

 

Softening of the cervix or Goodell’s sign is a sign that appears at around 6 weeks in early pregnancy. It is an early pregnancy sign. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ballottement: This is a 2nd trimester sign of pregnancy. Ballottement can be external or internal. 

 

Option B. Braxton Hicks contractions: These are painless, irregular uterine contractions that begin in the second trimester. They are symptoms of the patient and not signs. 

 

Option C. Amenorrhoea: Amenorrhoea in a patient who has been having previously regular cycles is the most common symptom of pregnancy. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Softening of the cervix or Goodell’s sign is a Presumptive sign of the 1st trimester of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which infection is typically associated with a creamy, fishy odor? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gardnerella

 

Bacterial Vaginosis (BV) caused by Gardnerella vaginalis produces a characteristic fishy odor vaginal discharge. This distinctive odor is one of the key diagnostic criteria for BV. The discharge is typically thin, homogeneous, gray-white that coats the vaginal walls. The fishy smell becomes more pronounced during the "Whiff test" when 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to the discharge, releasing volatile amines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: Trichomonas infection causes a greenish-yellowish discharge that is often frothy. It's associated with dysuria, dyspareunia, and the characteristic "strawberry cervix" appearance, but lacks the fishy odor.

 

Option C. Candida: Candida infection presents with thick curdy white discharge resembling cottage cheese or flakes adherent to the vaginal wall. It causes intense pruritus but has no fishy odor. The vaginal pH remains acidic (<4.5).

 

Option D. Chlamydia: Chlamydia typically causes mucopurulent cervical discharge but is not associated with fishy odor. It's often asymptomatic and is a common cause of cervicitis and PID when it ascends to the upper genital tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a fishy odor, especially when performing the Whiff test, is a pathognomonic feature of Bacterial Vaginosis, which provides a key clinical distinction from other vaginal infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with vaginal bleeding. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 8.0 mm. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histopathological examination of curettage

 

In postmenopausal women with vaginal bleeding, endometrial thickness >5mm on transvaginal ultrasound warrants histopathological examination to exclude malignancy. The evaluation algorithm for postmenopausal bleeding specifically indicates that endometrial biopsy is necessary when endometrial thickness exceeds 5mm. This patient's endometrial thickness is 8mm, which exceeds this threshold and necessitates tissue sampling to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is too aggressive as an initial step. Hysterectomy should only be considered after histopathological confirmation of malignancy or in cases of complex hyperplasia with atypia that has a 29% risk of progression to cancer. The diagnostic workup must be completed first.

 

Option B. Begin progesterone therapy: Treatment cannot begin without a tissue diagnosis. Progesterone therapy is appropriate for certain types of endometrial hyperplasia, but diagnosis must precede treatment. Different types of hyperplasia have different management approaches based on their risk of progression to cancer.

 

Option D. Follow-up sonography: This would be appropriate if the endometrial thickness was <5mm. Since the thickness is 8mm, which exceeds the 5mm threshold for postmenopausal women with bleeding, immediate histopathological examination is indicated rather than follow-up imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal bleeding, endometrial thickness >5mm on transvaginal ultrasound necessitates histopathological examination to rule out endometrial malignancy, regardless of other clinical factors.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with dysgerminoma of the ovary, which tumor marker is most likely to be elevated? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH)

 

Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary, accounting for 30-40% of malignant germ cell tumors. The characteristic tumor marker for dysgerminoma is Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH). This specific tumor marker is used clinically for diagnosis, monitoring treatment response, and surveillance for recurrence in patients with dysgerminoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Serum HCG: Serum HCG is the tumor marker for non-gestational choriocarcinoma of the ovary, not dysgerminoma. While some dysgerminomas may occasionally produce HCG if they contain syncytiotrophoblastic giant cells, it is not the primary or characteristic tumor marker for pure dysgerminoma.

 

Option B: Serum Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): Alpha-fetoprotein is the characteristic tumor marker for yolk sac tumors (endodermal sinus tumors). It is not typically elevated in pure dysgerminoma. If a dysgerminoma shows elevated AFP, it suggests the presence of mixed germ cell elements, particularly yolk sac components.

 

Option D: Serum CA 19-9: CA 19-9 is not a typical tumor marker for germ cell tumors of the ovary. It is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal malignancies, particularly pancreatic cancer. It may be elevated in some epithelial ovarian tumors, especially mucinous types, but not in dysgerminoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum LDH is the primary tumor marker for dysgerminoma and should be monitored for diagnosis, treatment response, and surveillance of this malignant germ cell tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is NOT true? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) levels are reduced

 

In PCOS, FSH levels are not specifically reduced but rather not increased. FSH level is typically normal due to the negative feedback effect of chronically elevated estrogen and follicular inhibin. While there is an elevated LH

 

ratio in PCOS, this is primarily due to increased LH rather than decreased FSH. FSH levels typically remain within normal range in patients with PCOS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luteinizing Hormone (LH) levels are elevated: This is TRUE. In PCOS, there is increased pulse frequency of GnRH which leads to preferential LH secretion rather than FSH, resulting in tonically elevated LH levels. The LH ratio is frequently > 2:1, which is characteristic of PCOS.

 

Option C. Estrogen levels are elevated: This is TRUE. In PCOS, there are raised levels of estradiol and estrone, with estrone being markedly elevated. PCOS creates a tonic hyperestrogenic state due to peripheral conversion of androgens (mainly androstenedione) to estrone and reduced SHBG leading to increased free estradiol.

 

Option D. Androgen levels are elevated : This is TRUE. Hyperandrogenism is a key feature of PCOS, with elevated androgens mainly from the ovary but also from the adrenals. Androstenedione is raised, serum testosterone is typically > 150 ng/dL, and DHEA-S may be marginally elevated. This androgen excess produces clinical symptoms like hirsutism and acne.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In PCOS, there is a characteristic hormonal profile with elevated LH, normal FSH (creating an increased LH ratio), elevated androgens, and elevated estrogens (particularly estrone), with the primary abnormality being androgen excess from the ovaries and a disturbed hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

choices.text: Interference with implantation of fertilized ovum

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a mechanism of action of the oral contraceptive pill? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interference with placental functioning

 

Oral contraceptive pills work through multiple mechanisms, but interfering with placental functioning is not one of them. The primary mechanisms are aimed at preventing pregnancy before implantation occurs. Once placental development begins, OCPs have no effect, which is why they cannot terminate an established pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of ovulation: This is a primary mechanism of combined oral contraceptives. The hormones synergistically suppress FSH and LH release from the pituitary, preventing follicular development and ovulation.

 

Option B. Prevention of fertilization: OCPs alter cervical mucus, making it thick, viscid and scanty, which creates a barrier that prevents sperm penetration into the upper genital tract.

 

Option C. Interference with implantation: OCPs produce endometrial changes including stromal edema, decidual reaction, and regression of glands, making the endometrium non-receptive to a developing blastocyst.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Oral contraceptives function exclusively by preventing the establishment of pregnancy through pre-implantation mechanisms rather than disrupting already established pregnancies or placental function.

questions.text: What is the smallest diameter of the true pelvis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sacrocotyloid diameter

 

The sacrocotyloid diameter measures 9.5 cm (3¾") and represents the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the iliopubic eminence. This is the smallest diameter among the major pelvic measurements in the true pelvis. It holds particular clinical significance as it represents the space occupied by the biparietal diameter of the fetal head while negotiating the pelvic brim in cases of flat pelvis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interspinous diameter: The interspinous (or bispinous) diameter measures 10.5 cm and extends between the tips of the two ischial spines. While this is an important diameter at the midpelvis and represents the narrowest part of the pelvic cavity, it is still larger than the sacrocotyloid diameter.

 

Option B. Diagonal conjugate: The diagonal conjugate measures 12 cm (4¾") and extends from the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint of the sacral promontory. This is significantly larger than the sacrocotyloid diameter and is measured clinically during pelvic assessment.

 

Option C. True conjugate: The true conjugate (also called anatomical conjugate) measures 11 cm (4¼") and extends from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis. Though important, it is not the smallest pelvic diameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sacrocotyloid diameter (9.5 cm) is the smallest of the major pelvic measurements and has clinical significance in obstetrics as it may limit fetal head passage through the pelvic inlet, particularly in cases of flat pelvis.

questions.text: What does the term "aspermia" specifically refer to? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Absence of semen

 

Aspermia specifically refers to the failure of emission of semen (no ejaculate). This represents a condition where there is complete absence of ejaculate during sexual activity, distinct from other sperm or semen abnormalities. It's categorized under post-testicular causes of male infertility and affects the emission phase of ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Absence of sperm in ejaculate: This is incorrect as it describes azoospermia, not aspermia. Azoospermia means there is semen but it contains no spermatozoa.

 

Option C. Absence of sperm motility: This is incorrect as it describes asthenozoospermia or necrozoospermia. Asthenozoospermia refers to reduced sperm motility, while necrozoospermia refers to spermatozoa that are dead or motionless.

 

Option D. Occurrence of abnormal sperm: This is incorrect as it describes teratozoospermia, which is defined as a high percentage (>70%) of spermatozoa with abnormal morphology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspermia specifically refers to the complete absence of semen ejaculate, representing a failure of emission, which differs from conditions affecting sperm quality or quantity within the ejaculate.

questions.text: Up to what duration of pregnancy is the anti-progesterone compound RU-486 (Mifepristone) effective for inducing abortion? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 63 days

 

In the context of medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), mifepristone (RU-486) is effective for inducing abortion up to 63 days (9 weeks) of pregnancy. The efficacy of the medical method using mifepristone plus misoprostol decreases after 7 weeks, with success rates of 98% up to 7 weeks and dropping to 95% for pregnancies between 7-9 weeks (63 days).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 72 days: This duration (approximately 10 weeks) exceeds the recommended timeframe for mifepristone use in medical abortion. The efficacy significantly decreases beyond 9 weeks.

 

Option C. 88 days: This duration (approximately 12-13 weeks) falls into the second trimester, where medical methods still use mifepristone but with different protocols and dosing regimens than first-trimester procedures.

 

Option D. 120 days: This duration (approximately 17 weeks) is well into the second trimester, where mifepristone may be used but with different protocols and higher risks compared to first-trimester abortions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mifepristone combined with misoprostol is most effective for medical termination of pregnancy when used within the first 9 weeks (63 days) of pregnancy, with optimal results achieved when used before 7 weeks.

questions.text: At what gestational age can congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) typically be diagnosed via fetal ultrasound? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24 Weeks

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH) are commonly diagnosed antenatally, most frequently during the second trimester ultrasound, typically around 18-24 weeks of gestation. While some cases can be identified earlier, like during the dating scan or as early as 10-12 weeks, and others may not be detected until the third trimester or even postpartum, the majority are discovered during the second trimester ultrasound. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9 Weeks: This is too early for CDH diagnosis. At 9 weeks, fetal anatomical structures are still developing and not sufficiently differentiated to allow reliable detection of diaphragmatic defects. The diaphragm and thoracic structures are not adequately developed or visible on ultrasound at this early stage.

 

Option B. 15: While CDH can be detected at 15 weeks, in majority of cases, it is detected after 20 weeks

 

Option D. 30 Weeks: This is quite late for initial diagnosis of CDH. While some cases may remain undetected until the third trimester (which begins at 28 weeks), this represents delayed rather than typical diagnosis. Most cases of CDH should be identified during second-trimester anatomical surveys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia can typically be diagnosed via ultrasound as early as 14-15 weeks but the typical time of diagnosis is between 18-24 weeks.

questions.text: In a partogram, the progression of labor is charted with respect to which of the following? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervical dilatation

 

The partogram (also called partograph) is a graphic representation of labor progress where cervical dilatation is plotted against time. The graph shows cervical dilatation measured in centimeters plotted as "X" marks against time in hours. This creates the primary curve that demonstrates the progression of labor. The partogram divides labor into latent phase and active phase, with the active phase starting at 5 cm dilatation according to the WHO Labor Care Guide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal Heart Rate: is incorrect because while fetal heart rate is recorded on the partogram, it is not the parameter used to chart the progression of labor. FHR is monitored and recorded to assess fetal wellbeing during labor.

 

Option C. Maternal BP: is incorrect because maternal blood pressure is monitored and recorded on the partogram for maternal safety, but it does not reflect the progression of labor.

 

Option D. Cervical length: is incorrect because although cervical length is related to labor progress (through effacement), it is cervical dilatation, not length, that is specifically plotted to track labor progression on the partogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The partogram tracks labor progression primarily through plotting cervical dilatation against time, allowing visualization of the labor curve and early identification of deviation from normal labor patterns. This graphic tool is essential for timely decisions regarding labor management.

questions.text: Which of the following sequences correctly describes the progression from disease to disability? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disease - Impairment - Disability – Handicap

 

The correct sequence of progression from disease to disability is:

 

 

  • This represents the logical progression where a disease process first causes structural or functional abnormalities (impairment), which then restricts activities (disability), ultimately resulting in social disadvantage (handicap).
  • WHO defines impairment as "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological or anatomical structure or function," disability as "restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in a normal manner," and handicap as "disadvantage that limits fulfillment of a normal role."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disease - Disability - Impairment - Handicap: This sequence incorrectly places disability before impairment. Impairment (anatomical/physiological loss) must occur before disability (functional limitation) in the causal pathway.

 

Option C. Disease - Disability - Handicap – Impairment: This sequence incorrectly places impairment at the end. Impairment is the direct consequence of disease and precedes both disability and handicap in the progression.

 

Option D. Disease - Handicap - Disability – Impairment: This sequence reverses the established progression. A specific example illustrates this: an accident (disease) leads to loss of foot (impairment), which causes inability to walk (disability), resulting in unemployment (handicap).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence Disease → Impairment → Disability → Handicap represents a causal chain where disease causes anatomical/functional changes, leading to activity limitations, and ultimately resulting in social disadvantages that prevent fulfillment of normal roles.

questions.text: When two variables demonstrate a strong positive correlation, what is the value of their coefficient of correlation? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) +1

 

  • The correlation coefficient (r) is bounded between -1.0 and +1.0. When examining the relationship between two variables, a value of r approaching +1 indicates a strong positive association. 
  • This means when one variable increases, the other variable also increases proportionally, creating a direct relationship that characterizes strong positive correlation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. -1: This value represents a strong negative correlation, where one variable increases as the other decreases. When r is near -1, it indicates that the variables move in opposite directions.

 

Option B. 0: When r = 0, it indicates no association between the variables. There is no linear relationship present when the correlation coefficient is zero.

 

Option D. +2: This value is impossible for a correlation coefficient. The correlation coefficient r must lie between -1.0 and +1.0. Any value outside this range is mathematically invalid. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correlation coefficient (r) must fall within the range of -1 to +1, with +1 representing perfect positive correlation where both variables move proportionally in the same direction.

questions.text: Which term is used to describe the first case of a disease that comes to the attention of an investigator? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (b) Index case

 

The index case is defined as the first case of a disease that comes to the attention of the investigator. This is an important epidemiological concept because the index case may not necessarily be the first case that occurred in the population. The index case is the one that triggers the investigation, leading to the identification of other cases in an outbreak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient Zero: A synonym for Index case but is a less precise term: it may be used to describe either the first case of the disease, the first case on record, or the first case within a specific group

 

Option C. Primary case - The primary case refers to the first case of a communicable disease introduced into the population unit being studied. The primary case represents the actual first occurrence in the outbreak, not the first one detected by health officials.

 

Option D. Secondary case - Secondary cases are those that develop from contact with the primary case. These represent subsequent transmission in the outbreak chain, not the first identified case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In epidemiological investigations, the index case (first identified) is distinguished from the primary case (first occurrence), which is crucial for accurate outbreak investigation and understanding transmission dynamics.

choices.text: Not related to the incubation period

questions.text: In the context of a communicable disease, when the maximal infectivity occurs during the incubation period, what is the relationship between the generation time and the incubation period? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Shorter than the incubation period

 

  • Generation time is defined as "the interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host." 
  • When maximal infectivity occurs during the incubation period (before symptoms appear), the generation time must be shorter than the incubation period, as the incubation period extends from infection until the first appearance of symptoms. 
  • Though generation time is generally roughly equal to incubation period, this specific scenario describes a situation where maximum infectivity precedes symptom onset.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Longer than the incubation period: This would only be true if maximal infectivity occurred after the appearance of symptoms (after the incubation period ended), but the question specifically states maximal infectivity occurs during the incubation period.

 

Option C. Equal to the incubation period: While generation time is roughly equal to the incubation period in many diseases, this does not apply when maximal infectivity occurs before the end of the incubation period, as specified in the question.

 

Option D. Not related to the incubation period: These concepts are clearly related. Generation time and incubation period are related concepts in infectious disease epidemiology, with specific temporal relationships.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generation time measures the interval from infection to maximal infectivity, while incubation period measures time from infection to symptom onset. Their relationship varies by disease, but when maximal infectivity occurs during the incubation period, generation time must be shorter than incubation period.

choices.text: Easily curable or highly fatal disease

questions.text: What does it indicate about a disease if it has a high incidence but low prevalence? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (a) Easily curable or highly fatal disease

 

  • The relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed by the formula P = I × D, where P is prevalence, I is incidence, and D is duration of disease. 
  • When a disease has high incidence but low prevalence, it indicates that despite many new cases occurring (high incidence), the cases don't accumulate in the population (low prevalence). 
  • This happens when the duration of illness is short - either because patients recover quickly (easily curable) or die rapidly (highly fatal). Examples include food poisoning (rapid recovery) and homicides (rapidly fatal) which have virtually no prevalence despite having incidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Highly infectious: High infectiousness increases incidence (new cases) but doesn't necessarily result in low prevalence. Without rapid resolution, infectious diseases could still accumulate many cases, leading to high prevalence.

 

Option C. Chronic disease: Chronic diseases show the opposite pattern. Tuberculosis, for example, has a high prevalence rate relative to incidence because new cases keep occurring while old ones persist for months or years. Chronic diseases typically have high prevalence relative to incidence.

 

Option D. Poor reporting practices: This doesn't explain the epidemiological relationship between incidence and prevalence. Poor reporting would likely affect both measures, not create a specific pattern of high incidence with low prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mathematical relationship between prevalence, incidence and duration (P = I × D) demonstrates that diseases with short duration (due to rapid cure or death) will show high incidence but low prevalence in a population.

questions.text: What percentage of data values fall within two standard deviations from the mean in a normal distribution? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 95.4%

 

  • In a normal distribution, the percentage of values falling within two standard deviations (Mean ± 2SD) on either side of the mean is 95.4%. This is one of the fundamental properties of the normal curve that follows the empirical rule, sometimes called the 68-95-99.7 rule. 
  • This property is crucial for statistical analysis as it helps determine confidence intervals and predict the probability of values falling within specific ranges.

 

Visual Support

 

The distribution of values in a normal curve follows this pattern:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 66.7%: This value doesn't represent any standard statistical range in a normal distribution. The percentage of values within Mean ± 1SD is 68.3%, not 66.7%.

 

Option B. 91.1%/: This percentage doesn't correspond to any standard interval in the normal distribution. It falls between the coverage of Mean ± 1SD (68.3%) and Mean ± 2SD (95.4%).

 

Option D. 99.7%: Mean ± 2SD. 99.7% represents the percentage of values that fall within three standard deviations (Mean ± 3SD) from the mean in a normal distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a normal distribution, 95.4% of all values fall within two standard deviations (Mean ± 2SD) of the mean, which is a critical concept for statistical analysis, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing.

questions.text: Under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP), what category and color of drug box was designated for sputum smear-positive cases treated after default? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Category 2, Blue

 

  • The Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) categorizes TB patients based on their treatment history and sputum status. Patients who are being treated after default are classified under Category 2. 
  • These retreatment cases receive their medications in patient-wise boxes that are color-coded blue. The blue box contains the full course of treatment for Category 2 patients, with medications packaged in blister packs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Category 1, Red: Category 1 with red boxes is designated for new TB cases (new sputum smear-positive, new sputum smear-negative, and new extrapulmonary TB cases), not for retreatment scenarios like default cases.

 

Option C. Category 2, Yellow: While Category 2 is correct for retreatment cases, the color code for Category 2 boxes is blue, not yellow. There is no yellow color code in the RNTCP treatment regimen.

 

Option D. Category 1, Green: This is incorrect on both counts. Category 1 does not include retreatment cases like default cases, and green is not a designated color for TB treatment boxes in the RNTCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retreatment TB patients, including those treated after default, are classified as Category 2 and receive their medications in blue-colored boxes, while new cases (Category 1) receive medications in red-colored boxes.

questions.text: Under the National Cancer Control Programme, oncology wings were sanctioned to: [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Medical College Hospitals

 

  • The National Cancer Control Programme was launched in 1975-76 and revised in 1984-85 and 2004. Under the revised programme, the Oncology Wing Development Scheme was specifically initiated to fill geographic gaps in cancer treatment facilities. 
  • This scheme provides central assistance of Rs. 3 crores per institution for purchase of equipment (including cobalt units) and civil work, while the manpower is provided by the concerned state government/institution. 
  • Medical College Hospitals were prioritized for establishing these oncology wings to ensure wider accessibility of cancer treatment facilities across the country.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regional Cancer Centres: The Regional Cancer Centre Scheme is a separate component of the NCCP. Instead of establishing new oncology wings, this scheme focuses on strengthening existing regional cancer centers to act as referral centers for complicated cases at the tertiary level.

 

Option B. Private Hospitals: The NCCP does not sanction oncology wings to private hospitals. The programme primarily works through government healthcare infrastructure to ensure affordability and accessibility of cancer care.

 

Option D. Voluntary Organizations: Voluntary organizations are engaged under the "Decentralized NGO Scheme" component of NCCP, but specifically for IEC activities and early detection of cancer, not for establishing oncology wings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oncology Wing Development Scheme under NCCP strategically establishes cancer treatment facilities in Medical College Hospitals to address geographic gaps in cancer care availability while utilizing existing healthcare education infrastructure.

questions.text: What is the minimum number of antenatal care (ANC) visits required according to the 2010 Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW) guidelines? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (d) 4

 

  • The minimum number of antenatal visits recommended is 4 visits covering the entire period of pregnancy. 
  • These visits follow a specific schedule: 1st visit within 12 weeks for registration and first check-up, 2nd visit between 14-26 weeks, 3rd visit between 28-34 weeks, and 4th visit between 36 weeks and term.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: One antenatal visit is grossly inadequate for monitoring pregnancy and detecting complications. A single visit cannot provide the necessary surveillance throughout the different stages of pregnancy.

 

Option B. 2: Two visits fall short of the recommended minimum and would not allow adequate monitoring of all stages of pregnancy, particularly in the critical third trimester.

 

Option C. 3: Three visits, while better than fewer, still does not meet the minimum requirement of 4 visits needed for comprehensive antenatal care.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A minimum of 4 antenatal visits is essential for adequate maternal and fetal monitoring throughout pregnancy, with each visit scheduled at specific gestational ages to detect and manage potential complications early.

choices.text: ½ of total energy and ½ of protein
⅓ of total energy and ½ of protein
½ of total energy and ⅓ of protein
⅓ of total energy and ⅓ of protein

questions.text: Meals under the Mid-day Meal Program (MDMP) should provide?[NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (b) ⅓ of total energy and ½ of protein

 

  • In formulating mid-day meals for school children, the established principle is that the meal should supply at least one-third of the total energy requirement, and half of the protein need. 
  • This balanced approach ensures the meal serves as an effective nutritional supplement without becoming a complete substitute for home diet, making it both nutritionally adequate and practically implementable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ½ of total energy and ½ of protein: The energy proportion is overstated. Providing half of daily energy requirements would make the meal too substantial and potentially costly.

 

Option C. ½ of total energy and ⅓ of protein: This option incorrectly reverses the proportions of both nutrients.

 

Option D. ⅓ of total energy and ⅓ of protein: While the energy proportion is correct, the protein requirement is understated. Growing children need more protein proportionally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mid-day meal program balances nutritional adequacy with practical implementation by focusing more heavily on protein (½ of daily needs) while providing moderate energy support (⅓ of daily needs) to school children.

questions.text: The provision for the post of ASHA was created under which scheme? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) NRHM

 

  • The provision for the post of ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) was created under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM). 
  • NRHM aims to provide accessible, affordable, accountable, effective and reliable primary health care, with ASHA workers serving as a bridge to reduce gaps in rural health care delivery. 
  • Creating a cadre of Accredited Social Health Activists is specifically listed as the first component in NRHM's Plan of Action to Strengthen Infrastructure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. ICDS (Integrated Child Development Services): ICDS works with Anganwadi Workers (AWWs) and focuses on supplementary nutrition, immunization, health check-ups, referral services, pre-school education, and nutrition & health education for children and mothers. ASHA is not part of the ICDS structure.

 

Option C. RCH (Reproductive and Child Health): The RCH program focuses on maternal and child health services but did not create the provision for ASHAs. RCH was later integrated into the overarching NRHM framework.

 

Option D. None: This is incorrect as ASHA was definitely created under NRHM as part of its core design and implementation strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASHA represents a key innovation of NRHM, designed to serve as the first point of contact between the community and the public health system in rural areas, making healthcare more accessible at the village level.

questions.text: What is the BMI of a person weighing 98 kg with a height of 175 cm? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (b) 32

 

The Body Mass Index (BMI) is calculated using the formula: BMI = Weight (kg) / Height² (m²). For this person:

 

Weight = 98 kg

 

Height = 175 cm = 1.75 m

 

BMI = 98 / (1.75)² = 98 / 3.0625 = 32.0

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30: is incorrect. If BMI were 30, the weight would be approximately 91.9 kg (30 × 1.75²).

 

Option C. 34: is incorrect. This would require a weight of approximately 104 kg (34 × 1.75²).

 

Option D. 36: is incorrect. This would require a weight of approximately 110.3 kg (36 × 1.75²).

 

Educational Objective:

 

BMI is classified into categories with clinical significance: a BMI of 32 falls into the Obese Class I category (30.00-34.99), which is associated with moderate risk of comorbidities in the WHO classification of adult obesity.

questions.text: What is the recommended daily allowance (RDA) for a woman engaged in heavy work? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 2800 kcal/day

 

The energy requirement for an adult woman engaged in heavy work is 2,850 kcal/day as established in the 2010 dietary guidelines. This is based on a reference woman weighing 55 kg, with heavy work requiring approximately 52 kcal/kg/day. 2800 kcal/day is the closest match to this recommendation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2300 kcal/day: This value is significantly lower than required for heavy work. It falls between the energy requirements for sedentary work (1,900 kcal/day) and moderate work (2,230 kcal/day) for adult women.

 

Option B. 2600 kcal/day: This is insufficient for heavy work, though it exceeds the requirement for moderate work. Heavy physical activity demands substantially more energy than this amount provides.

 

Option D. 3800 kcal/day: This greatly exceeds the recommended allowance for women engaged in heavy work (2,850 kcal/day). Even for men performing heavy work, the requirement is 3,490 kcal/day, making this value excessively high.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Energy requirements are specifically tailored to gender, body weight, and physical activity level, with heavy work requiring substantially more calories than sedentary or moderate work activities.

questions.text: Which of the following fruits is the richest source of Vitamin C? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Guava

 

  • Guava contains 212 mg of Vitamin C per 100g, making it the richest source among the given options. This is significantly higher than oranges, which contain only 68 mg per 100g. 
  • The hierarchy of Vitamin C content in fruits places Amla (Indian Gooseberry) at the top, followed by Guava, and then citrus fruits like oranges.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orange: Contains 68 mg of Vitamin C per 100g, which is considerably less than

 

Option C. Strawberry: Not listed with specific Vitamin C values in the nutritional tables of common fruits.

 

Option D. Kiwi: Not listed with specific Vitamin C values in the nutritional tables of common fruits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While Amla (Indian Gooseberry) is actually the richest natural source of Vitamin C (600 mg/100g), among the common fruits listed in the question options, guava stands out as an exceptionally rich non-citrus source of Vitamin C with more than three times the content found in oranges.

questions.text: Methionine, an essential amino acid, is deficient in which of the following? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Pulses

 

Pulses are deficient in methionine and cysteine. This is a characteristic nutritional limitation of pulse proteins. Despite their high overall protein content (20-25%), pulse proteins are considered nutritionally inferior to animal proteins partly due to this specific amino acid deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Milk: Milk proteins contain all essential amino acids in adequate proportions, including methionine. Milk proteins are nutritionally complete.

 

Option B. Meat: Meat is not deficient in methionine. Animal proteins are "biologically complete" because they contain all essential amino acids in adequate amounts.

 

Option D. Wheat: Wheat, as a cereal, has different limiting amino acids. Cereal proteins are deficient in lysine and threonine, not methionine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The complementary relationship between cereal and pulse proteins forms the nutritional basis for traditional food combinations in many cultures - cereals provide methionine (which pulses lack) while pulses provide lysine (which cereals lack), creating a complete protein profile when eaten together.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins can be synthesized by intestinal bacteria in sufficient amounts to meet body requirements? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin K exists in at least two major forms - vitamin K₁ and vitamin K₂. Vitamin K₂ is synthesized by intestinal bacteria, which usually provides an adequate supply for human needs. 
  • The bacterial synthesis in the intestine typically meets the body's vitamin K requirements, making it unique among vitamins in this regard.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12: While bacteria in the colon synthesize vitamin B12, this synthesis is not sufficient to meet human requirements. The fact that strict vegetarians develop B12 deficiency confirms that intestinal synthesis alone is inadequate.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: Vitamin A is obtained from animal sources as preformed vitamin A (retinol) and from plant sources as provitamins (carotenes). There is no significant bacterial synthesis of vitamin A in the intestines.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine must be obtained from dietary sources like cereals, pulses, and yeast. Intestinal bacteria do not synthesize significant amounts of thiamine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Intestinal bacteria normally produce adequate vitamin K₂ for body requirements, which explains why long-term antibiotic therapy that suppresses normal gut flora can lead to vitamin K deficiency.

questions.text: What is the earliest feature of Vitamin A deficiency? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Night blindness 

 

  • Night blindness (nyctalopia) is the first symptom and first manifestation of vitamin A deficiency. It occurs due to impairment in dark adaptation, where affected individuals cannot see in dim light or at dusk. 
  • Mothers can detect this condition when their children cannot see in late evenings or find them in a darkened room.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratomalacia: This represents the most severe form (X3B) of vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by liquefaction of the cornea, which may burst open leading to permanent vision loss. It occurs at a much later stage in the progression of the disease.

 

Option B. Conjunctival xerosis: This is the first clinical sign (X1A) of vitamin A deficiency where the conjunctiva becomes dry and non-wettable, but it appears after night blindness has already developed.

 

Option C. Bitot's spot: These are the first specific manifestation (X1B), appearing after night blindness and conjunctival xerosis. They appear as triangular, pearly-white or yellowish foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The progression of vitamin A deficiency follows a clear sequence: night blindness (first symptom) → conjunctival xerosis (first clinical sign) → Bitot's spots → corneal xerosis → corneal ulceration → keratomalacia. 
  • Early detection at the night blindness stage allows for intervention before irreversible structural damage occurs.

questions.text: Sleeping Sickness is transmitted by: [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (b) Tse-Tse Fly

 

Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis) is transmitted by the Tse-tse fly (Glossina). This vector-borne disease relationship is fundamental in tropical medicine. The Tse-tse fly serves as the biological vector that transmits the trypanosomes responsible for African sleeping sickness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sandfly: Sandflies (Phlebotamus) transmit diseases like Kala Azar, Oriental Sore, Changuinola virus, Sicilian virus, Oraya fever, Sandfly Fever, Chandipura virus, and Naples virus - not sleeping sickness.

 

Option C. Ticks: Ticks (both soft and hard varieties) transmit diseases such as Q Fever, Relapsing Fever, KFD, tick paralysis, tick encephalitis, babesiosis, Congo fever, tularemia, and tick hemorrhagic fever. They do not transmit sleeping sickness.

 

Option D. Louse: Lice are vectors for epidemic typhus, trench fever, relapsing fever, and pediculosis. They are not associated with sleeping sickness.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vector-disease relationships are specific and important in epidemiology. The Tse-tse fly (Glossina) is the definitive vector for African sleeping sickness, while the American form of sleeping sickness (Chagas disease) is transmitted by the Reduviid bug (Triatominae), also called the kissing bug or assassin bug.

questions.text: Which mosquito is commonly found in urban areas? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (a) Anopheles Stephensi

 

  • Anopheles Stephensi is predominantly found in urban areas. This mosquito species has adapted well to urban environments and commonly breeds in overhead tanks, cisterns, and other artificial water containers typical in cities. 
  • It thrives in clean water collections found in urban infrastructure, making it the primary Anopheles species in urban settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anopheles Gambiae: This species is primarily found in Africa and not typically associated with urban environments in the Asian context.

 

Option C. Anopheles Culicifacies: This is predominantly a rural vector in India. It typically breeds in clean water bodies like streams and irrigation channels in agricultural settings.

 

Option D. Anopheles Baimaii: This species is mainly found in forest and forest-fringe areas, preferring natural breeding sites rather than urban environments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vector mosquitoes have specific ecological niches and breeding preferences. Anopheles Stephensi's adaptation to urban environments makes it particularly important for malaria control programs in cities, where it utilizes man-made clean water collections for breeding.

questions.text: Who proposed the theory of multifactorial causation of disease? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (b) Pettenkoffer

 

  • The theory of multifactorial causation of disease was proposed by Patten Koffer (also spelled as Pettenkoffer). This theory recognizes that diseases result from the interaction of multiple factors rather than a single cause. 
  • The multifactorial causation model demonstrates how various factors contribute collectively to disease development through reactions at the cellular level, providing a more comprehensive understanding of disease etiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louis Pasteur: He proposed the Germ Theory of Disease, which attributes diseases to specific microorganisms, not the multifactorial causation theory.

 

Option C. Fracastorius: Not associated with any of the major disease causation theories in epidemiology.

 

Option D. Aristotle: He proposed the Theory of Spontaneous Generation, which incorrectly suggested that living organisms could arise from non-living matter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The multifactorial causation theory represents a significant advancement in understanding disease etiology by recognizing that most diseases result from complex interactions of multiple causal factors rather than single causes, moving beyond the limitations of the germ theory.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is most heat stable? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (d) Hepatitis B

 

  • Hepatitis B belongs to Group F in the relative heat sensitivity classification, making it the least heat sensitive (most heat stable) vaccine among the given options. 
  • Vaccines are grouped from A to F based on their sensitivity to heat, with Group A being the most heat sensitive and Group F being the least heat sensitive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine): Incorrect OPV is classified in Group A, making it the most heat sensitive vaccine. It appears at the extreme left of the heat sensitivity scale, indicating its high vulnerability to heat degradation. For long-term storage, OPV requires temperatures between -15°C to -25°C.

 

Option B. Measles: Incorrect Measles vaccine falls in Group D of the heat sensitivity classification. As a freeze-dried vaccine, it has moderate heat sensitivity - more stable than OPV but less stable than BCG and Hepatitis B.

 

Option C. BCG: Incorrect BCG vaccine is categorized in Group E of heat sensitivity. While it demonstrates good heat stability and is more stable than both OPV and Measles, it is still more heat sensitive than Hepatitis B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The heat stability of vaccines follows a distinct hierarchy: Hepatitis B (Group F) → BCG (Group E) → Measles (Group D) → OPV (Group A). 
  • This property significantly impacts cold chain management requirements for each vaccine, with the most heat-sensitive vaccines requiring stricter temperature controls.

questions.text: The Live Attenuated H1N1 Influenza vaccine is administered by which route? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Intranasal

 

  • Live attenuated influenza vaccines are administered through the intranasal route. This provides immunity at the site where respiratory viruses normally enter the body. 
  • Live attenuated vaccines like H1N1 Live typically engage mucosal surfaces to produce both local (IgA) and systemic (IgG) immunity. 
  • The intranasal administration mimics the natural route of infection for influenza viruses, stimulating a more comprehensive immune response than parenteral routes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intramuscular: Intramuscular route is typically used for killed/inactivated vaccines, including inactivated influenza vaccines. The H1N1 Killed vaccine would be administered through this route, not the live attenuated version. Intramuscular administration bypasses the respiratory mucosa where influenza viruses naturally replicate.

 

Option C. Subcutaneous: Subcutaneous administration is primarily used for certain killed vaccines and toxoids. Live viral vaccines targeting respiratory pathogens would not achieve optimal mucosal immunity through this route, making it inappropriate for live attenuated influenza vaccines.

 

Option D. Intradermal: Intradermal route is used for specific vaccines like BCG and fractional IPV. This route provides limited exposure to mucosal surfaces and would not be effective for respiratory virus vaccines that require replication in the respiratory tract to generate proper immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live attenuated vaccines are designed to mimic natural infection, and for respiratory pathogens like influenza, intranasal administration provides direct access to respiratory mucosa where the virus naturally replicates, producing both mucosal and systemic immunity.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not given during pregnancy? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles

 

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated during pregnancy because it is a live attenuated vaccine. 
  • Pregnancy is considered an immunocompromised state, and live vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy except for Yellow Fever vaccine. 
  • Administration of measles vaccine during pregnancy could theoretically pose a risk to the developing fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus Toxoid: Tetanus Toxoid is routinely administered during pregnancy. It's included in the standard antenatal care protocol with TT-1 given early in pregnancy and TT-2 given four weeks later, or a booster dose if the woman received TT doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years.

 

Option C. HBV (Hepatitis B): Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a live vaccine. It can be safely administered during pregnancy when indicated and poses no theoretical risk to the fetus.

 

Option D. Rabies: Rabies vaccine is a killed/inactivated vaccine. It can be administered during pregnancy in post-exposure situations without risk to the fetus. As it's not a live vaccine, it doesn't carry the theoretical risks that contraindicate live vaccines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live attenuated vaccines are generally contraindicated during pregnancy due to theoretical risk of fetal infection, while killed/inactivated vaccines, toxoids, and recombinant vaccines can be administered during pregnancy when indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines contains the largest amount of egg protein? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Yellow Fever

 

  • Yellow fever vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine prepared from the 17D strain, which is grown in chick embryo and subsequently freeze-dried. 
  • The vaccine contains significant egg protein content, which explains why anaphylaxis reactions have been documented, occurring mainly in individuals with egg allergies. 
  • This vaccine requires careful storage between +5 and -30°C, preferably below zero.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rabies: Modern rabies vaccines like PCECV (Purified Chick Embryo Cell Vaccine) and PVRV (Purified Vero cell Vaccine) undergo extensive purification processes specifically designed to remove cellular proteins, resulting in lower egg protein content.

 

Option B. MMR: The MMR vaccine uses production methods that result in minimal egg protein in the final product. Egg allergy is not considered a major contraindication for MMR administration.

 

Option C. Influenza: While influenza vaccines are typically produced in eggs, the manufacturing process includes purification steps to reduce egg protein content below that found in yellow fever vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yellow fever vaccine's production method in chick embryo without extensive protein removal results in higher egg protein content than other vaccines, necessitating caution in individuals with egg allergies.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not accurate concerning a chalazion? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Associated with Severe Pain

 

A chalazion is characterized by being painless rather than painful. Chalazion symptoms include "painless swelling in the eyelid, gradually increasing in size." It is specifically described as a "chronic non-infective (non-suppurative) lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland" that develops without significant pain, which contrasts with painful conditions like hordeolum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Onset: Correct statement. Chalazion is defined as a "chronic non-infective lipogranulomatous inflammation" that develops gradually with "painless swelling in the eyelid, gradually increasing in size."

 

Option B. Involvement of the Meibomian Gland: Correct statement. Chalazion is specifically described as a "chronic non-infective (non-suppurative) lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland."

 

Option D. Characterized by Granulomatous Inflammation: Correct statement. A chalazion is definitively a "lipogranulomatous inflammation."

 

Contrast with painful lid conditions: Unlike chalazion, conditions like hordeolum externum (stye) and hordeolum internum are characterized by "acute pain associated with swelling of the lid." In hordeolum internum, the pain is even described as "more intense, due to the swelling being embedded deeply in the dense fibrous tissue."

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chalazion is a painless, chronic, lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland, which distinguishes it from painful acute lid conditions like hordeolum.

questions.text: Which syndrome is characterized by the symmetrical enlargement of both lacrimal and salivary glands? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mikulicz's Syndrome
