Mikulicz's Syndrome is specifically characterized by bilaterally symmetrical enlargement of the lacrimal and salivary glands. This condition is associated with various systemic diseases including leukemias, lymphosarcomas, benign lymphoid hyperplasia, Hodgkin's disease, sarcoidosis, and tuberculosis. This distinct pattern of bilateral glandular enlargement is the hallmark feature that defines this syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sjögren's Syndrome: While Sjögren's syndrome does affect both lacrimal and salivary glands, it presents primarily as an autoimmune chronic inflammatory disease characterized by aqueous deficiency dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and xerostomia (dryness of mouth), not symmetrical glandular enlargement. It typically occurs in women between 40-50 years of age.

 

Option C. Sturge-Weber Syndrome: This is associated with nevus flammeus (port wine stain), not lacrimal or salivary gland enlargement. It's characterized by facial vascular malformation.

 

Option D. Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome: This is associated with poliosis (greying of eyelashes and eyebrows) and various ocular conditions, not with lacrimal or salivary gland enlargement.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mikulicz's Syndrome presents with bilateral symmetrical enlargement of both lacrimal and salivary glands and should prompt investigation for underlying systemic conditions like lymphoproliferative disorders, sarcoidosis, or tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Vogt's triad in primary angle closure glaucoma? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Goniosynechiae

 

Vogt's triad is seen in both treated and non-treated cases after an attack of acute primary angle closure (PAC). It is specifically characterized by three distinct features: glaukomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity), patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreacting pupil due to sphincter atrophy. Goniosynechiae (peripheral anterior synechiae) are not part of Vogt's triad, though they are common findings in angle closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iris atrophy: This is a component of Vogt's triad. Patches of iris atrophy occur due to ischemic damage during the acute attack and represent one of the three classic findings.

 

Option C. Non-reacting pupil: This is a component of Vogt's triad. The slightly dilated, non-reactive pupil results from sphincter atrophy caused by ischemia during the acute attack.

 

Option D. Glaukomflecken: These are correctly described as part of Vogt's triad. Glaukomflecken are anterior subcapsular lenticular opacities that develop following an acute attack of angle closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vogt's triad consists of glaukomflecken (anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity), patches of iris atrophy, and slightly dilated non reacting pupil due to sphincter atrophy—it is a classic finding following an attack of acute primary angle closure glaucoma, while goniosynechiae represent a different pathological finding in this condition.

questions.text: Which condition is suggested by a painful red eye with a small and irregular pupil? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iritis/Iridocyclitis

 

Iritis/iridocyclitis classically presents with a painful red eye with circumcorneal congestion. The key diagnostic sign is the constricted and irregular pupil, which results from inflammation of the iris causing sphincter spasm and the formation of posterior synechiae. This pattern of symptoms forms a distinctive clinical picture that helps differentiate anterior uveitis from other causes of red eye.

 

Visual Support: In acute iritis, you would observe:

 

  • Pain localized to the eye
  • Circumcorneal redness (ciliary flush)
  • Constricted, irregular pupil
  • Cells in the anterior chamber
  • Keratic precipitates on the cornea

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Conjunctivitis: While conjunctivitis causes redness, it presents with foreign body sensation and itching rather than localized pain. The pupil remains normal in size and shape, unlike the constricted irregular pupil seen in iritis. The congestion is conjunctival rather than circumcorneal.

 

Option B. Corneal Ulcer: Though corneal ulcers present with pain and redness, the pupil is typically constricted but not irregular. The primary features are corneal ulceration/suppuration, which are not mentioned in the question scenario.

 

Option D. Acute Glaucoma: Acute glaucoma presents with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil (not constricted and irregular). It typically causes severe pain radiating beyond the eye, often with headache, nausea and vomiting, and marked elevation of intraocular pressure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A constricted, irregular pupil with circumcorneal redness and localized eye pain is the classic presentation of anterior uveitis (iritis/iridocyclitis) and should prompt immediate ophthalmologic evaluation to prevent complications like posterior synechiae and secondary glaucoma.

choices.text: Difference in the axial length of the eyeballs
Difference in the size of corneas
Difference in the size of pupils
Difference in the size of images formed by the two eyes

questions.text: What does aniseikonia refer to? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Difference in the size of images formed by the two eyes

 

Aniseikonia is defined as a condition wherein the images projected to the visual cortex from the two retinae are abnormally unequal in size and/or shape. Up to 5% aniseikonia is well tolerated by the visual system. The term specifically refers to the difference in image size perception between the two eyes, not the physical difference in ocular structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Difference in the axial length of the eyeballs: This is incorrect. While differences in axial length may cause anisometropia (unequal refractive error between eyes), it is not aniseikonia. Anisometropia can lead to aniseikonia, but they are distinct conditions. Anisometropia refers to the optical state when the total refraction of the two eyes is unequal.

 

Option B. Difference in the size of corneas: This is incorrect. Different corneal sizes may contribute to refractive differences between eyes but don't directly define aniseikonia. Aniseikonia specifically refers to the perceived image size difference, not the anatomical difference in corneal dimensions.

 

Option C. Difference in the size of pupils: This is incorrect. Pupil size differences (anisocoria) affect light entry but not image size perception. Pupils regulate light entry to the eye but don't significantly impact the size of images formed on the retina or perceived by the visual cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aniseikonia represents a perceptual phenomenon where the brain receives differently sized images from each eye, which can result from optical correction of anisometropia, retinal displacement, or cortical processing differences. It's a critical concept in understanding visual discomfort in patients with high refractive correction differences between eyes.

questions.text: Which feature is not associated with trachoma? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haab's Stria

 

Haab's stria is not associated with trachoma. These horizontal breaks in Descemet's membrane occur in congenital glaucoma, not in trachomatous infection. Trachoma is a chronic keratoconjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis with specific clinical features and sequelae that don't include Haab's stria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herbert's Pit: This is incorrect because Herbert's pits are specifically characteristic of trachoma. They are oval or circular pitted scars left after healing of Herbert follicles in the limbal area. These pits remain as permanent sequelae of the disease.

 

Option B. Arlt's line: This is incorrect because Arlt's line is a defining feature of trachoma. It refers to the linear scar present in the sulcus subtarsalis that forms during the cicatricial phase of trachoma as part of the scarring process.

 

Option C. Leber cells: This is incorrect because Leber cells are components of trachomatous follicles. These large multinucleated cells are found in the central part of each follicle along with mononuclear histiocytes and lymphocytes. Their presence helps differentiate trachoma follicles from follicles of other forms of follicular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Trachoma's pathognomonic features include Herbert's pits, Arlt's line, and follicles containing Leber cells, while Haab's stria belong to a completely different pathology (congenital glaucoma).

questions.text: What are the rounded, depressed regions of necrotic limbal follicles known as? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herbert's pits

 

Herbert's pits are the rounded, depressed regions that form after the healing of necrotic limbal follicles in trachoma. They represent a characteristic feature of the cicatricial phase of trachoma and remain as permanent sequelae of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Von Arlt's line: This is incorrect because Arlt's line refers to a linear scar present in the sulcus subtarsalis (the groove where the palpebral conjunctiva connects with the skin). It is another cicatricial feature of trachoma but is not related to necrotic limbal follicles. Arlt's line forms during the scarring stage of trachoma.

 

Option C. Fuchs' spots: This is incorrect because Fuchs' spots (or islets of Vogt) are whitish infiltrates seen in front of the head of a progressive pterygium. They are unrelated to trachoma or necrotic limbal follicles, being instead associated with pterygium formation.

 

Option D. Horner-Trantas dots: This is incorrect because Horner-Trantas spots are discrete whitish raised dots along the limbus seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They represent eosinophilic accumulations at the limbus, not necrotic follicles. They are characteristic of allergic conjunctival disease, not trachomatous infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Herbert's pits are pathognomonic scarring lesions of trachoma that form at the limbus after healing of Herbert's follicles, appearing as oval or circular pitted scars that persist as permanent markers of previous trachomatous infection.

questions.text: What is the primary action of the superior oblique muscle? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, Abduction, and Depression

 

The superior oblique muscle has three actions that can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID" where "SO" stands for Superior Oblique and "LID" stands for the three actions: Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression. The primary action of superior oblique is intorsion, the secondary action is depression, and the tertiary action is abduction. This functional pattern is consistent across all standard ophthalmology references.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adduction, Intorsion, and Depression: This is incorrect because the superior oblique causes abduction, not adduction. Adduction is primarily the action of the medial rectus muscle.

 

Option C.Abduction, Extorsion, and Depression: This is incorrect because superior oblique causes intorsion, not extorsion. Extorsion is the action of the inferior oblique muscle.

 

Options D. Elevation, Intorsion, and Adduction: This is incorrect on two counts. Superior oblique causes depression (not elevation) and abduction (not adduction). Elevation is primarily the action of the superior rectus and inferior oblique muscles.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The superior oblique muscle primarily produces intorsion, with secondary action of depression and tertiary action of abduction (lateral movement). This can be remembered with the mnemonic "SOLID" (Superior Oblique - Lateral, Intorsion, Depression).

questions.text: Which of the following is the layer between the choroid and the retina? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bruch's membrane

 

Bruch's membrane is the layer situated between the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), which is the outermost layer of the retina. It serves as a basement membrane to which the RPE is firmly adherent. This anatomical relationship is fundamental to understanding many retinal pathologies such as age-related macular degeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Descemet's membrane: This is incorrect as Descemet's membrane is located in the cornea, specifically between the corneal stroma and the corneal endothelium, not in the retina.

 

Option C. Photoreceptors: This is incorrect as photoreceptors (rods and cones) form the second layer of the retina, not the interface between choroid and retina. They are located within the neurosensory retina above the RPE.

 

Option D. Ganglion cell layer: This is incorrect as the ganglion cell layer is the eighth layer of the retina, containing cell bodies of ganglion cells, and is located much more internally than the choroid-retina interface.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bruch's membrane serves as a critical boundary between the vascular choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium, playing an important role in nutrient exchange and waste removal for the outer retinal layers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Argyll Robertson Pupil is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Consensual Light Reflex Normal

 

Argyll Robertson Pupil (ARP) is characterized by small, irregular pupils that accommodate but do not react to light - showing light-near dissociation. Both direct and consensual light reflexes are absent in ARP, while the near reflex remains intact. The consensual light reflex is absent, not normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Near Reflex Normal: The accommodation reflex is preserved in ARP. This is the key feature of light-near dissociation.

 

Option B. Direct Light Reflex Absent: This is a correct description of ARP, as the direct pupillary response to light is absent.

 

Option D. Visual Acuity Normal: Visual acuity is not affected by the pupillary abnormality in ARP.

 

Additional features of Argyll Robertson Pupil:

 

  • Bilateral involvement with small, irregular pupils
  • Pupils dilate poorly with mydriatics
  • Most commonly seen in tertiary neurosyphilis
  • Can also occur in diabetes, Wernicke's encephalopathy, and midbrain tumors
  • Caused by a lesion in the pretectal area of the midbrain

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Argyll Robertson Pupil shows complete light-near dissociation with absence of both direct and consensual light reflexes, while accommodation (near) reflex is preserved.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of non-ionizing radiation? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D (Infrared Rays)

 

Explanation: 

 

Infrared rays are classified as non-ionizing radiation. Non-ionizing radiation has lower energy levels that are insufficient to remove electrons from atoms or molecules, thus not creating ions. Ultrasonography is another example of non-ionizing radiation, which is why it's often preferred for certain applications like pregnancy imaging where radiation safety is paramount.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cosmic Rays - These are high-energy particles that originate from space and are a form of ionizing radiation. They have sufficient energy to remove electrons from atoms, creating ions.

 

Option B. Gamma Rays - These are electromagnetic waves with very high frequencies and energy levels. They are definitively ionizing radiation, capable of penetrating deeply into materials and causing significant ionization.

 

Option C. X-Rays - X-rays are a form of ionizing radiation used in radiography, fluoroscopy, and CT scanning. Their ionizing properties allow them to create images by differential absorption in tissues but also necessitate radiation safety protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding which radiological techniques use ionizing versus non-ionizing radiation is crucial for making appropriate imaging choices that balance diagnostic value with patient safety considerations.

choices.text: It has a half-life of 6 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) is NOT correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C (It emits Beta radiation)

 

Explanation

 

Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) emits gamma radiation, not beta radiation. The "m" in Tc-99m stands for metastable, which indicates that the nucleus releases gamma rays to reach a stable state. This metastable state decays by emitting low-energy gamma rays rather than beta emission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It has a half-life of 6 hours - CORRECT The physical half-life of Tc-99m is indeed 6 hours, meaning it loses roughly half of its radioactivity in that time. This relatively short half-life makes it ideal for diagnostic imaging while minimizing patient radiation exposure.

 

Option B. It is derived from Molybdenum - CORRECT Tc-99m is obtained from Molybdenum-99 generators used in nuclear medicine departments, allowing for on-site production of the radioisotope.

 

Option D. Its decay process is isomeric - CORRECT The "m" in Tc-99m stands for metastable, indicating an isomeric transition decay process where the nucleus releases energy (gamma rays) to reach a stable state without changing the number of protons or neutrons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Technetium-99m is the most widely used radioisotope in nuclear medicine due to its ideal 6-hour half-life, low-energy gamma emission (not beta), and versatility in being easily combined with various pharmaceuticals to target specific organs.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly lists the Hounsfield Units for air and water? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (Air: -1000, Water: 0)

 

Explanation: 

 

The Hounsfield Unit scale assigns specific values to different tissues and substances based on their radiodensity. On this scale, air has a value of -1000 and distilled water has a value of 0. This standardized scale provides objective measurement of blackness/whiteness on CT images, with water serving as the reference point from which other densities are measured.

 

Visual Support: The Hounsfield Unit scale shows these key values:

Air: -1000

Fat: -10 to -100

Distilled water: 0

Soft tissue: 20-30

Acute hemorrhage: 60-90

Iodinated contrast: 100-300

Bone/Ca²⁺: 1000

 

Other Options: 

  • Option B (Air: 0, Water: -1000) - This reverses the correct values, placing water at -1000 and air at 0, which contradicts the established Hounsfield scale.
  • Option C (Air: 0, Water: +1000) - This incorrectly assigns air the value of water (0) and gives water a value (+1000) that actually corresponds to bone density.
  • Option D (Air: +1000, Water: 0) - While this correctly identifies water as 0, it incorrectly assigns air a value of +1000, which is actually the approximate value for bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hounsfield Unit scale serves as the standardized measurement system for CT imaging, with water calibrated at 0 HU and air at -1000 HU, allowing for objective quantification of tissue densities across different CT examinations.

questions.text: Which of the following terms describes nuclides that have identical atomic mass numbers but different atomic numbers? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B (Isobars)

 

Explanation:

 

Isobars are nuclides that have the same mass number (A) but different atomic numbers (Z). This means they have the same total number of protons and neutrons, but the distribution between protons and neutrons differs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isotopes - Isotopes are different forms of the same element (same atomic number/Z) with different numbers of neutrons, resulting in different mass numbers (A). Isotopes have identical chemical properties but different physical properties due to their different masses.

 

Option C. Isotones - Isotones are nuclides that have the same number of neutrons but different numbers of protons. This results in different elements with different mass numbers but the same neutron count.

 

Option D. Isomers - Isomers are nuclides with identical atomic numbers (Z) and mass numbers (A), but different nuclear energy states. An example is Technetium-99m, where the "m" denotes a metastable state with higher energy than the ground state Technetium-99.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isobars are different elements with the same mass number but different atomic numbers, representing nuclides with the same total number of nucleons but different proton-to-neutron ratios.

questions.text: Which of the following features is NOT associated with Achondroplasia? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D (Vertical Acetabular Roof)

 

Explanation: 

 

Vertical Acetabular Roof is not a radiological feature associated with achondroplasia. Achondroplasia is the most common skeletal dysplasia, characterized by rhizomelic shortening (shortened proximal limbs) due to a mutation in the FGFR3 gene. The classic radiological features include bullet-shaped vertebrae, champagne glass pelvis, and metaphyseal flaring.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Bullet Shaped Vertebra - This is a characteristic finding in achondroplasia, showing posterior scalloping of the vertebral bodies, giving them a bullet-like appearance.
  • Option B. Champagne Glass Pelvis - This is a hallmark pelvic configuration in achondroplasia with narrow greater sciatic notch and flared iliac wings that resembles a champagne glass.
  • Option C. Trumpet Bone - While not always called by this specific name, the metaphyseal flaring with V-shaped metaphysis (Chevron sign) in achondroplasia gives long bones a trumpet-like appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia presents with distinctive radiological features including bullet-shaped vertebrae, champagne glass pelvis, and metaphyseal flaring, but vertical acetabular roof is not part of this skeletal dysplasia's characteristic pattern.

choices.text: Elevation of the right main bronchus
Enlargement of the left atrial appendage

questions.text: What is the earliest indicator of left atrial enlargement in cases of mitral stenosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B (Enlargement of the left atrial appendage)

 

Explanation:

 

Left atrial enlargement in mitral stenosis follows a specific pattern. The left atrial appendage (also called left auricle) is part of the normal left heart border, and its enlargement is the first radiographic sign of left atrial enlargement in mitral stenosis. This early change appears before other radiographic findings develop.

 

Left atrial enlargement in mitral stenosis manifests radiographically with straightening of the left heart border, which refers to the enlargement of the left atrial appendage that contributes to the left heart border contour.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elevation of the right main bronchus This is not an early sign of left atrial enlargement in mitral stenosis. While bronchial changes may occur with cardiac enlargement, elevation of the right main bronchus is not a characteristic early indicator in mitral stenosis cases.

 

Option C. Widening of the carina While splaying of the carina is a finding in mitral stenosis with left atrial enlargement, it is not the earliest indicator. Splaying of the carina occurs after the left atrium has significantly enlarged, not as the first radiographic sign.

 

Option D. Vertical displacement of the esophagus Displacement of the esophagus is not a recognized early sign of left atrial enlargement in mitral stenosis. The esophagus may be displaced in other cardiac conditions, but this is not an early indicator for mitral valve disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Left atrial enlargement in mitral stenosis first manifests radiographically as enlargement of the left atrial appendage, causing straightening of the left heart border, before progressing to other findings like double right heart border and splaying of the carina as the condition advances.

questions.text: FAST in the ATLS scheme is used for the evaluation of fluid in all of the following regions except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C (Pleura)

 

Explanation: 

 

The FAST examination protocol aims to identify intraperitoneal bleeding in trauma patients. A typical FAST examination involves searching for blood or fluid in the pericardium and peritoneum. The peritoneal search focuses on the area between the liver and right kidney and posterior pelvis (between the rectum and bladder in men and between the rectum and uterus in women) as these are the most dependent portions of the abdominopelvic cavity when the patient is supine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvis - INCORRECT. The posterior pelvis is specifically mentioned as one of the areas assessed in the FAST examination, as it's one of the most dependent portions of the abdominopelvic cavity when the patient is supine.

 

Option B. Pericardium - INCORRECT. The FAST examination explicitly includes searching for blood or fluid in the pericardium.

 

Option D. Perisplenic - INCORRECT. The perisplenic region would be included in the peritoneal evaluation, which is part of the FAST examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) examination primarily evaluates for free fluid in the pericardium and key dependent areas of the peritoneum, not in the pleural spaces.

questions.text: Most specific sign of Portal Hypertension on Ultrasound is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D (Recanalized Umbilical Vein)

 

A recanalized umbilical vein (also known as paraumbilical vein) represents a portosystemic collateral pathway that develops specifically in response to portal hypertension. When portal pressure increases significantly, blood seeks alternative routes from the portal system to the systemic circulation. The normally closed umbilical vein can reopen (recanalize) to establish this collateral pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enlarged Portal Vein Diameter > 13mm - While portal vein dilatation can occur in portal hypertension, it is not the most specific sign. Portal vein diameter can be influenced by multiple factors including body habitus, phase of respiration, and positioning. Additionally, the portal vein may not always enlarge despite significant portal hypertension.

 

Option B. Splenomegaly - Splenomegaly is commonly seen in portal hypertension but lacks specificity since it can result from numerous other conditions including hematologic disorders, infections, and inflammatory conditions that are unrelated to portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Ascites - While ascites is a complication of portal hypertension, it is not specific to this condition. Ascites can develop from multiple other causes including heart failure, hypoalbuminemia, nephrotic syndrome, and peritoneal malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recanalized umbilical vein is the most specific sonographic sign of portal hypertension as it represents a direct pathophysiological response to increased portal pressure, unlike other findings that can result from multiple etiologies.

questions.text: Sylvian Point is related to: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D (Lateral Cerebral Sulcus)

 

Explanation: 

 

The Sylvian Point is anatomically related to the lateral cerebral sulcus, also known as the Sylvian fissure. This important anatomical structure is bilaterally symmetric, contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and serves as the boundary that separates the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes. The Sylvian point specifically refers to a landmark point on this sulcus, which is a critical reference point in neuroanatomy and neuroimaging.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Central Sulcus - The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe and contains the motor and sensory cortices. It has no direct relationship with the Sylvian point, which is associated with the lateral cerebral sulcus.

 

Option B. Calcarian Sulcus - The calcarine sulcus is located in the medial aspect of the occipital lobe and contains the primary visual cortex. It is not related to the Sylvian point or the lateral sulcus anatomy.

 

Option C. Petro-occipital Sulcus - This sulcus is located at the junction of the petrous portion of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. It has no relationship with the Sylvian point, which is a cortical landmark.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sylvian point is related to the lateral cerebral sulcus (Sylvian fissure), which is an important bilateral CSF-containing space that separates the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes and serves as a critical landmark in neuroanatomy and neuroradiology.

questions.text: Arrow-headed fingers on X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (Acromegaly)

 

Explanation: 

 

Acromegaly is characterized by "spade phalanx" appearance of the fingers on X-ray, which presents as an arrow-headed appearance. This condition results from growth hormone (GH) overproduction in adults, with pituitary adenoma being the most common cause. The excessive GH leads to bony overgrowth and soft tissue enlargement, particularly affecting the hands and creating the distinctive spade-shaped appearance of the terminal phalanges.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperparathyroidism - Hyperparathyroidism causes subperiosteal bone resorption, particularly on the radial side of the middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers, as well as bone demineralization. The cortex appears "shaggy" with irregular margins, not arrow-headed.

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism - Hyperthyroidism is not associated with characteristic bone changes in the fingers resembling arrow-headed appearance. While thyroid disorders may affect bone metabolism, they do not cause the specific radiographic finding described in the question.

 

Option D. Hyperprolactinemia - Hyperprolactinemia is not associated with any specific bone changes in the fingers. Its clinical manifestations include galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility, without the skeletal manifestations like arrow-headed fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acromegaly causes distinctive hand changes including spade-shaped phalanges (arrow-headed fingers) on X-ray, along with other radiographic findings including increased heel pad thickness, prognathism, expanded sinuses, and calvarial thickening.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman undergoes screening mammography. The figure suggests a likely diagnosis of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B (Involuting Fibroadenoma)

 

Explanation: 

 

The mammogram shows coarse, popcorn-like calcifications within a well-circumscribed mass. This characteristic "popcorn" pattern of calcification is the classic radiographic appearance of an involuting fibroadenoma. These benign breast tumors typically develop in younger women and often undergo calcification during the involution process as women age, particularly after menopause.

 

Visual Support: The image demonstrates the typical popcorn calcification pattern within a well-defined mass - the hallmark radiographic appearance of an involuting fibroadenoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intraductal Carcinoma Breast - Incorrect because DCIS typically presents with fine, linear, branching or pleomorphic microcalcifications in a segmental or ductal distribution, not the coarse popcorn-like calcifications seen here.

 

Option C. Fibroadenosis - Incorrect as fibroadenosis (fibrocystic changes) typically shows multiple small cysts and areas of increased density without the characteristic popcorn calcifications visible in this image.

 

Option D. Fat Necrosis - Incorrect because fat necrosis typically appears as an oil cyst with a thin calcified rim, or as spiculated masses with architectural distortion. It lacks the typical popcorn calcification pattern seen in this mammogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarse "popcorn" calcifications within a well-circumscribed mass on mammography are pathognomonic for an involuting fibroadenoma, representing the degenerative calcification of a previously non-calcified fibroadenoma.

questions.text: An inguinal hernia with acute appendicitis occurring in the sac is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Amyand’s Hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically defined as an inguinal hernia where the content is the appendix. When the appendix becomes inflamed within the hernia sac, it represents a case of acute appendicitis occurring within an Amyand's hernia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Richter's Hernia: This occurs when only part of the bowel wall circumference is the content of the hernia. It typically doesn't present with intestinal obstruction but can directly progress to strangulation.
  • Option B. Littre's Hernia: This is defined as a hernia where the content is Meckel's diverticulum, not the appendix.
  • Option D. Maydl's Hernia: This refers to a double loop of intestine within the hernia sac.

 

Named Hernias at a glance:

  1. Omentocele - Content is omentum
  2. Enterocele - Content is intestine
  3. Richter's - Part of bowel wall circumference is in the sac
  4. Littre's - Content is Meckel's diverticulum
  5. Maydl's - Double loop of intestine
  6. Amyand's - Content is appendix
  7. Sliding hernia - Organs like cecum (right) or sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and form a part of the wall of the sac

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Amyand's hernia is specifically an inguinal hernia containing the appendix, regardless of whether the appendix is inflamed or normal.

questions.text: All of the following contribute to the circle of death, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Femoral artery

 

Explanation:

 

The "circle of death" refers to the vascular anastomotic ring formed around the femoral ring, which is critical during femoral hernia and laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery. This dangerous vascular circle is formed by the obturator artery, aberrant obturator artery (when present), and inferior epigastric artery. The femoral artery does not contribute to this vascular circle - it runs lateral to the femoral vein and outside the femoral ring.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Obturator artery: This vessel normally originates from the internal iliac artery and contributes to the vascular anastomosis around the femoral ring.
  • Option B. Aberrant Obturator artery: When present, this anomalous vessel arises from the inferior epigastric artery (instead of from the internal iliac) and courses around the femoral ring to reach the obturator foramen, creating a significant surgical risk.
  • Option C. Inferior Epigastric artery: This vessel runs along the medial border of the deep inguinal ring and can anastomose with the obturator artery, forming part of the "circle of death."

 

Femoral region anatomy relevant to hernias: The femoral ring has rigid boundaries including the inguinal ligament superiorly, femoral vein laterally, pubic arc (pecten pubis) inferiorly, and lacunar ligament medially. The contents of the femoral canal include fat and the lymph node of Cloquet.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During femoral hernia repair, particularly when making an incision in the lacunar ligament to relieve strangulation, surgeons must be extremely cautious of the "circle of death" formed by the obturator and inferior epigastric vessels - not the femoral artery.

choices.text: Triangle of death and circle of death
Triangle of doom and circle of death
Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally
Triangle of doom laterally and triangle of pain medially

questions.text: The Trapezoid of Disaster includes: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally

 

Explanation:

 

During laparoscopic hernia repair, the surgeon must navigate important anatomical landmarks in the inguinal region. The "Trapezoid of Disaster" contains two important triangles that require careful attention during mesh placement. The Triangle of Doom is bounded medially by the vas deferens and laterally by the testicular vessels, containing the external iliac vessels and genital branch of genitofemoral nerve. The Triangle of Pain is located lateral to this, bounded medially by testicular vessels and laterally by the iliopubic tract, containing the femoral nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, and lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: "Triangle of death" is anatomically known as the triangle of “doom”.
  • Option B: "Triangle of doom and circle of death" do not form a trapezoid of disaster.
  • Option D: This reverses the correct orientation. The Triangle of Doom is medial and the Triangle of Pain is lateral, not the opposite.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Triangle of Doom contains vital vascular structures (external iliac vessels) while the Triangle of Pain contains important nerves (femoral nerve, cutaneous nerves). Accurate identification of these anatomical landmarks is crucial to prevent iatrogenic injury during laparoscopic hernia repair.

questions.text: The four-layer suture repair of an inguinal hernia with double breasting of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Shouldice operation

 

Explanation:

 

The Shouldice operation is specifically characterized as a four-layer herniorrhaphy technique that involves double breasting of the conjoint tendon, inguinal ligament, and the two halves of the fascia transversalis to create a reinforced posterior wall repair. This multi-layered approach creates a strong repair using local tissues without mesh.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Lichtenstein operation: This is a tension-free hernioplasty that uses a polypropylene mesh placed on top of the posterior wall (onlay repair). It does not involve double breasting of local tissues or a four-layer repair.
  • Option C. Stoppa operation: This is a preperitoneal mesh repair technique primarily used for complex or recurrent hernias. It involves placing a large mesh in the preperitoneal space, not a four-layer tissue repair.
  • Option D. Bassini repair: While this is also a herniorrhaphy technique, it involves suturing the conjoint tendon to the inguinal ligament using interrupted sutures. It does not include the four-layer double breasting technique that defines the Shouldice repair.

 

Comparison of hernia repair techniques:

  • Herniorrhaphy: Strengthening of the posterior wall using locally available tissue 
    • Bassini: Simple suturing of conjoint tendon to inguinal ligament
    • Shouldice: Double-breasting with 4-layer posterior wall repair
    • Desarda: Uses a strip of external oblique aponeurosis
  • Hernioplasty: Use of prosthetic material (mesh) 
    • Lichtenstein: Onlay mesh repair

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Shouldice repair is distinguished by its meticulous four-layer closure technique with double-breasting of the posterior wall tissues, creating a strong anatomical repair without the use of prosthetic material.

questions.text: The most common site of acute limb ischemia from an embolic event is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Femoral Bifurcation

 

Explanation:

 

The femoral bifurcation is the most common site of acute limb ischemia from embolic events. Emboli typically originate from cardiac sources such as left atrial thrombus in atrial fibrillation or mural thrombus following myocardial infarction. These emboli travel through the arterial system until they lodge at points where vessels narrow significantly, with the femoral bifurcation being a prime location for emboli to become trapped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorto-iliac Bifurcation: While emboli at this location cause dramatic symptoms affecting both lower limbs simultaneously, they are less common than femoral emboli. Aortic bifurcation emboli typically cause bilateral symptoms with severe ischemia.

 

Option C. Popliteal Trifurcation: This is a more distal site where smaller emboli might lodge. While popliteal emboli do occur, they are less frequent than femoral emboli in acute limb ischemia presentations.

 

Option D. Brachial Artery: Upper extremity emboli are significantly less common than lower extremity emboli. The anatomical pathway from common cardiac sources naturally directs most emboli toward the lower limbs rather than the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Embolic occlusions most frequently occur at the femoral bifurcation, presenting as unilateral acute limb ischemia with the classic signs: pain, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis.

choices.text: Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli
Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli
Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli

questions.text: Where is the most common site for a venous ulcer to develop? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Medial aspect of the ankle around the malleoli 

 

Explanation:

 

Venous ulcers characteristically develop in the skin of the gaiter region, the area between the muscles of the calf and the ankle. The majority of ulcers develop on the medial side of the calf below the malleoli. This is the region where many of the Cockett perforators join the posterior tibial vein to the posterior arch vein (superficial vein). The chronic venous hypertension in this area leads to tissue damage and eventually ulceration when exposed to high venous and capillary pressures chronically.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Lateral aspect of the ankle below the malleoli: While ulcers associated with short saphenous vein incompetence may develop on the lateral side of the leg, they are less common than medial ulcers.
  • Option C. Lateral aspect of the ankle above the malleoli: Venous ulcers rarely extend into the upper calf, and this location would be uncommon.
  • Option D. Medial aspect of the thigh: Venous ulcers typically occur below the malleoli in the gaiter area rather than thigh.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Venous ulcers most commonly occur on the medial aspect of the ankle below the malleoli (gaiter area) due to the presence of perforating veins and high venous pressure in this region, especially in patients with chronic venous insufficiency.

questions.text: Decubitus ulcer is best classified as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Pressure ulcer

 

Explanation:

 

Decubitus ulcer is synonymous with pressure ulcer. These terms describe tissue necrosis with ulceration resulting from prolonged pressure that exceeds capillary occlusion pressure (over 30mmHg), leading to tissue anoxia and breakdown. They occur in areas where bony prominences create sustained pressure against soft tissues, particularly in bedridden or immobile patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous ulcer - Venous ulcers have distinct characteristics, typically appearing above the medial malleolus in the "Gaiter's area." They present as shallow ulcers associated with other signs of venous insufficiency such as hyperpigmentation, dermatitis, and varicosities. Unlike decubitus ulcers, they result from venous hypertension rather than direct pressure.

 

Option B. Arterial ulcer - Arterial (ischemic) ulcers occur at distal locations like toes and dorsum of foot. They are characteristically deep, severely painful, and associated with signs of peripheral vascular disease including brittle nails, sparse hair, and intermittent claudication. They stem from inadequate arterial perfusion rather than external pressure.

 

Option C. Neuropathic ulcer - Neuropathic ulcers typically form on weight-bearing areas of the foot with characteristic "punched out" edges and surrounding callosity. They develop due to sensory, motor, and autonomic neuropathy (commonly in diabetic patients) rather than from external pressure. The painless nature of these ulcers distinguishes them from decubitus ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pressure sores (decubitus ulcers) result from sustained pressure exceeding tissue perfusion pressure, causing ischemia and necrosis predominantly at bony prominences like the ischium, greater trochanter, and sacrum in immobile patients.

questions.text: Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. In the proximal calf

 

Explanation:

 

Boyd's perforator vein is most frequently located in the proximal calf region. It is one of the important named perforator veins that forms a direct communication between the superficial and deep venous systems. Specifically, Boyd's perforator connects the great saphenous vein to the deep veins (posterior tibial vein) at the level of the proximal calf. This perforator is clinically significant in patients with chronic venous insufficiency as incompetence in this perforator can contribute to varicose veins and venous hypertension.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. In the proximal thigh: This location is typically associated with Hunterian perforators, not Boyd's.
  • Option B. In the distal thigh: Dodd’s perforators are typically described in this location.
  • Option D. In the distal calf: This location is associated with Cockett's perforators (ankle perforators), which connect the posterior arch vein with the posterior tibial vein.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Boyd's perforator is located in the proximal calf, serving as an important communication between the great saphenous vein and deep posterior tibial vein. Its incompetence plays a significant role in the development of venous hypertension and varicose veins.

questions.text: Which of the following positions of the appendix is likely to present with suprapubic pain in a patient with acute appendicitis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Subcaecal

 

Explanation:

 

The subcaecal position is most likely to cause suprapubic pain among the given options. When the appendix is positioned below the cecum, it can extend inferiorly toward the pelvic brim. Inflammation in this position may spread downward, causing irritation to pelvic structures and resulting in suprapubic discomfort. This anatomical relationship explains why subcaecal appendicitis can present with symptoms similar to pelvic appendicitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pre-ileal - When the appendix is anterior to the terminal ileum, it typically presents with classic right iliac fossa pain at McBurney's point, not suprapubic discomfort.

 

Option B. Post-ileal - Post-ileal appendicitis typically causes ill-defined tenderness immediately to the right of the umbilicus and may present with features of diarrhea and retching rather than suprapubic pain.

 

Option D. Retrocecal - The most common position (74%), retrocecal appendicitis typically causes deep tenderness in the loin with possible psoas irritation, manifesting as flank or back pain rather than suprapubic discomfort.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The anatomical positioning of a subcaecal appendix allows for extension toward the pelvic region, making it most likely among the given options to cause suprapubic symptoms when inflamed.

questions.text: Which of the following provides the most accurate information for reporting the 'T stage' of esophageal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Endoscopic USG

 

Explanation:

 

Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the most accurate modality for determining the T stage (depth of tumor invasion) in esophageal carcinoma. EUS provides highly detailed images of the layers of the esophageal wall, allowing precise determination of tumor depth invasion through visualization of the mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and adventitia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT - INCORRECT CT scan is useful for identifying haematogenous metastases and is primarily used to identify distant metastasis (M stage). CT has limited axial resolution which precludes reliable assessment of both depth of wall penetration and early lymph node involvement.

 

Option B. PET - INCORRECT PET scanning is valuable for detecting distant metastatic disease not seen on CT alone, focused on identifying metabolically active tumor sites, but lacks the resolution to accurately determine depth of tumor penetration through the esophageal wall layers.

 

Option C. MRI - INCORRECT MRI doesn't expose the patient to ionizing radiation but is primarily used for metastasis detection rather than precise T-staging. It lacks the resolution needed for accurate T-staging compared to EUS.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For precise T-staging of esophageal carcinoma, endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is superior as it visualizes the multi-layered structure of the esophageal wall, allowing accurate determination of tumor depth penetration.

choices.text: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the hospital with an episode of acute cholecystitis. Symptoms are controlled with medical management. On ultrasound, there is a solitary gallstone of 1.5 cm. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list

 

Explanation:

 

For acute cholecystitis that has responded to medical management, the current best practice is early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during the same admission. The Tokyo guidelines recommend early cholecystectomy within 5-7 days for mild cases (Tokyo I). For this 45-year-old patient whose symptoms are controlled with medical management, proceeding with laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list (during the same admission) is the optimal approach, as it reduces the risk of recurrent attacks while operating when inflammation has started to resolve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation and regular follow-up - This is inappropriate for a patient who has already experienced acute cholecystitis. Once symptomatic complications occur, definitive surgical management is required to prevent recurrent attacks, which can be more severe and lead to additional complications.

 

Option B. Elective cholecystectomy after inflammation subsides - This approach represents delayed surgery scheduled weeks to months after discharge, which is now considered an outdated practice. It increases the risk of recurrent episodes during the waiting period and can lead to more difficult surgery due to scarring and adhesions.

 

Option D. Urgent open cholecystectomy - Open cholecystectomy is not the first-line approach unless laparoscopic surgery is contraindicated. For mild to moderate cases that have been medically stabilized, there is no indication for urgent open surgery, as laparoscopic approach offers less postoperative pain, shorter hospital stays, and faster recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For acute cholecystitis responsive to medical management, early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during the same admission (on the next available list) is the standard of care, offering the best balance between allowing initial inflammation to subside while preventing recurrent attacks.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect finding in Mirizzi syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Hemobilia

 

Explanation:

 

Mirizzi syndrome occurs when a gallstone becomes impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder, causing inflammation and extrinsic compression of the common hepatic duct. This mechanical obstruction leads to obstructive jaundice. Hemobilia (bleeding into the biliary tract) is not a feature of Mirizzi syndrome but rather a distinct pathology typically seen after liver trauma, vascular malformations, or biliary procedures, where erosion of a blood vessel leads to bleeding into the biliary tree.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jaundice - This is a correct feature of Mirizzi syndrome. Patients present with obstructive jaundice due to the mechanical compression of the common hepatic duct, resulting in the classic triad of jaundice, pruritis, and clay-colored stools.

 

Option B. Cystic duct obstruction - This is a correct feature of Mirizzi syndrome. The pathophysiology begins with a stone becoming impacted in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck, causing obstruction and surrounding inflammation that then affects nearby structures.

 

Option C. Cholecystocholedochal fistula - This is a correct feature seen in progressive Mirizzi syndrome. The Csendes classification describes how the impacted stone can erode through the wall of the cystic duct into the common hepatic duct, creating a fistula that may involve varying degrees of the duct circumference (Types 2-4).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mirizzi syndrome involves obstructive jaundice caused by extrinsic compression of the common hepatic duct by gallstones impacted in the cystic duct, potentially leading to fistula formation, but does not involve bleeding into the biliary tree (hemobilia).

questions.text: The Ripstein procedure is done for: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Rectal prolapse

 

Explanation:

 

The Ripstein procedure is a type of abdominal rectopexy used specifically for treating full-thickness rectal prolapse. It involves placing a mesh anterior to the rectum like a sling and fixing it to the sacrum behind. This technique suspends the rectum and prevents prolapse, though it has more post-operative complications due to its sling effect compared to other rectopexy methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hirschsprung disease - This is treated with pull-through procedures (Swenson, Duhamel, or Soave) which resect the aganglionic segment and create a colo-anal anastomosis, not with rectopexy.

 

Option C. Hemorrhoids - These are treated with different procedures including banding, sclerotherapy, hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan-Morgan or Ferguson), stapled hemorrhoidopexy, or newer techniques like Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - This condition requires Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy, which involves cutting the pyloric muscle along its length while preserving the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein rectopexy uses a mesh sling placed anterior to the rectum for full-thickness rectal prolapse, but has higher post-operative constipation rates compared to other rectopexy techniques like Well's procedure.

questions.text: In which of the following transplantations is organ/body size comparison believed to be least important? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pancreas

 

Explanation:

 

Organ size matching is specifically mentioned as important for heart, lung, liver and small bowel transplantation, but not for pancreas transplantation. Allocation of organs must take into account the relative size of the donor and recipient for most organ types. While kidney transplants can be performed between adults and children without significant size concerns, the heart, lung, liver, and small bowel require more careful size matching. The pancreas doesn't appear in discussions of organs requiring strict size compatibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heart - Incorrect. Size compatibility is critically important for heart transplantation. A heart that is too large won't fit in the recipient's chest cavity, while one that's too small may not provide adequate cardiac output for the recipient's body size. Precise size matching is essential for proper cardiac function.

 

Option B. Liver - Incorrect. Size matching is crucial for liver transplantation. An adult donor liver cannot be transplanted into a child because of the size mismatch. This has led to the development of split-liver transplantation, where the liver is divided so the left lobe or left lateral segments can be used for a child and the right lobe for an adult recipient.

 

Option D. Lung - Incorrect. Lung transplantation requires careful size matching to ensure proper fit within the chest cavity. Lungs that are too large cannot physically fit in the recipient's thoracic space, while lungs that are too small may not provide adequate respiratory function for the recipient.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While size matching is critical for heart, lung, liver, and small bowel transplantation, it is comparatively less critical for pancreatic transplantation among the given options.

choices.text: Rewarming with immersion in warm water
Rewarming with encouragement to walk on warm surfaces

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment for frostbite on the lower extremities? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Rewarming with immersion in warm water

 

Explanation:

 

The initial treatment for frostbite is rapid rewarming in a bath at 42°C. This method provides controlled rewarming at a specific temperature to prevent further tissue damage. Rapid rewarming is essential, but it must be done properly in a warm water bath to ensure even heat distribution and temperature control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rewarming with friction and/or massage - This is actively dangerous for frostbite. Frostbite causes delayed microvascular damage similar to cardiac reperfusion injury. Friction or massage would worsen this damage by potentially breaking fragile tissues that are already compromised.

 

Option B. Rewarming with blankets - This method is too slow and uncontrolled. Frostbite requires rapid rewarming at a specific temperature (42°C), which blankets cannot provide consistently.

 

Option D. Rewarming with encouragement of walking on warm surfaces - This would apply pressure to already damaged tissue. The level of damage is difficult to assess, and management is conservative until there is absolute demarcation of the level of injury. Walking would risk further injury before proper assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frostbite requires controlled, rapid rewarming in a water bath at a specific temperature (42°C) without applying pressure or friction to the damaged tissues, followed by conservative management until tissue demarcation is clear.

questions.text: All of the following criteria are used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. ROME Criteria

 

Explanation:

 

ROME Criteria is not used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis. The validated scoring systems for severity assessment in acute pancreatitis include Ranson, Glasgow (Imrie's), APACHE, SAPS, SOFA, MODS, and modified Marshall scoring systems. Additional tools include the BISAP Score and CT Severity Index. ROME Criteria is used for functional gastrointestinal disorders, not for assessing pancreatitis severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ranson Criteria - This is a valid severity assessment tool for acute pancreatitis. It uses 11 parameters (5 at admission and 6 at 48 hours), with a score ≥3 indicating severe pancreatitis. Parameters include age, white blood cell count, blood glucose, LDH, AST at admission and hematocrit fall, BUN rise, arterial oxygen, calcium levels, base deficit, and fluid sequestration at 48 hours.

 

Option B. APACHE-II - This is a valid severity assessment tool used in intensive care settings for pancreatitis patients. It assesses physiological parameters and can be calculated at any time during hospitalization, making it more dynamic than Ranson criteria.

 

Option C. Imrie's Criteria - Also known as the Glasgow scoring system, this is a valid severity assessment tool similar to Ranson but with fewer parameters. It also uses a cutoff of ≥3 to indicate severe pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Severity stratification in acute pancreatitis should be performed using validated scoring systems (Ranson, Glasgow/Imrie, APACHE, BISAP, CT Severity Index) to identify patients at risk for persistent organ failure and complications.

questions.text: The Alvarado score is used for the diagnosis of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Acute Appendicitis

 

Explanation:

 

The Alvarado score (also known as the MANTRELS score) is a clinical scoring system specifically developed to diagnose acute appendicitis. It uses 8 criteria with a total possible score of 10 points. The components of the score include: Migratory RIF pain (1 point), Anorexia (1 point), Nausea/vomiting (1 point), Tenderness in RIF (2 points), Rebound tenderness (1 point), Elevated temperature (1 point), Leukocytosis (2 points), and Shift to left of neutrophils (1 point). A score of 7 or more is strongly predictive of acute appendicitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatitis - Pancreatitis diagnosis relies on clinical features, elevated serum amylase/lipase levels, and imaging. The Ranson criteria or APACHE II scores are used for severity assessment, not the Alvarado score.

 

Option B. Cholecystitis - Diagnosis relies on Murphy's sign, ultrasonography findings, and laboratory values. The Tokyo Guidelines provide diagnostic criteria for acute cholecystitis, not the Alvarado score.

 

Option C. Turner's Syndrome - This is a genetic condition diagnosed by karyotype analysis showing 45, XO. Clinical scoring systems are not used for the diagnosis of genetic conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Alvarado score is a validated clinical decision tool specifically designed for diagnosing acute appendicitis, with a score ≥7 having high diagnostic value, helping to reduce negative appendectomy rates.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities are likely to be associated with imperforate anus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Esophageal atresia

 

Explanation:

 

Anorectal malformations (including imperforate anus) commonly occur with other congenital anomalies. The sacrum and genitourinary tract are often abnormal in these patients. Esophageal atresia frequently coexists with imperforate anus as part of the VACTERL association, where the "A" stands for anorectal malformations and the "E" for esophageal atresia. This embryological connection makes esophageal atresia the most likely associated abnormality from the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A (Pulmonary airway malformation): Not typically associated with anorectal malformations. While respiratory abnormalities can occur in complex syndromes, this specific malformation is not a common association.
  • Option B (Duodenal atresia): Though duodenal atresia is a significant congenital malformation, it has stronger associations with Down syndrome rather than with imperforate anus.
  • Option D (Hydrocephalus): Not commonly associated with imperforate anus. Neurological conditions are not typical components of the syndromes that include anorectal malformations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Imperforate anus frequently occurs with other congenital anomalies, particularly those affecting the sacrum, genitourinary tract, and other components of the VACTERL association, which includes esophageal atresia.

questions.text: Which of the following bariatric procedures has been shown to offer maximum weight reduction? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS)

 

Explanation:

 

BPD/DS produces the greatest weight loss among all bariatric procedures. It achieves maximum weight loss (70-80% excess weight loss at 3 years) compared to other procedures. This is primarily due to its powerful malabsorptive mechanism combined with the restrictive component of sleeve gastrectomy. The procedure creates a significant reduction in the absorptive surface of the intestine through the creation of a common channel of 75-125 cm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding - Gastric banding produces the least weight loss among the standard procedures, with only 40-50% Excess weight loss (EWL) at 3 years. It functions purely as a restrictive procedure without malabsorption, depending on reduced food intake rather than reduced absorption.

 

Option C. Roux-en-Y Gastric bypass - While effective, gastric bypass produces 50-60% Excess weight loss (EWL) at 3 years. This is substantially less than BPD/DS, though it has fewer nutritional complications and is more commonly performed.

 

Option D. Sleeve gastrectomy - Similar to gastric bypass, sleeve gastrectomy produces 50-60% EWL at 3 years. It works primarily through restriction and hormonal changes rather than malabsorption.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While BPD/DS produces the maximum weight loss (70-80% EWL), it also carries the highest risk of malnutrition and requires lifelong monitoring and supplementation. The choice of bariatric procedure should balance weight loss goals with nutritional risks and patient compliance factors.

questions.text: Fatty liver is caused by the accumulation of which substance? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A. Triglycerides

 

Explanation: 

 

Fatty liver (steatosis) is characterized by the abnormal accumulation of triglycerides within parenchymal cells, particularly in the liver. This occurs due to a disruption in normal lipid metabolism where the rate of triglyceride acquisition exceeds the rate of triglyceride removal. This accumulation can result from excessive intake of fats, defective transport mechanisms, or metabolic disorders affecting fat processing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) - While LDL carries cholesterol to tissues, it is not the primary substance that accumulates in fatty liver. LDL abnormalities are more commonly associated with atherosclerosis rather than hepatic steatosis.

 

Option C. Lipoprotein - This is a general class of biochemical compounds that facilitate lipid transport in the bloodstream. While lipoproteins are involved in fat metabolism, the specific accumulation in fatty liver is of triglycerides, not lipoproteins themselves.

 

Option D. VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein) - Although impaired VLDL secretion can contribute to fatty liver by preventing triglyceride export from hepatocytes, the substance that actually accumulates is triglycerides, not VLDL itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fatty liver (steatosis) results from the accumulation of triglycerides within hepatocytes, which may occur due to excessive intake, impaired export, or defective metabolism of fats.

questions.text: Which of the following acute phase reactants is known to induce rouleaux formation in erythrocytes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Fibrinogen

 

Explanation: 

 

Fibrinogen is an acute phase reactant that binds to red blood cells and causes them to form stacks called rouleaux. This property of fibrinogen is the basis for measuring the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), which is a simple test for detecting inflammatory responses. During inflammation, fibrinogen levels increase in the blood, enhancing rouleaux formation and consequently increasing the ESR. This occurs because the stacked red cells sediment more rapidly at unit gravity than individual red cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C-reactive protein (CRP) - While CRP is an important acute phase protein that can bind to microbial cell walls and act as an opsonin, it does not directly cause rouleaux formation. CRP is involved in complement activation and enhancing phagocytosis.

 

Option C. Serum Amyloid Associated (SAA) protein - SAA is another acute phase protein produced during inflammation, but it primarily binds to chromatin and microbial cell walls. It doesn't induce rouleaux formation. Prolonged production of SAA can lead to secondary amyloidosis.

 

Option D. IL-1 - This is a cytokine rather than an acute phase reactant. IL-1 is produced by activated macrophages and stimulates the liver to produce acute phase proteins, but it doesn't directly cause rouleaux formation.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fibrinogen is the acute phase reactant responsible for rouleaux formation in erythrocytes, which is the physiological basis for the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) test used to detect inflammatory conditions.

questions.text: The mosaic pattern of cement lines is characteristically seen in which of the following bone conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Paget's disease of bone

 

Explanation: 

 

Paget's disease of bone is characterized by excessive and abnormal bone remodeling, with initial osteoclastic bone resorption followed by excessive osteoblastic bone formation. This chaotic remodeling process creates a distinctive microscopic appearance known as a "mosaic pattern" of cement lines that resembles a jigsaw puzzle. These cement lines represent the reversal lines between areas of bone resorption and subsequent formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism - While hyperthyroidism can increase bone turnover and lead to osteoporosis, it does not produce the characteristic mosaic pattern of cement lines seen in Paget's disease. Hyperthyroidism causes generalized bone loss rather than the focal abnormal remodeling seen in Paget's disease.

 

Option C. Renal osteodystrophy - This is a complex bone disorder associated with chronic kidney disease. It can cause various bone abnormalities including secondary hyperparathyroidism, osteomalacia, and adynamic bone disease, but the characteristic mosaic pattern of cement lines is not a feature.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia - This condition is characterized by inadequate mineralization of bone matrix (osteoid) due to vitamin D deficiency or abnormal vitamin D metabolism. It shows increased unmineralized osteoid and inadequate calcification, not a mosaic pattern of cement lines.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The mosaic pattern of cement lines is a pathognomonic histological feature of Paget's disease of bone, reflecting the chaotic and accelerated bone remodeling process that characterizes this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is primarily found in the extracellular matrix?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Collagen

 

Explanation: 

 

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the extracellular matrix (ECM) and forms the primary structural component. It provides tensile strength and functions as a scaffolding for cells and tissues. Collagens are composed of three separate polypeptide chains braided into a triple helix structure. There are about 30 different collagen types identified, with types I, II, III, and V forming linear fibrils that comprise a major proportion of connective tissue in bone, tendon, cartilage, blood vessels, and skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrin - While fibrin can be found in the ECM during wound healing, it is not primarily an ECM component. Fibrin is formed from fibrinogen during blood clotting and is a key component of blood clots rather than normal ECM.

 

Option C. Fibrillin - Though fibrillin is indeed an ECM component, it is not as abundant as collagen. Fibrillin forms microfibrils that provide structural support for elastic fibers and is associated with elastin in tissues requiring elasticity, like blood vessels and skin.

 

Option D. Proteoglycan - Proteoglycans are important components of the ECM, consisting of a core protein with attached glycosaminoglycan chains. While they are significant ECM constituents that contribute to compressibility and lubrication, they are not as abundant as collagen, which makes up approximately 30% of the total protein in the human body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Collagen is the most abundant and primary structural protein in the extracellular matrix, providing essential tensile strength and scaffolding for tissues throughout the body.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is primarily found in tendons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Collagen

 

Explanation: 

 

Tendons are dense, fibrous connective tissues that connect muscle to bone and transmit force during movement. Collagen, specifically fibrillar type I collagen, is the predominant component of tendons, making up approximately 60-85% of the dry weight of the tendon. These collagen fibers are arranged in parallel bundles that provide the high tensile strength necessary for tendons to withstand and transmit the mechanical forces generated during muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrin - Fibrin is not a normal component of tendons. It is a fibrous protein formed from fibrinogen during blood clotting and is involved in wound healing rather than tendon structure.

 

Option C. Fibrillin - While fibrillin is an important extracellular matrix glycoprotein associated with elastin in elastic fibers, it is primarily found in tissues requiring elasticity such as blood vessels, skin, and ligaments. It is not a major component of tendons, which require tensile strength rather than elasticity.

 

Option D. Proteoglycans - Although proteoglycans are present in tendons, they make up a much smaller proportion compared to collagen. They contribute to the viscoelastic properties of tendons and help maintain tissue hydration, but they are not the primary structural component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tendons are composed primarily of type I collagen arranged in parallel bundles, providing the high tensile strength required for their function of transmitting force from muscle to bone.

questions.text: Onion skin appearance of the blood vessel in the spleen is observed in: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. SLE

 

Explanation: 

 

Onion skin appearance in the spleen is a characteristic finding in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). This pattern refers to concentric intimal and smooth muscle cell hyperplasia around central penicillary arteries in the spleen, giving them an "onion skin" appearance. This vascular change is one of several splenic abnormalities that can be found in SLE patients, along with splenomegaly, capsular thickening, and follicular hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ITP (Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura) - In ITP, the spleen shows increased megakaryocytes and may have increased phagocytic activity, but does not typically show onion skin vascular changes. ITP is characterized by immune-mediated destruction of platelets, often involving splenic macrophages.

 

Option B. Thalassemia - The spleen in thalassemia may show extramedullary hematopoiesis and hemosiderosis due to increased red cell destruction, but not onion skin change. Splenomegaly in thalassemia is related to sequestration and destruction of abnormal erythrocytes.

 

Option D. Scleroderma - While scleroderma can cause vascular changes in many organs, the characteristic onion skin appearance of splenic vessels is not a typical finding. Scleroderma primarily affects the skin and small vessels of various organs with fibrosis and collagenization.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The "onion skin" appearance of splenic blood vessels, characterized by concentric intimal and smooth muscle cell hyperplasia of central penicillary arteries, is a distinctive histopathological finding in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus.

questions.text: The appearance of the spleen with amyloid deposits within the white pulp is known as: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A. Sago Spleen

 

Explanation: 

 

When amyloid deposits are localized primarily within the splenic follicles (white pulp), it produces a characteristic appearance called "sago spleen." The name derives from the visual resemblance of the affected follicles to tapioca-like granules on gross inspection. This pattern represents one of two main patterns of amyloid deposition in the spleen. In sago spleen, the deposits are largely limited to the splenic follicles, which correspond to the white pulp of the spleen where B lymphocytes are concentrated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lardaceous Spleen - This is the other pattern of splenic amyloidosis, but it involves the walls of the splenic sinuses and connective tissue framework in the red pulp rather than the follicles. Fusion of these deposits creates large, map like areas of amyloidosis. The term "lardaceous" refers to its waxy, fat-like appearance resembling lard.

 

Option C. Nutmeg Spleen - This is not a pattern of amyloidosis. Nutmeg spleen refers to the appearance of the spleen in chronic passive congestion, typically seen in right-sided heart failure. The alternating pattern of congested red pulp and pale areas creates an appearance resembling a nutmeg.

 

Option D. Mucin Spleen - This is not a recognized pattern of splenic pathology. Mucin is a glycoprotein produced by epithelial tissues, not associated with specific splenic pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloidosis of the spleen presents in two distinct patterns: sago spleen (affecting white pulp/follicles with tapioca-like granules) and lardaceous spleen (affecting red pulp with map like areas of deposition), representing different distribution patterns of amyloid deposition within the organ.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the genetics of G6PD Deficiency is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Contradicts the Lyon Hypothesis.

 

Explanation: 

 

G6PD deficiency follows an X-linked inheritance pattern, with the gene located on the X chromosome. The Lyon hypothesis (X-chromosome inactivation) actually explains why some heterozygous females can be affected by G6PD deficiency, though typically less severely than males. During early embryonic development, one X chromosome in each female cell is randomly inactivated. If a higher proportion of cells have the normal X chromosome inactivated, these females can express symptoms of G6PD deficiency. This variable inactivation creates a mosaic pattern in heterozygous females rather than contradicting the hypothesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-linked inheritance - This is correct. G6PD deficiency is indeed an X-linked recessive disorder, which places males at much higher risk for symptomatic disease.

 

Option B. More severe in males - This is correct. Since males have only one X chromosome, if they inherit the defective G6PD gene, they will express the disorder fully, making the condition typically more severe in males.

 

Option D. May affect heterozygous females - This is correct. Heterozygous females can be affected due to random X-inactivation, where some cells express the defective G6PD gene, potentially leading to clinical manifestations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that follows the principles of the Lyon hypothesis, with males being more severely affected, while heterozygous females may show variable expression depending on X-chromosome inactivation patterns.

choices.text: Acquired anomaly may be seen in myelodysplasia
Associated with normal survival of neutrophils

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pelger-Huet Anomaly is false? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Associated with large platelets.

 

Pelger-Huet anomaly is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by hypo segmented neutrophils with coarse, clumped chromatin, typically appearing as bilobed ("pince-nez" or "spectacle-shaped") nuclei. It is not associated with large platelets. The anomaly affects granulocyte nuclear segmentation but does not impact platelet morphology.
