Large platelets are more commonly associated with other conditions such as immune thrombocytopenia, Bernard-Soulier syndrome, or May-Hegglin anomaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inherited trait with hypo segmented neutrophils - This is a true statement. The hereditary form of Pelger-Huet anomaly is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by hypo segmented neutrophils with coarse clumped chromatin and normal neutrophil function.

 

Option B. Acquired anomaly may be seen in myelodysplasia - This is a true statement. Pseudo-Pelger-Huet cells are commonly seen in myelodysplastic syndromes. These cells are one of the characteristic findings of dysgranulopoiesis in MDS.

 

Option C. Associated with normal survival of neutrophils - This is a true statement. Despite the nuclear abnormality, neutrophil function and survival remain normal in hereditary Pelger-Huet anomaly. The condition is generally benign and does not affect the functional capabilities of neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelger-Huet anomaly affects nuclear segmentation of neutrophils but does not impact platelet morphology; the abnormal hypo segmented neutrophils retain normal function and survival time in the hereditary form of the condition.

questions.text: Pawn ball megakaryocytes are characteristic of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Myelodysplastic syndrome.

 

Explanation: 

 

Pawn ball megakaryocytes are a characteristic morphological finding in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). These abnormal megakaryocytes have separated nuclear lobes instead of the normal single multi-lobated nucleus. The presence of these distinctive megakaryocytes is part of the dysmegakaryopoiesis that occurs in MDS, along with other features like ringed sideroblasts and pseudo-Pelger-Huet neutrophils. These morphological abnormalities reflect the underlying maturation defect at the level of myeloid stem cells that characterizes MDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura - This is incorrect. In ITP, megakaryocytes are typically normal or increased in number, but they do not show the characteristic pawn ball morphology. ITP is an immune-mediated disorder characterized by antibody destruction of platelets.

 

Option C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura - This is incorrect. TTP is characterized by microthrombi formation due to abnormally large von Willebrand factor multimers. The bone marrow findings in TTP do not typically include pawn ball megakaryocytes.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol toxicity - This is incorrect. Chloramphenicol toxicity can cause bone marrow suppression and aplasia, but it is not specifically associated with pawn ball megakaryocytes. It tends to cause a general hypocellularity rather than dysplastic changes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pawn ball megakaryocytes, with their distinctive separated nuclear lobes, are a characteristic morphological finding in myelodysplastic syndromes and reflect the dysplastic changes in megakaryopoiesis that are a hallmark of this group of disorders.

questions.text: The 190 kDa BCR-ABL protein is most commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. ALL

 

Explanation: 

 

The 190 kDa BCR-ABL protein is most commonly associated with B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B-ALL). This specific form of the BCR-ABL fusion protein results from the Philadelphia chromosome t(9;22). While BCR-ABL is also found in Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), the size of the protein is different. In B-ALL, the BCR-ABL protein is usually 190 kDa in size, whereas in CML, a BCR-ABL protein of 210 kDa is typically present. The 190 kDa variant has stronger tyrosine kinase activity than the 210 kDa form and is strongly associated with a subset of B-ALL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AML - This is incorrect. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is not typically associated with the BCR-ABL fusion protein. AML is characterized by different genetic abnormalities including t(8;21), inv(16), and t(15;17).

 

Option C. CML - This is incorrect. While CML is associated with the BCR-ABL fusion protein, it is typically the 210 kDa form rather than the 190 kDa form. The 210 kDa BCR-ABL protein results from a different breakpoint in the BCR gene.

 

Option D. CLL - This is incorrect. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is not associated with BCR-ABL fusion proteins. CLL is characterized by other genetic abnormalities including deletions of 13q14.3, 11q, and 17p, and trisomy 12q.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The 190 kDa BCR-ABL fusion protein is specifically associated with Philadelphia chromosome-positive B-ALL, while the 210 kDa variant is found in CML; this difference in molecular weight reflects different breakpoints in the BCR gene and results in proteins with different tyrosine kinase activities.

questions.text: Backwash Ileitis is seen in: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Ulcerative Colitis

 

Explanation: 

 

Backwash ileitis is a feature of ulcerative colitis where mild mucosal inflammation of the distal ileum occurs. This happens in severe cases of ulcerative colitis, particularly when there is extensive colonic involvement (pancolitis). Unlike Crohn's disease, which can primarily involve the ileum with transmural inflammation, backwash ileitis in ulcerative colitis is superficial, represents an extension of the inflammatory process, and is limited to the mucosa and submucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Crohn's Disease - While Crohn's disease commonly affects the terminal ileum, the pattern of involvement is distinctly different from backwash ileitis. Crohn's disease features transmural inflammation, skip lesions, granulomas, and fibrosis. It primarily affects the ileum rather than being secondary to colonic inflammation.

 

Option C. Colonic Carcinoma - Colorectal carcinoma does not cause backwash ileitis. Carcinomas are malignant neoplasms that may invade locally but do not typically cause inflammatory changes in the distal ileum. They remain localized to their site of origin unless they metastasize.

 

Option D. Ileal Polyp - Ileal polyps are discrete lesions that occur within the ileum and do not cause the diffuse inflammatory process characteristic of backwash ileitis. Polyps may be inflammatory, hamartomatous, or neoplastic, but they do not cause inflammation extending from the colon into the ileum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Backwash ileitis refers specifically to the mild inflammatory involvement of the distal ileum in severe ulcerative colitis (particularly pancolitis) and is a distinctive feature that helps differentiate ulcerative colitis from other inflammatory bowel conditions.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of varenicline? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Partial agonist at acetylcholine receptors

 

Explanation:

 

Varenicline acts as a partial agonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, specifically the α4β2 subtype. It binds to these receptors and produces a weaker effect than nicotine while simultaneously blocking nicotine from binding, thereby reducing the reward associated with smoking. This dual action helps decrease craving for nicotine and makes varenicline the most effective anti-smoking medication available.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Antagonist at serotonergic receptors: Varenicline does not act on serotonergic receptors. This mechanism is associated with certain antidepressants and anxiolytics.
  • Option B. Blocks dopamine receptors: Dopamine receptor blockade is the mechanism of action for antipsychotic drugs, not varenicline. While smoking does increase dopamine release, varenicline works directly on nicotinic receptors.
  • Option C. Inverse agonist at acetylcholine receptors: Varenicline is not an inverse agonist. Inverse agonists produce effects opposite to agonists by reducing receptor activity below baseline. Varenicline partially activates the receptor while blocking full activation by nicotine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is the most effective anti-smoking drug, working through partial agonism at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors to reduce craving while simultaneously blocking the rewarding effects of nicotine from cigarettes.

questions.text: Which region of the liver is typically affected initially by passive venous congestion? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Centrilobular region

 

Passive congestion of the liver results from right-sided cardiac decompensation. This leads to blood backing up in the venous system, causing congestion of the centrilobular sinusoids. The centrilobular region (zone 3) is most susceptible because it's farthest from the arterial blood supply. With time, centrilobular hepatocytes become atrophic, resulting in markedly attenuated liver cell plates. Left-sided cardiac failure or shock may lead to hepatic hypoperfusion and hypoxia, causing ischemic coagulative necrosis of hepatocytes in the central region of the lobule (centrilobular necrosis).

 

Severe passive congestion with hepatic hypoperfusion can lead to centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, giving the liver a mottled appearance known as "nutmeg liver" due to its resemblance to the cut surface of a nutmeg. This shows a sharp demarcation between viable periportal and necrotic or atrophic pericentral regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midzone region - The middle zone (zone 2) is affected in passive congestion only after the centrilobular region has been compromised. It is not the primary area affected.

 

Option B. Periportal region - The periportal region (zone 1) is closest to the arterial and portal venous blood supply, so it's the last to be affected by passive congestion. It typically remains viable even when the centrilobular region shows necrosis.

 

Option D. Parahepatic region - This is not a standard term used in hepatic lobular architecture. The liver is divided into centrilobular, midzonal, and periportal regions based on their relationship to the terminal hepatic vein and portal tracts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Passive congestion of the liver affects the centrilobular (zone 3) region first due to its distance from the arterial blood supply, potentially leading to centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis and the characteristic "nutmeg liver" appearance in severe cases.

questions.text: Which region of the liver is most susceptible to ischemic injury? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Zone 3

 

Explanation: 

 

Zone 3 (centrilobular region) is the most susceptible to ischemic injury because it is farthest from the arterial blood supply. The liver has a unique architecture with blood flowing from the portal tracts (containing branches of the portal vein and hepatic artery) toward the central vein. This creates a gradient of oxygenation with Zone 1 (periportal) receiving the highest oxygen concentration and Zone 3 (centrilobular) receiving the lowest. During ischemic conditions such as shock or heart failure, the centrilobular hepatocytes are the first to suffer from hypoxia, leading to ischemic necrosis in this region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zone 1 - This is the periportal region closest to the incoming blood supply from both portal vein and hepatic artery. It receives the highest oxygen concentration and is therefore the most resistant to ischemic injury, being affected only in severe, prolonged ischemia.

 

Option B. Zone 2 - This is the midzonal region located between the periportal and centrilobular areas. It has intermediate vulnerability to ischemic injury, becoming affected after Zone 3 but before Zone 1.

 

Option D. Zone 4 - This is not a standard designation in liver lobular architecture. The liver is typically divided into three zones (1, 2, and 3) based on the concept of the hepatic acinus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Zone 3 (centrilobular region) is most vulnerable to ischemic injury due to its position farthest from the arterial blood supply, which makes it the first area to suffer from hypoxia during compromised circulation, manifesting as centrilobular necrosis.

questions.text: Which disorder associated with the ATP 7A gene results in low serum copper levels? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Menkes disease

 

Explanation: 

 

Menkes disease is a disorder characterized by low serum copper levels due to mutations in the ATP7A gene. This gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase that is responsible for copper absorption from the intestine and distribution to various tissues. When this gene is mutated, copper cannot be properly absorbed from the intestinal tract, leading to copper deficiency. This X-linked recessive disorder manifests with neurological deterioration, growth failure, and characteristic kinky hair (described as "steel wool" hair) due to abnormal copper-dependent cross-linking in hair proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson's syndrome - This is a benign disorder characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by mutations in the ABCC2 gene, which encodes a transport protein that moves bilirubin out of hepatocytes. It has no relation to copper metabolism.

 

Option B. Wilson disease - This is actually the opposite condition of Menkes disease. Wilson disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene (not ATP7A) and results in excessive copper accumulation in tissues, particularly the liver and brain, rather than copper deficiency.

 

Option D. Gilbert's disease - This is another benign disorder affecting bilirubin metabolism, characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. It has no connection to copper metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Menkes disease is an X-linked disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, resulting in impaired copper absorption and transport, which leads to copper deficiency manifesting as growth failure, neurological deterioration, and characteristic kinky hair.

questions.text: Which gene or protein deficiency is associated with Marfan’s Syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Fibrillin-1

 

Explanation: 

 

Marfan syndrome is caused by an inherited defect in the fibrillin-1 gene (FBN1), which maps to chromosomal locus 15q21. More than 1000 distinct causative mutations in the FBN1 gene have been found. Fibrillin is secreted by fibroblasts and is the major component of microfibrils found in the extracellular matrix. These microfibrils serve as scaffolds for the deposition of tropoelastin, an integral component of elastic fibers. The abnormal fibrillin protein acts as a dominant negative, preventing the assembly of normal microfibrils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrillin 2 - While fibrillin-2 is related to fibrillin-1 and has similar functions in the extracellular matrix, mutations in fibrillin-2 are associated with congenital contractural arachnodactyly (CCA), not Marfan syndrome.

 

Option C. Collagen - Defects in collagen are associated with other connective tissue disorders such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, not Marfan syndrome. Different variants of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are caused by mutations in different collagen genes.

 

Option D. Elastin - While elastin interacts with fibrillin in elastic fibers, defects in elastin are associated with supravalvular aortic stenosis and Williams syndrome, not Marfan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Marfan syndrome results from mutations in the FBN1 gene encoding fibrillin-1, which disrupts microfibril formation and leads to excessive TGF-β signaling, resulting in the classic manifestations of skeletal abnormalities, ocular defects, and cardiovascular complications.

questions.text: Chromosomal location of Adult Polycystic Kidney Disease I and II respectively is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Chromosome 16 and 4

 

Explanation: 

 

Autosomal dominant (adult) polycystic kidney disease is caused by mutations in genes located on different chromosomes. PKD1 gene is located on chromosome 16p and encodes the protein polycystin-1, which is responsible for 85-90% of ADPKD cases. The PKD2 gene is located on chromosome 4q and encodes polycystin-2. Both proteins are believed to function together by forming heterodimers, and mutations in either gene produce essentially the same phenotype, though patients with PKD2 mutations tend to have a slower disease progression compared to those with PKD1 mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromosome 16 and 1 - While chromosome 16 is correct for PKD1, chromosome 1 is incorrect for PKD2. There is no PKD gene on chromosome 1.

 

Option C. Chromosome 11 and 5 - These chromosomes are not associated with adult polycystic kidney disease. Chromosome 11p is associated with Wilms tumor genes (WT1, WT2) in the renal tumors section.

 

Option D. Chromosome 21 and 18 - These chromosomes are not associated with adult polycystic kidney disease. Chromosome 21 is associated with Down syndrome, which has an association with horseshoe kidney, but not ADPKD.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is caused by mutations in the PKD1 gene on chromosome 16p (accounting for 85-90% of cases) or the PKD2 gene on chromosome 4q (10-15% of cases), which encode polycystin-1 and polycystin-2 respectively—proteins that function together and localize to the primary cilia of tubular cells.

questions.text: Basket weave appearance of Glomerular Basement Membrane on Electron Microscopy is seen in: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Alport syndrome

 

Explanation: 

 

Alport syndrome is characterized by a distinctive "basket weave appearance" of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy. This morphological finding is due to a defect in the α5 chain of type IV collagen, which is the primary component of the GBM. In Alport syndrome, the basement membrane shows characteristic irregular thickening, lamellation of the lamina densa, and pronounced splitting, creating the distinctive basketweave pattern that is diagnostic for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Post Streptococcal GN - This condition typically shows subepithelial humps or deposits on electron microscopy, not basket weave appearance. These electron-dense "humps" are immune complexes nestled against the GBM, typically in subepithelial locations.

 

Option C. Polyarteritis nodosa - This is a systemic vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries, not primarily a glomerular disease. It does not show basket weave appearance of the GBM on electron microscopy.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis - This is a vasculitis affecting large and medium-sized arteries, particularly cranial branches of arteries originating from the aortic arch. It does not affect glomerular basement membranes and thus would not show basket weave appearance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The basket weave appearance on electron microscopy—characterized by alternating thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with lamellation and splitting—is a pathognomonic finding in Alport syndrome, representing the ultrastructural manifestation of the underlying genetic defect in type IV collagen.

choices.text: Atrophy of pons with preservation of midbrain
Atrophy of both pons and midbrain
Atrophy of midbrain with preservation of pons

questions.text: Progressive Supranuclear Palsy is characterized by: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Atrophy of midbrain with preservation of pons

 

Explanation: 

 

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is an atypical parkinsonian syndrome characterized by midbrain atrophy while the pons remains relatively preserved. This disorder presents with progressive truncal rigidity, disequilibrium with frequent falls, and difficulty with voluntary eye movements, particularly affecting vertical gaze. Additional common symptoms include nuchal dystonia (neck stiffness), pseudobulbar palsy, and a mild progressive dementia. The pathologic hallmark of PSP is the presence of tau-containing inclusions in neurons and glial cells in the brain stem and deep grey matter structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrophy of pons with preservation of midbrain - This pattern is more characteristic of multiple system atrophy (MSA), particularly the cerebellar variant (MSA-C), where pontine atrophy is a prominent feature while the midbrain may be relatively spared.

 

Option B. Atrophy of both pons and midbrain - While some neurodegenerative conditions may affect both structures, PSP specifically shows predominant midbrain atrophy with relative preservation of the pons.

 

Option D. Atrophy of fronto-temporal region - This pattern is characteristic of frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD), which presents with behavioural changes and language deficits rather than the movement disorder seen in PSP.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Progressive supranuclear palsy is characterized by selective midbrain atrophy with relative sparing of the pons, manifesting clinically as a distinctive atypical parkinsonian syndrome with vertical gaze palsy, postural instability, and falls.

questions.text: Plaques Jaunes are seen in: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Head injury

 

Explanation: 

 

Plaques jaunes (meaning "yellow plaques" in French) are yellowish-brown, depressed, retracted patches involving the crests of gyri that represent the end-stage appearance of traumatic brain contusions. These lesions develop as a result of the long-term healing process following traumatic brain injury. Old traumatic lesions characteristically develop these yellow-brown discolored areas on the brain surface, particularly at sites where the brain has impacted against the skull. Histologically, these areas show gliosis and residual hemosiderin-laden macrophages, representing the final stage of resolution of a traumatic contusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis - Neurosyphilis can produce several patterns of CNS involvement including meningovascular neurosyphilis, paretic neurosyphilis, and tabes dorsalis, but plaques jaunes are not characteristic of syphilitic infection. Neurosyphilis typically shows meningeal inflammation, obliterative endarteritis, and in some cases, parenchymal damage.

 

Option C. Endocarditis - Infective endocarditis can lead to cerebral complications through septic emboli, resulting in multiple infarcts or abscesses, but these do not produce the characteristic yellow plaques seen in healed traumatic lesions.

 

Option D. Atherosclerosis - Cerebral atherosclerosis can lead to ischemic infarcts that eventually form cavitations, but these typically appear as fluid-filled cavities with surrounding gliosis rather than the yellow surface discoloration characteristic of plaques jaunes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Plaques jaunes are pathognomonic for healed traumatic brain contusions, appearing as yellowish-brown, depressed scars on the crests of gyri at sites of previous trauma, representing the end-stage of traumatic brain injury healing.

questions.text: The predominant differentiation in Kaposi's sarcoma is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Lymphatic

 

Explanation: 

 

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV, also known as human herpesvirus 8 [HHV8]). The predominant differentiation in KS is lymphatic in nature, which is evident from its histology and pathogenesis. While Kaposi sarcoma has features of both blood vessel and lymphatic differentiation, the predominant endothelial differentiation is lymphatic, which is consistent with the virus's tropism for lymphatic endothelium. This explains why KS can arise in settings of lymphedema (as in the Steward-Treves syndrome) and is classified as a lymphangiosarcoma in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neural - Kaposi sarcoma does not show neural differentiation. Neural differentiation is seen in tumors like schwannomas and neurofibromas, which arise from neural sheath cells.

 

Option C. Muscular - While blood vessels contain smooth muscle cells, Kaposi sarcoma is primarily of endothelial origin with lymphatic differentiation. Tumors with muscular differentiation include leiomyomas and leiomyosarcomas.

 

Option D. Epithelial - Kaposi sarcoma shows endothelial rather than epithelial differentiation. Epithelial differentiation is characteristic of carcinomas, which arise from epithelial tissues like skin or glandular structures.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Kaposi sarcoma shows predominantly lymphatic endothelial differentiation and is caused by KSHV/HHV8 infection, appearing in four clinical variants: classic, endemic African, transplantation-associated, and AIDS-associated, with the latter being the most aggressive form.

questions.text: The number of Barr bodies in Klinefelter’s syndrome is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 1

 

Explanation: 

 

In Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY), there is one Barr body. The number of Barr bodies follows the formula of the number of X chromosomes minus one (X-1). Since Klinefelter syndrome patients have two X chromosomes (XXY), they have one Barr body (2-1=1). This is a phenotypically male condition that is the most common genetic cause of male infertility, characterized by testicular atrophy, decreased testosterone, increased FSH/LH, gynecomastia, and tall stature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0 - This is incorrect for Klinefelter syndrome. Normal males (XY) and Turner syndrome patients (XO) have zero Barr bodies because they only have one X chromosome (1-1=0).

 

Option C. 2 - This would be found in a 47,XXX karyotype (Triple X syndrome or "Superfemale"), where three X chromosomes are present, resulting in two Barr bodies (3-1=2).

 

Option D. 3 - This would be found in a female with four X chromosomes (e.g., 48,XXXX), which is extremely rare. The number of Barr bodies would be three (4-1=3).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The number of Barr bodies follows the simple formula (X-1), where Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) has one Barr body, normal females (46,XX) have one Barr body, and normal males (46,XY) have zero Barr bodies.

questions.text: Perl’s stain is used to demonstrate which of the following in tissues? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Hemosiderin

 

Explanation: 

 

Perl's stain (also known as Prussian blue stain) is specifically used to demonstrate hemosiderin in tissues. Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex that appears as blue granules when stained with Perl's stain. This staining technique is particularly useful in detecting iron deposits in tissues, which occurs in conditions like hemosiderosis or hemochromatosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fat - Fat in tissues is typically demonstrated using special fat stains such as Oil Red O or Sudan stains, not Perl's stain. These fat stains work on frozen sections as lipids are dissolved by the solvents used in routine tissue processing.

 

Option C. Reticulin - Reticulin fibers are demonstrated using silver stains like Gordon and Sweet's silver stain, which highlights the thin reticular fibers in black or dark brown. Perl's stain does not demonstrate reticulin.

 

Option D. Fibrin - Fibrin is typically demonstrated using special stains like Phosphotungstic Acid-Hematoxylin (PTAH) or Martius Scarlet Blue (MSB) stain, which color fibrin red or blue depending on the stain used. Perl's stain does not demonstrate fibrin.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Perl's stain (Prussian blue) is specifically used to detect iron deposits like hemosiderin in tissues, appearing as blue granules, and is valuable in diagnosing iron overload disorders and conditions with abnormal iron metabolism.

questions.text: Disorders resulting from defects in nucleotide excision repair include all of the following except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Ataxia Telangiectasia (AT)

 

Explanation:

 

Ataxia telangiectasia is not a disorder resulting from defects in nucleotide excision repair. It is instead caused by mutations in the ATM gene (Ataxia Telangiectasia Mutated), which is involved in DNA double-strand break repair pathways. The ATM protein functions as a cell cycle checkpoint kinase that phosphorylates and activates proteins involved in DNA damage response. This condition is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia, oculocutaneous telangiectasia, immunodeficiency, and increased risk of malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) - This is correctly associated with defects in nucleotide excision repair. XP is characterized by extreme sensitivity to UV light, resulting in severe sunburns, pigmentation changes, and a high risk of skin cancers. It is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in nucleotide excision repair.

 

Option B. Cockayne syndrome (CS) - This is correctly associated with defects in nucleotide excision repair. Specifically, it involves defects in transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair. CS is characterized by growth failure, premature aging, and neurological abnormalities.

 

Option C. Trichothiodystrophy (TTD) - This is correctly associated with defects in nucleotide excision repair. TTD is characterized by brittle hair with low sulphur content, intellectual disability, short stature, and ichthyosis. It results from mutations in genes involved in both nucleotide excision repair and transcription.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While Xeroderma Pigmentosum, Cockayne syndrome, and Trichothiodystrophy all result from defects in nucleotide excision repair pathways, Ataxia Telangiectasia involves a distinct DNA repair mechanism related to double-strand break repair through the ATM gene.

questions.text: The histology of a 12-month-old boy with an abdominal tumor shows multiple elements, including blastemal, stromal, and epithelial tissues. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Wilms tumor

 

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) is a malignant renal tumor that typically occurs in children between 2-5 years of age. The characteristic histological pattern described in the question is the classic "triphasic pattern" of Wilms tumor consisting of blastemal, epithelial, and stromal components. This is often referred to by the mnemonic "BEST" (Blastemal, Epithelial, STromal). The tumor presents as an abdominal mass, which is the earliest and most common presentation, along with potential symptoms of fever and hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ganglioneuroma - This is a benign tumor of the sympathetic nervous system composed of mature ganglion cells and Schwann cells. It lacks the triphasic pattern with blastemal elements seen in Wilms tumor.

 

Option B. Neuroblastoma - While this is also a common pediatric malignancy, neuroblastoma is derived from neural crest cells and consists of small round blue cells with rosette formation. It doesn't contain the triphasic pattern described.

 

Option C. Teratocarcinoma - This is a mixed germ cell tumor containing teratomatous elements and embryonal carcinoma. While it may have multiple tissue types, it typically occurs in the gonads (testis) rather than the kidney in children.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Wilms tumor is characterized histologically by a triphasic pattern of blastemal, epithelial, and stromal components (BEST), and is the most common primary renal malignancy in children, typically presenting as an abdominal mass in children aged 2-5 years.

questions.text: Which histological type of Wilms tumor has the worst prognosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Blastemal type

 

Explanation: 

 

Wilms tumor has varying prognosis based on its histological appearance. The blastemal predominant type generally has the worst prognosis among the various histological patterns. This is particularly true in post-chemotherapy specimens where predominant blastemal elements represent chemotherapy-resistant tissue. The blastemal component consists of primitive, undifferentiated cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and significant mitotic activity, contributing to its aggressive behavior.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epithelial type - Epithelial predominant Wilms tumors generally have a better prognosis than blastemal type. These tumors show greater differentiation with tubular and glomeruloid structures.

 

Option B. Stromal type - Stromal predominant Wilms tumors typically have a favorable prognosis. These tumors contain differentiated mesenchymal elements and tend to be less aggressive.

 

Option D. Mixed type - Mixed type Wilms tumors contain relatively balanced proportions of all three components. They generally have an intermediate prognosis, better than blastemal type but potentially worse than purely epithelial or stromal types.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Blastemal predominant Wilms tumor carries the worst prognosis among the histological subtypes, particularly when persistent after chemotherapy, while more differentiated patterns (epithelial and stromal) generally have more favorable outcomes.

questions.text: The Bloom Richardson system is used for grading: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Ca Breast

 

Explanation: 

 

The Bloom-Richardson system is a histologic grading system specifically designed for breast cancer. This system evaluates three key morphological features of the tumor:

 

  1. Tubule formation (the degree to which cancer cells form tubular structures)
  2. Nuclear pleomorphism (variation in nuclear size and shape)
  3. Mitotic count (number of dividing cells, reflecting proliferation rate)

 

Each feature is scored from 1-3, and the scores are combined to determine the final grade (Grade 1-3), which helps predict tumor behavior and guides treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ca Colon - Colorectal carcinomas are typically graded using different systems that assess glandular differentiation, with staging commonly done using Duke's classification or TNM system.

 

Option B. Ca Stomach - Gastric cancer uses the Lauren classification (intestinal vs. diffuse) or WHO classification based on histomorphology, not the Bloom-Richardson system.

 

Option D. Ca Pancreas - Pancreatic adenocarcinoma grading relies on assessment of glandular differentiation and other features using a different grading approach.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Bloom-Richardson (Nottingham) grading system is specifically used for breast cancer and evaluates tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic count to determine tumor grade, which is a critical prognostic factor.

questions.text: Which protein, having structural homology with plasminogen, is responsible for myocardial infarction and stroke? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LP(a)

 

Explanation:


LP(a) or Lipoprotein(a) consists of one mole of LDL attached to one mole of apo(a). The apo(a) component shows structural homologies to plasminogen, which is clinically significant. This similarity to plasminogen, a key protein in the fibrinolytic system, allows LP(a) to inhibit fibrinolysis (the normal breakdown of blood clots). Consequently, LP(a) promotes both atherosclerosis and thrombosis, significantly increasing the risk of premature coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, and stroke.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HDL: High-density lipoprotein is actually protective against cardiovascular disease. It removes cholesterol from peripheral tissues and has antiatherogenic properties without any structural similarity to plasminogen.

 

Option C. LDL:  While low-density lipoprotein contributes to atherosclerosis by delivering cholesterol to tissues, it doesn't have structural homology with plasminogen.

 

Option D. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is an amino acid that at elevated levels is associated with increased cardiovascular risk, but it's not a protein and does not have structural homology with plasminogen.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

LP(a) contributes to cardiovascular disease through a unique dual mechanism: promoting atherosclerosis like LDL, while also increasing thrombosis risk due to its structural homology with plasminogen that inhibits normal fibrinolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests has the briefest window period for identifying HIV infection? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Nucleic acid test (NAT)

 

Explanation:

 

Nucleic acid tests (NATs) have the shortest window period for detecting HIV infection, typically identifying the virus 10-12 days after infection. NATs directly detect viral RNA in the bloodstream rather than waiting for the development of antibodies or sufficient levels of viral proteins. This makes them extremely valuable for detecting very early HIV infections, particularly in high-risk settings or when testing blood donations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibody assay: Antibody tests have a significantly longer window period of approximately 3-12 weeks after infection, as they depend on the host's immune response to produce detectable antibodies against HIV. While they are the most commonly used screening tests due to cost and availability, they cannot detect very early infections.

 

Option B. P24 antigen assay: The p24 antigen test detects the HIV p24 protein and has a window period of about 2-3 weeks after infection. While shorter than antibody tests, it's still longer than NAT. The p24 antigen is often combined with antibody testing in 4th generation assays.

 

Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is actually a type of nucleic acid testing technology used to detect HIV RNA or proviral DNA. When used for HIV RNA detection, it performs similarly to other NATs. This option represents a specific methodology rather than a distinct test category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleic acid tests have the shortest window period (10-12 days) for HIV detection and are the most sensitive for early infection, but antibody-based tests remain the mainstay for routine screening due to cost and availability considerations.

choices.text: The discomfort frequently radiates to the trapezius muscles

questions.text: Which of the following statements about angina pectoris is NOT correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. The discomfort frequently radiates to the trapezius muscles

 

Explanation:

 

Angina pectoris is characterized by chest discomfort that may radiate to the jaw, shoulder, back, or arm, but radiation specifically to the trapezius muscles is not a typical pattern of angina. Angina is classically described as a pressure, squeezing, or heaviness in the chest that can radiate to other areas but not typically to the trapezius muscles. The diagnosis of angina is based on three key features: chest discomfort that is aggravated by exertion or emotional stress and relieved by rest or nitro-glycerine within minutes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is associated with Levine's sign - This is correct. Levine's sign refers to the patient clenching a fist over the sternum to describe the sensation of chest pain typical of angina.

 

Option B. The pain has a crescendo-decrescendo pattern - This is correct. Anginal pain typically builds gradually, reaches a peak, and then subsides, rather than having sudden onset and offset.

 

Option D. Episodes generally last between 2 and 5 minutes - This is correct. Angina episodes typically last less than 5 minutes, often resolving within 30 seconds to 5 minutes, especially when the patient stops exertion or takes nitroglycerin.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Angina pectoris typically presents as chest discomfort that may radiate to the jaw, shoulder, back, or arm (not trapezius muscles), is triggered by exertion or emotional stress, and is relieved by rest or nitroglycerin within minutes.

choices.text: The second intercostal space on the right side
The second intercostal space on the left side
The third intercostal space on the right side
The third intercostal space on the left side

questions.text: In the context of cardiac examination, Erb's point corresponds to which of the following locations? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. The third intercostal space on the left side.

 

Explanation:

 

Erb's point is anatomically located at the third intercostal space on the left side of the sternum. This is an important auscultatory area during cardiac examination as multiple murmurs may be heard at this location. The third left intercostal space is a significant area where sounds from different cardiac structures converge, making it a crucial point for clinical examination of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The second intercostal space on the right side: This is the aortic area of cardiac auscultation where aortic valve sounds and murmurs related to the aortic valve are best heard. It is not Erb's point.

 

Option B. The second intercostal space on the left side: This is the pulmonic area where pulmonic valve sounds and murmurs associated with the pulmonary valve are best heard. This is not Erb's point.

 

Option C. The third intercostal space on the right side: This is not a standard auscultatory area for cardiac examination. Erb's point is specifically on the left side, not the right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erb's point is located at the third intercostal space on the left side of the sternum and serves as an important auscultatory area where multiple cardiac murmurs may be detected during examination.

choices.text: In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a lower pitch
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur is of the crescendo type
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a softer intensity
In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a briefer duration

questions.text: How does the murmur of severe aortic regurgitation differ from that of mild aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a briefer duration

 

Explanation:

 

In severe aortic regurgitation, the diastolic pressure half-time is significantly shorter (<200 ms) compared to mild AR (>500 ms). This occurs because as AR severity increases, the pressure between the aorta and left ventricle equalizes more rapidly during diastole, resulting in a shorter murmur duration. The characteristic murmur is high-pitched, diastolic, and decrescendo in nature, best heard at Erb's area with the patient leaning forward, but in severe AR it terminates earlier in diastole due to this rapid pressure equalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a lower pitch - Incorrect because the murmur of AR is characteristically high-pitched regardless of severity, heard best with the diaphragm of the stethoscope.

 

Option B. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur is of the crescendo type - Incorrect because AR murmurs are typically decrescendo in configuration, beginning loudly and diminishing in intensity as diastole progresses, reflecting the decreasing pressure gradient.

 

Option C. In severe aortic regurgitation, the murmur has a softer intensity - Incorrect because severe AR is typically associated with a louder murmur due to greater regurgitant flow, not softer intensity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The duration of an aortic regurgitation murmur is inversely related to its severity - severe AR produces a shorter diastolic murmur due to more rapid pressure equalization between the aorta and left ventricle, as evidenced by a shorter pressure half-time (<200 ms in severe AR versus >500 ms in mild AR)

questions.text: An individual experiences sudden death, and their ECG reveals ST segment elevation in leads V1-V3 along with right bundle branch block. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Brugada syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Brugada syndrome is characterized by a distinctive ECG pattern showing ST segment elevation in right precordial leads (V1-V3) with a right bundle branch block (RBBB) appearance. This genetic disorder affects cardiac sodium channels and predisposes patients to ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, especially during sleep or rest. The ECG abnormalities can wax and wane over time and may become more pronounced during acute illness and fever. The pattern includes a coved ST elevation followed by a negative T wave in the right precordial leads.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Though HOCM is a cause of sudden cardiac death, its ECG findings typically include left ventricular hypertrophy, deep Q waves in lateral and inferior leads, and ST-T wave abnormalities. It does not produce the characteristic ST elevation in V1-V3 with RBBB pattern seen in Brugada syndrome.

 

Option B. Aortic valve stenosis: While aortic stenosis can cause sudden death, its ECG findings typically include left ventricular hypertrophy and ST-T wave abnormalities in lateral leads. It doesn't cause the specific pattern of ST elevation in V1-V3 with RBBB seen in this case.

 

Option D. Ashman phenomenon: This is a conduction abnormality characterized by aberrant ventricular conduction (typically RBBB morphology) following a short-long R-R interval sequence. It is not associated with ST elevation in V1-V3 and is not a cause of sudden cardiac death.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Brugada syndrome presents with a distinctive ECG pattern of ST elevation in right precordial leads (V1-V3) with RBBB appearance and is an important cause of sudden cardiac death in structurally normal hearts, especially in young adults.

choices.text: Inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere
Inferior frontal gyrus of the right hemisphere
Superior temporal gyrus of the left hemisphere
Superior temporal gyrus of the right hemisphere

questions.text: A right-handed individual exhibits non-fluent aphasia with intact comprehension. Which of the following brain regions is most likely affected? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Inferior frontal gyrus of the left hemisphere

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has non-fluent aphasia with intact comprehension, which is characteristic of Broca's aphasia. Broca's aphasia results from damage to the inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area) in the dominant hemisphere, which is the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals. This area is supplied by the superior division of the middle cerebral artery. In Broca's aphasia, speech production is impaired (non-fluent) while comprehension remains relatively intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior frontal gyrus of the right hemisphere: In right-handed individuals, language functions are usually lateralized to the left hemisphere. The right inferior frontal gyrus is not primarily responsible for language production, so damage here would not typically cause non-fluent aphasia.

 

Option C. Superior temporal gyrus of the left hemisphere: Damage to this area (Wernicke's area) causes a different type of aphasia characterized by fluent speech with poor comprehension (Wernicke's aphasia), which is the opposite of what the patient exhibits.

 

Option D. Superior temporal gyrus of the right hemisphere: Similar to option B, the right hemisphere in right-handed individuals is not dominant for language functions. Damage to this area would not typically cause aphasia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Non-fluent aphasia with preserved comprehension (Broca's aphasia) results from damage to the inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area) in the dominant hemisphere, which is the left hemisphere in most right-handed individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following features of tuberous sclerosis is typically present during infancy but resolves by adulthood? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Rhabdomyomas of the heart

 

Explanation:

 

Rhabdomyomas of the heart are benign tumors that represent one of the earliest manifestations of tuberous sclerosis. These cardiac tumors are typically present during fetal life or early infancy but have a tendency to spontaneously regress with age. The majority of cardiac rhabdomyomas associated with tuberous sclerosis resolve by childhood or early adulthood, often without causing significant clinical problems. While present, they can cause arrhythmias or outflow obstruction, but their natural history is typically one of regression rather than progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angiofibromas on the face: These lesions (formerly called adenoma sebaceum) typically appear during childhood (around 3-5 years of age) and persist throughout adulthood. They are reddish-brown papules that appear in a butterfly distribution across the face and tend to increase in number and size during adolescence rather than resolving.

 

Option C. Fibromas around the nails: Periungual fibromas (Koenen tumors) typically appear during adolescence or early adulthood and persist rather than resolve. These flesh-colored nodules emerge from the nail folds, primarily of the toes but sometimes the fingers.

 

Option D. Angiomyolipomas in the kidneys: Renal angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that typically appear during childhood or adolescence and continue to grow throughout adulthood. They do not spontaneously regress and may require monitoring or intervention if they grow large or cause symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cardiac rhabdomyomas are unique among the major manifestations of tuberous sclerosis in that they typically appear in early life and have a natural history of spontaneous regression, while most other tuberous sclerosis lesions persist or progress over time.

choices.text: It is a complication of measles virus infection
Its incidence has decreased after the introduction of vaccination
It most commonly affects individuals between 5 and 15 years old
It typically presents initially with fever and headache

questions.text: Which of the following statements about subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is NOT correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. It typically presents initially with fever and headache

 

Explanation:

 

SSPE is a rare, progressive neurological disorder caused by a persistent measles virus infection that leads to brain inflammation and neurodegeneration. The disease typically has an insidious onset with subtle behavioral and intellectual deterioration rather than acute symptoms like fever and headache.

 

SSPE presents with progressive cognitive decline, personality changes, and school performance deterioration as the initial manifestations. This is followed by myoclonus, ataxia, and eventually a vegetative state. The absence of fever and headache as initial presenting features distinguishes it from acute viral encephalitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a complication of measles virus infection: This statement is correct. SSPE is caused by a persistent infection with a defective measles virus that remains dormant in the CNS for years after the initial infection before causing progressive neurodegeneration.

 

Option B. Its incidence has decreased after the introduction of vaccination: This statement is correct. The introduction of measles vaccination has significantly reduced the incidence of SSPE, as preventing the primary measles infection prevents the subsequent development of SSPE.

 

Option C. It most commonly affects individuals between 5 and 15 years old: This statement is correct. SSPE typically affects children and adolescents who had measles infection at a very young age, with disease onset usually occurring 6-8 years after the primary infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

SSPE presents with insidious behavioral and cognitive changes rather than acute symptoms like fever and headache, and represents a rare but devastating delayed complication of measles virus infection that has become increasingly uncommon due to vaccination.

choices.text: Neither the white nor the gray matter

questions.text: Binswanger's disease, a form of vascular dementia, primarily affects which part of the brain? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. The white matter

 

Explanation:

 

Binswanger's disease, also known as subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy, is a prototypical clinical syndrome of vascular cognitive impairment that primarily affects the white matter of the brain. The condition is characterized by progressive confluent subcortical and periventricular white matter disease visible on neuroimaging, with hypoperfusion and hypometabolism. Pathologically, it involves extensive demyelination and destruction of white matter with relative sparing of the subcortical U fibers. Patients typically present with hypertension or systemic vascular disease, and may develop gradual accumulation of focal neurological deficits along with cognitive dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The gray matter: Binswanger's disease specifically targets white matter rather than gray matter. Gray matter disorders typically present with different clinical patterns, such as cortical symptoms including aphasia, agnosia, or apraxia, which are not characteristic of Binswanger's disease.

 

Option C. Both the white and gray matter: While some vascular dementias can affect both white and gray matter, Binswanger's disease is defined by its predominant impact on white matter. The pathology shows selective destruction of white matter with relative preservation of gray matter structures.

 

Option D. Neither the white nor the gray matter: This is incorrect as Binswanger's disease definitively affects brain tissue, specifically the white matter regions. It is not a disease of other tissues such as blood vessels alone or non-neural brain components.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Binswanger's disease is a subcortical vascular dementia characterized by progressive white matter destruction due to small vessel disease, resulting in a dysexecutive syndrome with apathy, mood alterations, executive dysfunction, and slowed information processing.

choices.text: There is an incremental response on 2-3 Hz nerve stimulation
Antibodies are directed against voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCC)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is NOT correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. There is an incremental response on 2-3 Hz nerve stimulation

 

Explanation:

 

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is a presynaptic disorder of the neuromuscular junction. In LEMS, at low rates of repetitive nerve stimulation (2-3 Hz), a decremental response is observed, similar to myasthenia gravis. However, at high rates of stimulation (20-50 Hz) or following brief exercise, an incremental response occurs, which is characteristic of LEMS. This distinguishes LEMS from myasthenia gravis. LEMS is caused by autoantibodies directed against P/Q-type calcium channels at motor nerve terminals, which impair acetylcholine release.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibodies are directed against voltage: gated calcium channels (VGCC) - This statement is correct. LEMS is caused by autoantibodies directed against P/Q-type calcium channels at the motor nerve terminals, detected in approximately 85% of LEMS patients. These autoantibodies impair the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

 

Option C. Reflexes are absent or depressed: This statement is correct. In LEMS, patients have depressed or absent reflexes, which is a distinguishing feature from myasthenia gravis.

 

Option D. Patients experience autonomic changes: This statement is correct. LEMS patients experience autonomic changes such as dry mouth and impotence, which are characteristic features of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In LEMS, a decremental response occurs at low rates of nerve stimulation (2-3 Hz), while an incremental response is seen at high rates of stimulation (20-50 Hz) or after brief exercise—this electrophysiologic pattern helps distinguish LEMS from myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Which of the following vascular events is most closely associated with pure word deafness? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Stroke involving the middle cerebral artery

 

Explanation:

 

Pure word deafness results from damage to the auditory association cortex in the temporal lobe. The inferior division of the middle cerebral artery supplies the temporal cortex and Wernicke's area. Pure word deafness presents with intact fluency, lost comprehension specifically to spoken language, lost repetition, but intact naming - a distinctive pattern caused by focal damage to auditory language processing pathways, which are within the MCA territory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stroke involving the posterior cerebral artery: PCA strokes typically cause visual field defects, and when affecting the dominant hemisphere may cause alexia without agraphia, but not pure word deafness as the PCA supplies primarily visual processing areas.

 

Option C. Aneurysm of the vertebral artery: Vertebral artery lesions typically cause lateral medullary syndrome with symptoms like vertigo, ipsilateral facial sensory loss, and contralateral body sensory loss, not language disorders.

 

Option D. Aneurysm of the basilar artery: Basilar artery lesions produce brainstem syndromes with cranial nerve palsies and long tract signs, not selective auditory comprehension deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Pure word deafness is a distinctive language disorder involving selective impairment of spoken language comprehension with preserved other language functions, resulting from lesions to the temporal auditory processing areas in the middle cerebral artery territory.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Paralysis of the tongue

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) results from occlusion of the vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), affecting the lateral medulla. Key features include ipsilateral cerebellar signs (ataxia), Horner's syndrome, and sensory deficits with a classic crossed pattern (ipsilateral face and contralateral body). Dysphagia and dysarthria occur due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus (9th, 10th cranial nerves). However, tongue paralysis (hypoglossal or 12th nerve dysfunction) is notably absent because the hypoglossal nucleus lies medially in the medulla and is not affected in this lateral syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ataxia: This IS a characteristic feature of Wallenberg syndrome due to involvement of the spinocerebellar tracts and connections to the cerebellum, causing ipsilateral cerebellar signs.

 

Option B. Difficulty swallowing: This IS a characteristic feature due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus which supplies the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, resulting in dysphagia, dysphonia, and impaired gag reflex.

 

Option C. Crossed pattern of sensory loss: This IS a classic feature with ipsilateral face sensory loss (from trigeminal nucleus involvement) and contralateral body sensory loss (from spinothalamic tract involvement).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lateral medullary syndrome produces a distinctive constellation of ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, Horner's syndrome, and facial sensory loss with contralateral body sensory loss, but spares the hypoglossal nerve (XII), so tongue paralysis is not part of this syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic finding in Reiter's syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Nodules in the subcutaneous tissue

 

Explanation:

 

Reiter's syndrome, now termed Reactive Arthritis (ReA), is one of the seronegative spondyloarthropathies characterized by a clinical triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis that typically follows gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections. ReA has specific skin manifestations including circinate balanitis (inflammation of the penis glans), keratoderma blennorrhagica (pustular skin lesions on palms/soles), and oral ulcerations. Subcutaneous nodules are not characteristic of ReA but are instead a classic finding in rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratoderma blennorrhagica: This is a characteristic skin manifestation of Reiter's syndrome, appearing as pustular skin lesions on palms and soles that can resemble psoriasis. This distinctive rash is a key diagnostic feature of ReA.

 

Option C. Balanitis circinate: This is a characteristic finding in Reiter's syndrome, presenting as inflammation of the glans penis with circular lesions. It's one of the specific mucocutaneous manifestations of ReA.

 

Option D. Ulcerations in the oral cavity: Oral ulcerations are indeed a characteristic finding in Reiter's syndrome. These painless ulcers are part of the mucocutaneous manifestations that can occur in patients with ReA.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rheumatoid nodules (subcutaneous nodules) are characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis but not Reiter's syndrome/Reactive Arthritis, which instead features distinctive skin and mucosal lesions including keratoderma blennorrhagica, circinate balanitis, and oral ulcerations.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered an extra glandular manifestation of Sjogren's syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Enlargement of both parotid glands

 

Explanation:

 

Enlargement of the parotid glands is one of the main glandular manifestations of Sjögren's syndrome, not an extra-glandular manifestation. Parotid gland enlargement occurs in about two-thirds of patients with primary Sjögren's syndrome due to lymphocytic infiltration of the gland. This is considered part of the primary exocrinopathy that characterizes the disease, alongside xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenomenon of Raynaud: This is a true extra-glandular manifestation of Sjögren's syndrome, occurring in approximately 37% of patients. In one-third of patients, it precedes the sicca manifestations and is categorized as a non-specific extra-glandular feature.

 

Option B. Nephritis of the tubulointerstitial type: This is a genuine extra-glandular manifestation affecting 9% of Sjögren's syndrome patients. It is categorized as a peri-epithelial manifestation, typically asymptomatic, and results from lymphocyte accumulation around renal tubules.

 

Option D. Development of lymphoma: This is a serious extra-glandular manifestation occurring in approximately 6% of Sjögren's syndrome patients. Glandular MALT lymphoma is most common, with risk factors including persistent parotid enlargement, purpura, leukopenia, cryoglobulinemia, low C4 complement, and certain autoantibodies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sjögren's syndrome manifestations are classified as either glandular (involving exocrine glands like parotid, lacrimal, and salivary) or extra-glandular (affecting other organ systems including lungs, kidneys, vessels, and nervous system), with the latter occurring in about one-third of patients and determining disease severity.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT associated with granulomatous pathology? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Polyarteritis nodosa (classic PAN)

 

Explanation:

 

Polyarteritis nodosa is characterized by a necrotizing inflammation of small and medium-sized muscular arteries, but it does not typically demonstrate granulomatous features. PAN is a panarteritis that involves neutrophil infiltration of all layers of the vessel wall with fibrinoid necrosis, leading to compromise of the vascular lumen, thrombosis, and tissue infarction. However, granuloma formation - a hallmark of many other vasculitides - is notably absent in classic PAN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's):  it is characterized by necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis involving small arteries and veins. The histopathologic hallmarks include granuloma formation that may be intravascular or extravascular, which is crucial to its diagnosis.

 

Option B. Arteritis of Takayasu:  it demonstrates granulomatous inflammation of the vessel wall. The pathological features include granulomatous panarteritis with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasional giant cells.

 

Option D. Arteritis of the giant cell type:  it is defined by granulomatous vasculitis with giant cell formation. This is a panarteritis with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates within the vessel wall and frequent giant cell formation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classic polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing, non-granulomatous vasculitis of medium-sized arteries, distinguishing it from other major vasculitides like GPA, Takayasu arteritis, and Giant Cell Arteritis, which all demonstrate granulomatous inflammation.

choices.text: Systemic sclerosis of the diffuse cutaneous type
Connective tissue disease of the mixed type

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most strongly associated with the presence of anti-centromere antibodies? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Syndrome characterized by CREST features.

 

Explanation: 

 

Anti-centromere antibodies are highly specific for limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), which is classically associated with the CREST syndrome (Calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia). These antibodies show a strong association with clinical features including digital ischemic ulcers, calcinosis cutis, and isolated pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), while renal crisis is rarely seen in patients with this antibody pattern. Anti-centromere antibodies display a discrete speckled (centromere) pattern on immunofluorescence testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic sclerosis of the diffuse cutaneous type: Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc) is associated with anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, not anti-centromere antibodies. These antibody patterns are mutually exclusive in systemic sclerosis.

 

Option B. Connective tissue disease of the mixed type: Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is characterized by the presence of U1-RNP antibodies. Anti-centromere antibodies are not a serological feature of MCTD.

 

Option D. Inflammatory myopathy, particularly polymyositis: PM/Scl and anti-Jo antibodies are the serological markers associated with myositis overlap syndromes. Anti-centromere antibodies are not typically found in inflammatory myopathies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anti-centromere antibodies have high specificity for limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) and the CREST variant, serving as important serological markers that help distinguish this clinical phenotype from other forms of systemic sclerosis and connective tissue disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT indicate a state of prediabetes? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. All of the above.

 

Explanation:

 

None of the options listed (A, B, or C) actually indicate prediabetes. Instead, they represent values below the diagnostic thresholds for diabetes. Prediabetes is specifically defined as:

Fasting plasma glucose (FPG) = 5.6-6.9 mmol/L (100-125 mg/dL), termed "impaired fasting glucose" (IFG)

Plasma glucose levels between 7.8 and 11.0 mmol/L (140-199 mg/dL) following oral glucose challenge, termed "impaired glucose tolerance" (IGT)

HbA1c of 5.7-6.4%

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fasting glucose levels below 126 mg/dl: This is not a specific indicator of prediabetes. While prediabetes (100-125 mg/dL) falls within this range, so does normal glucose (<100 mg/dL). FPG ≥126 mg/dL is the diagnostic threshold for diabetes.

 

Option B. 2-hour post-glucose (PG) levels below 200 mg/dl: This includes both normal (<140 mg/dL) and prediabetic (140-199 mg/dL) ranges. A 2-hour PG ≥200 mg/dL indicates diabetes.

 

Option C. Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels below 7%: This includes normal (<5.7%), prediabetic (5.7-6.4%), and even some diabetic (6.5-6.9%) values. HbA1c ≥6.5% is diagnostic for diabetes.

 

Option D. All of the above: Correct answer as none of these values specifically indicate prediabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prediabetes has specific diagnostic ranges (FPG 100-125 mg/dL, 2-hour PG 140-199 mg/dL, or HbA1c 5.7-6.4%) that represent intermediate hyperglycemia between normal glucose tolerance and diabetes.

choices.text: It is a large-caliber arteriole situated beneath the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract
It hemorrhages through a tiny mucosal erosion
It is most frequently found on the greater curvature of the proximal stomach
It is also referred to as a persistent caliber artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding a Dieulafoy's lesion is NOT accurate? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  C. It is most frequently found on the greater curvature of the proximal stomach.

 

Explanation:

 

A Dieulafoy's lesion is an uncommon but important cause of gastrointestinal bleeding. While these lesions do occur in the stomach, they are not predominantly found on the greater curvature of the proximal stomach. Dieulafoy's lesions can occur throughout the GI tract, with the most common location being the lesser curvature of the stomach, particularly within 6 cm of the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a large-caliber arteriole situated beneath the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract: Dieulafoy's lesions are characterized by abnormally large submucosal arterioles that can erode through the overlying mucosa and cause bleeding.

 

Option B. It hemorrhages through a tiny mucosal erosion:  Dieulafoy's lesions bleed through small mucosal defects or erosions, making them sometimes difficult to detect endoscopically when not actively bleeding.

 

Option D. It is also referred to as a persistent caliber artery: Dieulafoy's lesions are sometimes called "persistent caliber arteries" because they maintain their large diameter as they approach the mucosa, rather than tapering normally.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dieulafoy's lesions are an important cause of GI bleeding characterized by large submucosal arterioles that bleed through small mucosal defects, and are most commonly found on the lesser curvature of the stomach rather than the greater curvature.

questions.text: Gastric antral vascular ectasia is responsible for which of the following appearances? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Watermelon stomach.

 

Explanation:

 

Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by its distinctive endoscopic appearance resembling the stripes of a watermelon, hence the name "watermelon stomach." This condition features linear red streaks arranged in a radial pattern around the antrum of the stomach. These streaks represent dilated mucosal blood vessels that can cause chronic blood loss and iron deficiency anemia. GAVE is often associated with certain systemic conditions including portal hypertension, autoimmune disorders, and chronic renal failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Washerman stomach: This is not a recognized term for any specific gastric endoscopic finding. It does not describe the appearance of gastric antral vascular ectasia.

 

Option C. Windmill stomach: This is not a recognized term in gastroenterology for describing the appearance of gastric lesions or vascular abnormalities.

 

Option D. Windshield stomach: This is not a recognized term for any specific gastric endoscopic finding. It is not used to describe gastric antral vascular ectasia or any other known gastric condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Gastric antral vascular ectasia produces a characteristic endoscopic appearance called "watermelon stomach" with red stripes resembling a watermelon, representing dilated blood vessels that can cause chronic blood loss.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions reduces the dose requirement of thyroid hormone replacement in a woman with hypothyroidism? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Having liver cirrhosis

 

Explanation:

 

Liver cirrhosis reduces thyroid hormone requirements because cirrhosis is associated with decreased thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) metabolism, which leads to reduced clearance of thyroid hormones. Cirrhosis is a condition that decreases TBG levels. When TBG levels are decreased, less exogenous thyroid hormone is needed to maintain euthyroidism as more free hormone is available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Being pregnant: Pregnancy actually increases thyroid hormone requirements by up to 45% during pregnancy in levothyroxine-treated hypothyroid women. Women should increase levothyroxine from once daily dosing to nine doses per week as soon as pregnancy is confirmed to anticipate these increased needs.

 

Option C. Taking phenytoin: Phenytoin increases thyroid hormone requirements. As an antiepileptic drug (AED), phenytoin induces hepatic enzymes that accelerate the metabolism of thyroid hormones, necessitating higher replacement doses to maintain euthyroidism.

 

Option D. Receiving androgen therapy: Androgen therapy decreases TBG levels, which would theoretically reduce thyroid hormone requirements, similar to cirrhosis. However, this doesn't automatically translate to a significant clinical reduction in replacement needs compared to the pronounced effect of liver cirrhosis on overall thyroid hormone metabolism.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Conditions that decrease thyroid-binding globulin levels or reduce thyroid hormone metabolism (like cirrhosis) decrease thyroid hormone replacement requirements, while conditions that increase binding proteins or enhance metabolism (like pregnancy or enzyme-inducing medications) increase replacement needs.

choices.text: Human T-lymphotropic Virus 1 (HTLV-1) and Adult T-cell Leukemia
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and Diffuse B-Cell Lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of infectious agents and their associated malignancies is incorrectly matched? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and Lymphoplasmacytic Lymphoma.

 

Explanation:

 

HHV-8 is not associated with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. HHV-8 is associated with primary effusion lymphoma and multicentric Castleman's disease. Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (Waldenström macroglobulinemia) is associated with hepatitis C virus, not HHV-8, as shown in the infectious associations of lymphoid malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) and Burkitt's Lymphoma: EBV is strongly associated with endemic (African) Burkitt's lymphoma, where it can be found in nearly all cases, while most non-endemic BLs are EBV negative.

 

Option B. Human T-lymphotropic Virus 1 (HTLV-1) and Adult T-cell Leukemia: HTLV-1 directly leads to adult T-cell lymphoma/leukemia (ATL) in a small percentage of infected individuals. The virus is transmitted through breast milk from infected mothers.

 

Option C. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and Diffuse B-Cell Lymphoma: HIV infection predisposes patients to developing aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infectious agents can play significant roles in the pathogenesis of specific lymphoid malignancies, but each has characteristic associations that are important for understanding disease etiology and treatment approaches.

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibodies is incorrectl
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Anti-LKM3 and Chronic Hepatitis C

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-LKM3 is associated with chronic hepatitis D, not chronic hepatitis C. In the classification of chronic hepatitis, anti-LKM3 antibodies are specifically linked to hepatitis D virus infection, while hepatitis C has different immunologic markers. This represents an important serologic distinction that helps in differentiating between these viral hepatitis types.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-LKM1 and Autoimmune Hepatitis II: This association is correct. Anti-LKM1 (liver-kidney microsome type 1) antibodies are characteristic markers of type II autoimmune hepatitis. These antibodies can occasionally be found in some cases of hepatitis C, but they are primarily diagnostic for autoimmune hepatitis type II.

 

Option B. Anti-LKM2 and Drug-Induced Hepatitis: This association is correct. Anti-LKM2 antibodies are directed against cytochrome P450 enzymes and are characteristically found in cases of drug-induced hepatitis, reflecting the immunologic response to drug-metabolite adducts formed during hepatic injury.

 

Option D. Anti-SLA and Autoimmune Hepatitis Type III: This association is correct. Anti-SLA (antibodies to soluble liver antigen) are specifically associated with autoimmune hepatitis type III, which represents a serologic subcategory of autoimmune hepatitis with distinctive clinical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Specific autoantibody profiles serve as important serologic markers that help differentiate between various forms of chronic liver disease - anti-LKM3 is specifically associated with chronic hepatitis D, not hepatitis C, while different LKM autoantibody subtypes have distinct disease associations.

questions.text: A patient presents with elevated bilirubin levels. Urine urobilinogen is absent, but urine bilirubin is present. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Obstructive jaundice

 

Explanation:

 

The pattern of laboratory findings with elevated bilirubin levels, presence of bilirubin in urine, and absence of urobilinogen in urine is characteristic of obstructive (cholestatic) jaundice. In obstructive jaundice, conjugated bilirubin cannot be excreted into the intestine due to biliary obstruction. This conjugated hyperbilirubinemia results in spillage of water-soluble conjugated bilirubin into urine (bilirubinuria). Since bilirubin cannot reach the intestine, there is no formation of urobilinogen by intestinal bacteria, resulting in absent urinary urobilinogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis: While hepatitis can cause elevated bilirubin, it typically has a mixed pattern with both direct and indirect bilirubin elevation. In hepatitis, urobilinogen would be present or elevated in urine due to continued, albeit reduced, flow of bilirubin to the intestines where it is converted to urobilinogen.

 

Option B. Hemolytic jaundice: In hemolytic jaundice, there is unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia due to excessive destruction of red blood cells. Since unconjugated bilirubin is not water-soluble, it cannot appear in urine. Urobilinogen would be increased, not absent, due to increased bilirubin load reaching the intestines.

 

Option D. Gilbert's syndrome: This is characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. As with hemolytic jaundice, unconjugated bilirubin does not appear in urine. Additionally, urobilinogen would be normal or slightly increased in Gilbert's syndrome, not absent.

 

Educational Objective:
