The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by K+ gradient, and alterations in extracellular K+ concentration have significant effects on neuronal excitability - hyperkalemia increases excitability by bringing the membrane potential closer to threshold.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones reduces food intake via dual pathways by stimulating melanocyte stimulating hormone and inhibiting AgRP? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Leptin 

 

Explanation: 

 

Leptin is produced by adipose tissue and signals the status of fat stores in the body. As adipocytes increase in size, they release greater quantities of leptin which decreases food intake by increasing the expression of anorexigenic factors in the hypothalamus such as pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC). POMC is the precursor to melanocyte stimulating hormone. Leptin crosses the blood-brain barrier and activates central factors in the hypothalamus that decrease food intake through multiple pathways, including stimulating POMC/melanocyte stimulating hormone while inhibiting orexigenic factors like AgRP.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. GLP-1: While GLP-1 is a hormone released coincident with meals that plays roles in digestion and absorption, it doesn't have the specific dual effect on melanocyte stimulating hormone and AgRP described in the question.
  • Option C. Ghrelin: Contrary to the question, ghrelin is a predominantly fast-acting orexin that stimulates food intake. It increases synthesis/release of central orexins, including neuropeptide Y and cannabinoids, and suppresses the ability of leptin to stimulate anorexigenic factors.
  • Option D. Insulin: Insulin doesn't have the specific documented effect on melanocyte stimulating hormone and AgRP pathways related to food intake as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptin functions as a critical anorexigenic hormone (decreases appetite) by acting on hypothalamic centers through multiple pathways, serving as a key signal from adipose tissue to the brain about the body's energy stores.

questions.text: All of the following are unpaired anterior branches of the abdominal aorta, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Median sacral artery

 

 

The median sacral artery is not an anterior branch of the abdominal aorta, but rather a terminal branch that arises from the posterior aspect of the aorta at its bifurcation into the common iliac arteries. It descends in the midline anterior to the sacrum and coccyx. This artery is unpaired but is not classified as an anterior branch due to its position and point of origin.

 

The main unpaired anterior branches of the abdominal aorta include the celiac trunk (T12-L1), superior mesenteric artery (L1), and inferior mesenteric artery (L3), which supply the foregut, midgut, and hindgut respectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Celiac trunk - This is indeed an unpaired anterior branch of the abdominal aorta arising at the level of T12-L1. It divides into the left gastric, splenic, and common hepatic arteries and supplies the foregut derivatives.

 

Option B. Inferior mesenteric artery - This is an unpaired anterior branch of the abdominal aorta arising at the level of L3. It supplies the hindgut derivatives including the left one-third of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and upper rectum.

 

Option C. Superior mesenteric artery - This is an unpaired anterior branch of the abdominal aorta arising at the level of L1. It supplies the midgut derivatives including the small intestine, cecum, appendix, ascending colon, and right two-thirds of the transverse colon.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The abdominal aorta has three major unpaired anterior branches (celiac trunk, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery) that supply the three embryological divisions of the gut, while the median sacral artery is a terminal branch arising from the posterior aspect of the aorta at its bifurcation.

questions.text: The inferior epigastric artery originates from which of the following arteries? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. External iliac artery

 

The inferior epigastric artery originates from the external iliac artery just above the inguinal ligament near the lower end. It runs upwards and medially in the extraperitoneal connective tissue, passes just medial to the deep inguinal ring, pierces the fascia transversalis at the lateral border of the rectus abdominis, and enters the rectus sheath by passing in front of the arcuate line. Within the sheath, it supplies the rectus muscle and ends by anastomosing with the superior epigastric artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Internal iliac artery - This artery gives rise to branches that supply pelvic viscera and the gluteal region, but it does not give rise to the inferior epigastric artery. The internal iliac artery provides branches like the superior and inferior gluteal arteries, internal pudendal artery, and obturator artery.

 

Option C. Femoral artery - The femoral artery is the continuation of the external iliac artery below the inguinal ligament. It supplies the lower limb and gives branches like the superficial epigastric artery (not the inferior epigastric), but not the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Option D. Thoracic artery - The thoracic artery (likely referring to the internal thoracic/internal mammary artery) gives rise to the superior epigastric artery, not the inferior epigastric. The superior epigastric artery anastomoses with the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The inferior epigastric artery is a branch of the external iliac artery that runs upward in the anterior abdominal wall to supply the rectus abdominis muscle and forms an important anastomosis with the superior epigastric artery, creating a connection between the subclavian and external iliac arterial systems.

questions.text: What is the distance from the upper incisor teeth to the bronchial constriction of the esophagus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. 27 cm

 

Explanation:

 

The bronchial constriction of the esophagus occurs at the level where the left main bronchus crosses the esophagus, which is approximately 27 cm (11 inches) from the upper incisor teeth. This constriction is located at the T6 vertebral level. The esophagus has four sites of constriction: the cervical constriction at the cricopharyngeal junction (C6), the aortic constriction where the aortic arch crosses (T4), the bronchial constriction at the left main bronchus (T6), and the diaphragmatic constriction at the esophageal hiatus (T10). These constrictions are important to consider during endoscopic procedures or when evaluating patients with dysphagia.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 15 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the cervical constriction at the cricopharyngeal junction.

 

Option B. 22 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the aortic constriction where the aortic arch crosses the esophagus.

 

Option D. 40 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the diaphragmatic constriction at the esophageal hiatus.

 

Educational objective:

 

The bronchial constriction of the esophagus lies 27 cm (11 inches) from the upper incisor teeth, at the level where the left main bronchus crosses the esophagus (T6 vertebral level).

choices.text: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: Which of the following structures is contained within the femoral canal? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Lymph node of Cloquet

 

The femoral canal is the medial compartment of the femoral sheath, which is a funnel-shaped sleeve of fascia enclosing the upper 3-4 cm of the femoral vessels. The femoral canal contains a lymph node of Cloquet or Rosenmüller, lymphatics, and a small amount of areolar tissue. This lymph node drains the glans penis in males and the clitoris in females. The femoral canal is about 1.5 cm long and about 1.5 cm wide at its base, with its upper end called the femoral ring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral artery - This is incorrect because the femoral artery is contained in the lateral compartment of the femoral sheath, not the femoral canal.

 

Option C. Femoral vein - This is incorrect because the femoral vein is contained in the intermediate compartment of the femoral sheath, not the femoral canal.

 

Option D. Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve - This is incorrect because this nerve occupies the lateral compartment of the femoral sheath along with the femoral artery, not the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The femoral canal is the medial compartment of the femoral sheath containing the lymph node of Cloquet (Rosenmüller), lymphatics, and areolar tissue, making it a potential site for femoral hernia development, especially in females due to their wider pelvis

questions.text: The third ventricle is the cavity of which part of the brain? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Diencephalon

 

The third ventricle is the cavity of the diencephalon, which is part of the forebrain (prosencephalon). The diencephalon consists of thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus, metathalamus, and subthalamus. The third ventricle is a narrow cavity that lies between the two halves of the thalamus. It communicates with the lateral ventricles through the interventricular foramina of Monro, and posteriorly it continues as the cerebral aqueduct which passes through the midbrain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Telencephalon - The telencephalon (cerebral hemispheres) contains the lateral ventricles, not the third ventricle. The lateral ventricles are C-shaped cavities within each cerebral hemisphere.

 

Option B. Mesencephalon - The mesencephalon (midbrain) contains the cerebral aqueduct (aqueduct of Sylvius), not the third ventricle. The cerebral aqueduct connects the third ventricle to the fourth ventricle.

 

Option C. Rhombencephalon - The rhombencephalon (hindbrain) contains the fourth ventricle, not the third ventricle. The fourth ventricle is the cavity of the pons, medulla oblongata and cerebellum.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The third ventricle is specifically the cavity of the diencephalon, situated between the two thalami, and forms part of the ventricular system connecting the lateral ventricles to the fourth ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct.

questions.text: In the mid-axillary line, the right costo-phrenic recess extends up to the level of which rib? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. 10th

 

The pleura (parietal pleura) extends beyond the lung, forming recesses that allow for lung expansion during respiration. At the mid-axillary line, the pleura extends down to the 10th rib, while the lung itself ends at the 8th rib in this line. This creates the costodiaphragmatic recess, which is an important potential space for pleural fluid collection. This anatomical relationship is clinically significant because it makes the area between the 8th and 10th ribs in the mid-axillary line an ideal location for thoracentesis (pleural tapping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6th - This is incorrect as the pleura extends much lower than the 6th rib in the mid-axillary line. The 6th rib marks approximately where the pleura crosses in the mid-clavicular line, not the mid-axillary line.

 

Option C. 8th - The 8th rib in the mid-axillary line marks the lower border of the lung, not the pleura. The pleural reflection extends further down to create the costodiaphragmatic recess.

 

Option D. 12th - The pleura does not extend as far down as the 12th rib in the mid-axillary line. The pleura reaches the 12th rib posteriorly near the vertebral column, not in the mid-axillary line.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The pleura extends to the 10th rib in the mid-axillary line while the lung ends at the 8th rib, creating a costodiaphragmatic recess between the 8th-10th ribs that is clinically important for thoracentesis procedures.

questions.text: In comparison to Bochdalek hernias, Morgagni hernias are: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Less common

 

Morgagni hernias are congenital diaphragmatic hernias that occur anteriorly through the foramen of Morgagni (space of Larrey), which is located between the sternal and costal attachments of the diaphragm. These hernias are significantly less common than Bochdalek hernias, accounting for only about 2-3% of all congenital diaphragmatic hernias. Unlike Bochdalek hernias, Morgagni hernias are typically smaller in size, tend to be right-sided, and are anterior rather than posterior in location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior in location - This is incorrect as Morgagni hernias are anterior diaphragmatic hernias. It's actually Bochdalek hernias that occur posterolaterally through the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm.

 

Option C. Larger in size - This is incorrect as Morgagni hernias are typically smaller than Bochdalek hernias. Bochdalek hernias are often large enough to allow significant herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity.

 

Option D. More frequently left-sided - This is incorrect as Morgagni hernias are more commonly right-sided (90% of cases) or bilateral, whereas Bochdalek hernias are more frequently left-sided (approximately 80-85% of cases).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Morgagni hernias are less common anterior diaphragmatic hernias that are typically right-sided, in contrast to the more common, left-sided, posterior Bochdalek hernias.

questions.text: Injury to which of the following structures will result in decreased lacrimal secretion? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Pterygopalatine ganglion

 

Pterygopalatine ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion associated with the secretomotor pathway of the lacrimal gland. The secretomotor pathway for the lacrimal gland begins at the superior salivatory nucleus in the brainstem, travels via the facial nerve (CN VII) and continues as the greater petrosal nerve. This nerve joins with the deep petrosal nerve in the pterygoid canal to form the nerve of pterygoid canal (Vidian's nerve), which synapses in the pterygopalatine ganglion. Postganglionic fibers then travel with the maxillary nerve to the zygomatic nerve, and then via the zygomaticotemporal nerve to join the lacrimal nerve, ultimately supplying the lacrimal gland and causing lacrimation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid nerve - This is not a standard anatomical term. The parotid gland receives parasympathetic innervation via the otic ganglion through the auriculotemporal nerve, not the lacrimal gland.

 

Option B. Gasserian ganglion - This is the trigeminal ganglion which contains cell bodies of sensory neurons of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). While it's related to the lacrimal nerve (via V1), it doesn't contain parasympathetic fibers for lacrimal secretion.

 

Option C. Ciliary ganglion - This parasympathetic ganglion is associated with CN III and controls pupillary constriction and accommodation. It's not involved in the secretomotor pathway for the lacrimal gland.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The secretomotor pathway for the lacrimal gland follows the course: superior salivatory nucleus → facial nerve → greater petrosal nerve → nerve of pterygoid canal → pterygopalatine ganglion → maxillary nerve → zygomatic nerve → zygomaticotemporal nerve → lacrimal nerve → lacrimal gland.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the auditory pathway? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Genu of the internal capsule

 

The auditory pathway consists of multiple relays from the cochlea to the auditory cortex. The trapezoid body contains crossing fibers from the cochlear nuclei to the superior olivary nucleus. The lateral lemniscus carries auditory information from the superior olivary nucleus to the inferior colliculus. The medial geniculate body is the thalamic relay nucleus for auditory information before it reaches the auditory cortex. However, the genu of internal capsule contains corticobulbar fibers and not auditory fibers. Auditory radiations pass through the sublentiform part of the internal capsule, not the genu.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trapezoid body - This is part of the auditory pathway, containing crossing fibers from cochlear nuclei to superior olivary nucleus.

 

Option B. Medial geniculate body - This is a key relay station in the auditory pathway, located in the thalamus. It receives input from the inferior colliculus and projects to the auditory cortex.

 

Option D. Lateral lemniscus - This is an important auditory tract in the brainstem that carries information from the superior olivary nucleus to the inferior colliculus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The auditory pathway involves the trapezoid body, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, and medial geniculate body before reaching the auditory cortex via the sublentiform (not genu) part of the internal capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following pharyngeal arches do not play a role in the development of the definitive adult tongue? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 2nd pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation: 

 

The 2nd pharyngeal arch does not contribute to the formation of the definitive adult tongue. During tongue development, the 2nd arch mesoderm gets buried below the surface as the 3rd arch mesoderm grows over it to fuse with the mesoderm of the 1st arch. The 2nd arch structures are overgrown and do not form any part of the definitive tongue.

 

Contributions of the other pharyngeal arches:

  • Option A. 1st pharyngeal arch: Forms the anterior two-thirds of the tongue via two lingual swellings and tuberculum impar. This "oral part" of the tongue is innervated by the mandibular branch (V3) for general sensation and chorda tympani (VII) for taste.
  • Option C. 3rd pharyngeal arch: Forms the posterior one-third of the tongue (except the most posterior part). This "pharyngeal part" is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX).
  • Option D. 4th pharyngeal arch: Forms the posterior-most part of the tongue near the vallecula, innervated by the superior laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve (X).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While the 1st, 3rd, and 4th pharyngeal arches contribute to the definitive adult tongue, the 2nd pharyngeal arch mesoderm becomes buried and makes no contribution to the final tongue structure.

questions.text: The cranial part of the accessory nerve supplies which of the following muscles? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Superior constrictor

 

The cranial part of accessory nerve (CN XI) has a distinctive distribution pattern where it joins the vagus nerve (CN X) after both exit through the jugular foramen. After joining the vagus nerve, the cranial part of accessory nerve contributes fibers that are distributed with the pharyngeal branch of vagus nerve to supply 5 out of 6 pharyngeal muscles, including the superior constrictor muscle. It also supplies 4 out of 5 palatal muscles and all intrinsic muscles of the larynx. This unique pattern where the cranial root joins the vagus for distribution is important for understanding pharyngeal innervation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sternocleidomastoid - This muscle is supplied by the spinal part of the accessory nerve, not the cranial part. The spinal root emerges from the lateral aspect of the spinal cord, enters the cranium through foramen magnum, and then exits through jugular foramen.

 

Option B. Trapezius - Like the sternocleidomastoid, trapezius is also supplied by the spinal part of accessory nerve, not the cranial part. The spinal accessory component provides motor innervation to this muscle.

 

Option D. Stylopharyngeus - This is the only pharyngeal muscle not supplied by the cranial part of accessory nerve. It is uniquely innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

 

Educational Objective: The cranial part of accessory nerve joins the vagus nerve and supplies most pharyngeal muscles (5 out of 6) including the superior constrictor, while the spinal part independently supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

questions.text: Which posterior mediastinal structure is located posterior and to the right of the esophagus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Azygos vein

 

The azygos vein is located in the posterior mediastinum, posterior and to the right of the esophagus. In the posterior mediastinum, the azygos vein ascends on the right side of the vertebral column, behind the esophagus, and arches over the root of the right lung to drain into the superior vena cava. The relations of the thoracic part of the esophagus to the right side include the azygos vein, which runs posterior to the esophagus on the right side of the vertebral column.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracic duct - The thoracic duct is located posterior and to the left of the esophagus in the posterior mediastinum, not to the right. It courses upward between the azygos vein and descending aorta.

 

Option B. Descending aorta - The descending thoracic aorta is related to the left side of the esophagus, not the right side. It descends along the left side of the vertebral column.

 

Option D. Vertebral body - While the vertebral column is posterior to the esophagus, it's in the midline rather than specifically to the right of the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The azygos vein runs on the right side of the vertebral column posterior to the esophagus in the posterior mediastinum, making it the only structure among the options that is both posterior and to the right of the esophagus.

questions.text: Which secondary ossification center of the femur is the first to fuse with the shaft? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Lesser trochanter

 

The lesser trochanter is the first secondary ossification center of the femur to fuse with the shaft. This traction epiphysis appears between 13-14 years and fuses with the shaft by 16-17 years. The lesser trochanter is a nonarticular traction epiphysis that provides attachment to the iliopsoas muscle, which exerts a pulling force on this bony projection during muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Greater trochanter - The greater trochanter is also a traction epiphysis (provides attachment to muscles like gluteus medius), but it appears at 4 years and fuses with the shaft around 17-18 years, after the lesser trochanter has already fused.

 

Option C. Femoral head - The femoral head is a pressure epiphysis that appears at 1 year and fuses with the shaft by 18-19 years. Being articular, it's involved in weight transmission at the hip joint.

 

Option D. Distal end - The distal end of the femur is the first secondary ossification center to appear (around birth), but it's the last to fuse with the shaft (around 18-20 years). It's a pressure epiphysis that transmits weight at the knee joint.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Traction epiphyses (like the lesser trochanter) generally fuse earlier than pressure epiphyses (like the femoral head and distal end), with the lesser trochanter being the first secondary ossification center of the femur to fuse with the shaft.

questions.text: Which nerve provides the motor and sensory supply to the diaphragm? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Phrenic nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The phrenic nerve provides both motor and sensory innervation to the diaphragm. It arises from the cervical plexus, specifically from C3-C5 spinal nerve roots (predominantly C4). The phrenic nerve descends through the neck, enters the thorax, and runs between the fibrous pericardium and mediastinal pleura to reach the diaphragm. The right phrenic nerve is shorter, more vertical, and passes through the vena caval opening of the diaphragm, while the left phrenic nerve is longer, more oblique, and pierces the left cupola of the diaphragm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C2, C3, C4 Roots: While the phrenic nerve does originate from cervical roots (mainly C3-C5, with C4 predominating), these roots themselves do not directly supply the diaphragm. They contribute to forming the phrenic nerve, which then innervates the diaphragm.

 

Option C. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve (C6, C7, C8) supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle, not the diaphragm. It is a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.

 

Option D. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve (C5, C6, C7) supplies the serratus anterior muscle, not the diaphragm. It's an important nerve for scapular stabilization during arm movements.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The phrenic nerve (C3-C5) is the sole motor and sensory nerve of the diaphragm, with irritation of its central portion causing referred pain to the shoulder tip due to shared C4 innervation.

choices.text: The abdominal part of the esophagus is supplied by the left gastric artery
It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium
The cervical part of the esophagus is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the esophagus is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: c) It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium

 

Explanation:

 

The esophagus is lined by stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium, not ciliated columnar epithelium. This epithelium forms a protective layer resistant to abrasion from food passing through the esophagus. The lamina propria consists of loose connective tissue with papillae, and the muscularis mucosae becomes more distinct in the lower part formed by longitudinal muscle fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is approximately 25 cm long - This is correct. The esophagus is approximately 25 cm long, and is one of several structures in the body that measure about 25 cm, including the duodenum, ureter, descending colon, and stomach.

 

Option B. The abdominal part of the esophagus is supplied by the left gastric artery - This is correct. The lower 1/3rd part of the esophagus, including the abdominal portion, receives its arterial supply from the esophageal branches of the left gastric artery.

 

Option D. The cervical part of the esophagus is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery - This is correct. The upper 1/3rd part of the esophagus (cervical part) is supplied by the inferior thyroid artery.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The esophagus is lined by stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium, which provides protection against abrasion, whereas ciliated columnar epithelium is found in respiratory passages and certain parts of the female reproductive tract.

choices.text: Junction of the superior vena cava (SVC) and left brachiocephalic vein
Junction of the left internal jugular and left subclavian vein

questions.text: Where does the thoracic duct enter the systemic circulation? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: b. Junction of the left internal jugular and left subclavian vein

 

 

Explanation:

 

The thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body, extending from the cisterna chyli in the upper abdomen to the root of the neck. After ascending through the posterior and superior mediastinum, the thoracic duct arches laterally at the level of the seventh cervical vertebra. It then descends in front of the first part of the left subclavian artery and finally terminates by opening into the angle of junction between the left subclavian and left internal jugular veins, effectively entering the venous system at this point.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Junction of the SVC and left brachiocephalic vein: The thoracic duct does not enter at this location. This junction is too far from the neck region where the thoracic duct actually terminates.

 

Option C. Directly into the coronary sinus: The coronary sinus is a venous structure located in the heart that drains cardiac veins. The thoracic duct has no direct connection to the coronary sinus.

 

Option D. Into the azygos vein: While the thoracic duct and azygos vein are both located in the posterior mediastinum, the thoracic duct does not empty into the azygos vein. The azygos vein drains into the superior vena cava.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The thoracic duct, which collects lymph from the entire body except the right upper quadrant, terminates by emptying into the venous system at the junction of the left subclavian and left internal jugular veins.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a tributary of the thoracic duct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d. Right jugular trunk

 

 

Explanation:

 

The right jugular trunk is not a tributary of the thoracic duct. Instead, it drains into the right lymphatic duct. The thoracic duct receives lymph from roughly both halves of the body below the diaphragm and the left half above the diaphragm. At the root of the neck, it receives the left jugular trunk (from nodes in the neck), the left subclavian trunk (from nodes in the axilla), and the left bronchomediastinal trunk (which drains lymph from the left half of the thorax).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left lumbar trunk: This is a tributary of the thoracic duct. It brings lymph from the lower limb and pelvis on the left side and contributes to the formation of the cisterna chyli, which is the beginning of the thoracic duct.

 

Option B. Right lumbar trunk: Despite being on the right side, this is also a tributary of the thoracic duct. It contributes to the formation of the cisterna chyli and helps drain lymph from the right lower limb and abdomen.

 

Option C. Left jugular trunk: This is a tributary of the thoracic duct. It drains lymph from the left side of the head and neck and joins the thoracic duct near its termination.

 

Education Objective: 

 

 

The thoracic duct receives lymph from both lower limbs and abdomen, and from the left side of the thorax, left upper limb, and left side of head and neck, while the right jugular trunk drains to the right lymphatic duct.

questions.text: Which structure passes posterior to the hilum of the lung? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Vagus nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The vagus nerve passes posterior to the hilum of the lung. The relations of the root of the lung include both anterior and posterior structures. Posteriorly, the vagus nerve and posterior pulmonary plexus are located behind the hilum. The vagus nerve descends through the thorax, contributing to the formation of the posterior pulmonary plexus, which supplies the bronchial tree and lung tissue. After passing behind the root of the lung, the vagus nerve continues downward to help form the esophageal plexus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phrenic nerve: The phrenic nerve runs anterior to the root of the lung, not posterior. It descends between the fibrous pericardium and mediastinal pleura to supply the diaphragm. It is accompanied by the pericardiacophrenic vessels.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava (SVC): The SVC is located anterior and to the right of the trachea and does not pass posterior to the hilum of the lung. It forms part of the anterior relations of the right lung hilum.

 

Option D. Right atrium: The right atrium forms part of the mediastinal surface impression on the right lung but is anterior to the hilum, not posterior. It has no relation to the posterior aspect of the lung hilum.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The vagus nerve passes posterior to the hilum of the lung, contributing to the posterior pulmonary plexus before continuing downward to form the esophageal plexus.

questions.text: In which section of the mediastinum is the arch of the aorta located? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Superior mediastinum

 

Explanation:

 

The arch of the aorta is located in the superior mediastinum. The superior mediastinum lies above an imaginary plane passing through the sternal angle (manubriosternal junction) anteriorly and the lower border of the T4 vertebra posteriorly. This division separates the superior mediastinum from the inferior mediastinum. The arch of the aorta begins behind the upper border of the second right sternocostal joint, arches upwards, backwards, and to the left, and ends at the lower border of the T4 vertebra, forming a major structure within the superior mediastinum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior mediastinum: This is part of the inferior mediastinum, located behind the pericardium. It contains the descending thoracic aorta (not the arch), esophagus, thoracic duct, azygos and hemiazygos veins, and splanchnic nerves.

 

Option C. Middle mediastinum: This section of the inferior mediastinum contains the heart enclosed in the pericardium, the ascending aorta (not the arch), and the pulmonary trunk. The arch of the aorta lies above this division.

 

Option D. Anterior mediastinum: This is the smallest part of the inferior mediastinum, located between the sternum and the pericardium. It contains the thymus gland (or its remnants), lymph nodes, and areolar tissue. The arch of the aorta is not found here.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The arch of the aorta is a key structure in the superior mediastinum, along with the brachiocephalic veins, superior vena cava, trachea, and esophagus.

questions.text: Into which structure do the right suprarenal veins drain? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Inferior vena cava


 

Explanation:

 

The right suprarenal vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava. This differs from the venous drainage pattern of the left suprarenal gland, which drains into the left renal vein. This asymmetric pattern of suprarenal venous drainage follows the general principle of asymmetry in venous drainage seen in other retroperitoneal structures, where right-sided vessels often connect directly to the inferior vena cava while left-sided vessels join via intermediate veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right renal vein - This is incorrect as the right suprarenal vein bypasses the right renal vein and drains directly into the inferior vena cava. Only the left suprarenal vein drains into its corresponding renal vein.

 

Option C. Left renal vein - This is incorrect for the right suprarenal vein. The left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein, but the right suprarenal vein has a different drainage pattern.

 

Option D. Accessory Hemiazygos vein - This is incorrect as the accessory hemiazygos vein is part of the thoracic venous system that drains into the azygos vein, not a recipient of suprarenal venous drainage.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The right suprarenal vein drains directly into the inferior vena cava, while the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein - an important example of asymmetric venous drainage in retroperitoneal structures.

choices.text: Lateral part of the medial femoral condyle
Medial part of the medial femoral condyle
Lateral part of the lateral femoral condyle
Medial part of the lateral femoral condyle

questions.text: Most common site of osteochondritis dissecans: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Lateral part of the medial femoral condyle

 

Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) most commonly affects the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle of the knee joint. This condition involves the separation of a segment of articular cartilage and subchondral bone from the underlying bone surface, typically due to repetitive trauma or compromised blood supply. The knee is the most commonly affected joint in the body, and is also the largest joint in our body. The pathology involves an area of avascular necrosis that may lead to fragmentation and separation of bone and cartilage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medial part of the medial femoral condyle - This is not the typical location for OCD. The condition preferentially affects the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle due to biomechanical stresses and vascular patterns. The medial aspect experiences different loading patterns.

 

Option C. Lateral part of the lateral femoral condyle - While OCD can occur here, it is less common than the lateral part of the medial femoral condyle. The lateral femoral condyle is subjected to different biomechanical forces during knee motion.

 

Option D. Medial part of the lateral femoral condyle - This is an uncommon location for OCD. The blood supply and stress patterns in this region differ from those at the classic location on the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Osteochondritis dissecans most commonly affects the lateral part of the medial femoral condyle of the knee, involving separation of articular cartilage and subchondral bone due to compromised vascularity or repetitive trauma.

questions.text: Thurston-Holland's sign is seen in Salter Harris Type: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. II

 

  • The Thurston-Holland's sign refers to the triangular metaphyseal fragment that remains attached to the epiphysis in Salter-Harris Type II fractures. 
  • This metaphyseal fragment is a key radiographic finding that helps distinguish Type II from other types of epiphyseal injuries. 

 

 

  • Type II is one of the most common epiphyseal injuries and has a generally good prognosis because the growth plate is not significantly damaged.
  • The fracture goes through the growth plate and then extends above into the metaphysis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A  I: In Type I fractures, there is a clean separation through the growth plate without any metaphyseal or epiphyseal fragment. The fracture line runs completely through the physis with no metaphyseal fragment. Often difficult to see on X-ray unless there's widening of the growth plate. So Thurston-Holland's sign is absent.

 

Option C  III: This type involves a fracture through the growth plate that extends into the epiphysis (joint surface). The fracture does not involve the metaphysis, so there is no metaphyseal fragment to produce Thurston-Holland's sign.

 

Option D V: This represents a crush injury to the growth plate that may not be visible on initial radiographs. It causes compression of the physis and has no visible fracture line or metaphyseal fragment, thus no Thurston-Holland's sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thurston-Holland's sign refers specifically to the metaphyseal fragment seen in Salter-Harris Type II fractures and serves as an important radiographic marker for identifying this type of injury, which has a good prognosis compared to types III, IV, and V.

questions.text: Position of limb in posterior dislocation of shoulder: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Adducted and internally rotated

 

In posterior dislocation of the shoulder, the limb is characteristically held adducted and internally rotated. This position occurs because the humeral head has dislocated posteriorly behind the glenoid. The position is often described as "Up/In" (arm is adducted) in contrast to anterior dislocation where the position is "Down/Out" (arm is abducted). Posterior dislocations are uncommon compared to anterior dislocations and are often caused by electric shock, epilepsy, or a direct blow to the front of the shoulder.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adducted and externally rotated: This position is not seen in shoulder dislocations because external rotation would typically reduce a posterior dislocation. External rotation moves the humeral head anteriorly.

 

Option B. Abducted and externally rotated: This describes the position commonly seen in anterior dislocation of the shoulder, not posterior dislocation. In anterior dislocation, the arm appears "down and out" with the humeral head displaced anteriorly.

 

Option C. Abducted and internally rotated: This is incorrect, as the arm is adducted in a posterior dislocation. While internal rotation is correct for a posterior dislocation, the combination with abduction is not typical.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Posterior dislocation of the shoulder presents with the characteristic "Up/In" position where the arm is adducted and internally rotated, contrasting with the "Down/Out" position (abducted) seen in the more common anterior dislocation.

choices.text: ACL, MCL, and Medial Meniscus tear
ACL, MCL, and Lateral Meniscus tear
ACL, PCL, and Medial Meniscus tear
ACL, PCL, and Lateral Meniscus tear

questions.text: The most common triad of acute knee injuries seen in athletes includes a combination of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ACL, MCL, and Medial Meniscus tear

 

  • The combination of ACL, MCL, and Medial Meniscus tear is known as O'Donoghue triad, which is considered a dangerous injury pattern 
  • The triad is represented by the acronym "MAM" - Medial collateral ligament, Anterior cruciate ligament, and Medial meniscus. 
  • This injury typically occurs when valgus force and rotational stress are applied to the knee joint during athletic activities.
  • This combination typically results from a valgus stress with external rotation of the tibia on a planted foot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACL, MCL, and Lateral Meniscus tear: This combination doesn't represent the classic O'Donoghue triad. While ACL and MCL injuries can occur together, the medial meniscus is the third component in the classic triad, not the lateral meniscus.

 

Option C. ACL, PCL, and Medial Meniscus tear: This combination involves both cruciate ligaments, which follows a different injury mechanism. PCL injuries typically occur with posterior force on the tibia, rather than the valgus/rotational force that produces O'Donoghue triad.

 

Option D. ACL, PCL, and Lateral Meniscus tear: This combination includes both cruciate ligaments with the lateral meniscus, which would require a complex injury mechanism not typical of most athletic injuries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

O'Donoghue triad consists of injury to the Medial collateral ligament (M), Anterior cruciate ligament (A), and Medial meniscus (M), creating the "MAM" pattern that typically results from valgus force combined with rotation.

questions.text: Which of the following bone tumors most closely resembles osteomyelitis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Ewing's Sarcoma

 

Ewing's sarcoma closely resembles osteomyelitis clinically and radiologically. It typically occurs in the diaphysis of long bones, affects patients in the 1st-2nd decade of life, and often presents with pain, swelling, and fever. The radiological features include onion-peel appearance due to periosteal reaction with layered new bone formation, which can mimic the appearance of osteomyelitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma - While osteosarcoma can also present like osteomyelitis, it is less commonly confused with osteomyelitis than Ewing's sarcoma. Osteosarcoma typically affects the metaphysis (not diaphysis), has a "sun-ray" appearance on X-ray rather than the onion-peel appearance, and shows significant new bone formation with Codman's triangle.

 

 

Option C. Chondrosarcoma - This tumor typically affects patients aged 30-60 years, involves flat bones or upper end of femur, and has characteristic mottled calcification on X-ray. It doesn't present with fever or other inflammatory signs that would mimic osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Osteochondroma - This is a developmental malformation rather than a true tumor, presents as a painless swelling around joints (usually knee), and has a distinctive radiologic appearance showing a bony growth made of mature cortical bone and marrow. It doesn't resemble osteomyelitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ewing's sarcoma most closely mimics osteomyelitis due to its diaphyseal location, presentation with fever, and onion-peel appearance on X-ray—making it an important differential diagnosis in suspected cases of infection.

choices.text: Abduction of the carpo-metacarpal joint of the thumb
Flexion of the MCP joint of the middle finger

questions.text: Injury to the ulnar nerve at the wrist causes paralysis of which function? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Adduction of the thumb

 

In ulnar nerve injury at the wrist (low ulnar nerve palsy), there is paralysis of adduction of the thumb. This occurs because the adductor pollicis muscle is supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve in the hand. The ulnar nerve divides into superficial and deep terminal branches upon entering the palm. The deep branch supplies the adductor pollicis, all interossei, and medial two lumbricals.

 

The function of adductor pollicis can be tested using the "Book Test" or "Froment's sign." When a patient with ulnar nerve palsy attempts to hold a book between the thumb and index finger, they cannot use the adductor pollicis. Instead, they compensate by using the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve), resulting in flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apposition of the thumb - This function is performed by the opponens pollicis muscle, which is supplied by the median nerve, not the ulnar nerve. Apposition is a swinging movement of the thumb across the palm, not simple adduction.

 

Option B. Abduction of the carpo-metacarpal joint of the thumb - This function is performed by the abductor pollicis brevis, which is supplied by the median nerve. It can be tested using the "Pen Test," where the patient touches a pen held above the thumb.

 

Option D. Flexion of the MCP joint of the middle finger - This is primarily performed by the lumbricals. While the ulnar nerve does supply the medial two lumbricals (for the ring and little fingers), the middle finger's lumbrical is supplied by the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ulnar nerve injury at the wrist causes paralysis of adductor pollicis (tested by Froment's sign/Book test), interossei muscles (tested by Egawa's test for dorsal interossei and Card test for palmar interossei), and medial two lumbricals, resulting in a more pronounced claw hand deformity than high ulnar nerve palsy.

choices.text: All of the above are correct

questions.text: Regarding Congenital Talipes Equinovarus (CTEV), all of the following statements are true except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Varus at the talonavicular joint

 

This statement is incorrect because in CTEV (clubfoot), the varus deformity occurs primarily at the subtalar joint, not at the talonavicular joint. The subtalar joint is where the talus articulates with the calcaneum, and when the calcaneum is inverted, it takes the whole foot with it so that the sole faces medially, creating the varus deformity. The talonavicular joint contributes more to the adduction component of the deformity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This is correct. Equinus deformity in CTEV occurs primarily at the ankle joint (tibiotalar joint). The foot is fixed in plantar flexion at this joint, creating the equinus component.

 

Option C: This is correct. The adduction deformity in CTEV occurs at the midtarsal joints, mainly at the talonavicular joint. This creates the medial deviation of the forefoot, which is a key component of clubfoot.

 

Option D: This is incorrect because option B contains an error. Not all of the statements are correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In CTEV, the pathoanatomy involves specific deformities at different joints: equinus at the ankle (tibiotalar) joint, varus at the subtalar joint, and adduction at the midtarsal joints (primarily talonavicular). Understanding the precise location of each deformity component is crucial for proper treatment planning.

questions.text: In a Holstein-Lewis fracture, which nerve is most commonly injured? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Radial

 

Holstein-Lewis fracture is a spiral fracture of the humerus at the junction of the middle and distal third, which is commonly associated with radial nerve injury. The radial nerve is particularly vulnerable at this location as it traverses the spiral groove of the humerus and comes to lie close to the bone at this junction. The injury to the nerve results in wrist drop due to paralysis of the wrist, finger and thumb extensors, the brachioradialis, and the supinator muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axillary - This nerve is commonly injured in shoulder dislocations and fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus, not in Holstein-Lewis fractures.

 

Option B. Median - This nerve can be injured in supracondylar fractures of the humerus but is not typically associated with Holstein-Lewis fractures. Median nerve injury would cause a "pointing index" deformity.

 

Option D. Ulnar - This nerve is commonly injured in fractures of the medial epicondyle or in elbow dislocations, not in spiral fractures of the humeral shaft. Ulnar nerve injury would result in a claw hand deformity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Holstein-Lewis fracture is a specific type of spiral fracture at the junction of middle and distal third of the humerus that has a high association with radial nerve injury resulting in wrist drop.

questions.text: Where is primary hematogenous osteomyelitis most commonly observed in children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Metaphysis

 

Hematogenous osteomyelitis in children most commonly affects the metaphysis of long bones. This occurs due to the unique vascular arrangement in the metaphyseal region where blood vessels form a hair-pin loop arrangement, causing blood stasis. This anatomical feature makes the metaphysis a favorable site for bacteria to settle. The lower femoral metaphysis is the most frequently affected site, followed by upper tibial, upper femoral, and upper humeral metaphyses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is rarely the primary site of infection in hematogenous osteomyelitis. The epiphyseal plate actually serves as a barrier that is resistant to the spread of infection from the metaphysis.

 

Option B. Growth plate: The growth plate (physis) is typically not affected initially in osteomyelitis. It acts as a barrier to infection spread, though it may become damaged in advanced cases, leading to growth disturbances.

 

Option C. Diaphysis: While the diaphysis can be involved in osteomyelitis, particularly when infection spreads from the metaphysis or in certain conditions like Salmonella osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia, it is not the primary site of hematogenous osteomyelitis in children.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hematogenous osteomyelitis in children preferentially affects the metaphysis due to its unique vascular arrangement with hair-pin loop vessels causing blood stasis, creating a favorable environment for bacterial seeding.

questions.text: The mosaic pattern of cement lines is characteristically seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Paget's disease of bone

 

  • The mosaic pattern of cement lines is the diagnostic histological feature of Paget's disease of bone (also called Osteitis Deformans). 

 

 

  • This characteristic pattern results from excessive disorganized bone turnover due to osteoclast defect, where osteoclasts become larger and irregular. 
  • There's an initial phase of excessive bone resorption (osteoclastic activity) followed by a compensatory phase of abnormal, rapid, and disorganized bone formation (osteoblastic activity).
  • This disordered remodeling creates a distinctive puzzle-like or "mosaic" appearance of the cement lines between bone lamellae that is pathognomonic for Paget's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: Hyperthyroidism causes increased bone turnover and can lead to osteopenia or osteoporosis, but it does not produce the characteristic mosaic pattern of cement lines. It typically shows increased osteoclastic activity without the disordered remodeling seen in Paget's disease.

 

 

Option C. Renal osteodystrophy: Renal osteodystrophy presents with a mixture of features including those of hyperparathyroidism, osteomalacia, osteoporosis, and osteosclerosis. It can produce "rugger jersey spine" appearance, but does not show the mosaic pattern of cement lines characteristic of Paget's disease.

 

 

Option D. Osteomalacia: Osteomalacia is characterized by inadequate mineralization of osteoid tissue resulting in excessive uncalcified osteoid seams on histology. It does not display the mosaic cement line pattern seen in Paget's disease.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The mosaic (or marble) pattern of cement lines is a pathognomonic histological feature of Paget's disease, reflecting the excessive disorganized bone turnover that characterizes this condition.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with good prognosis in schizophrenia, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Predominant Negative symptoms

 

Explanation: Predominant negative symptoms are associated with poor prognosis in schizophrenia, not good prognosis. Negative symptoms (often remembered as the "6As") include avolition (loss of drive), apathy (lack of concern), anhedonia (loss of pleasure), asociality (lack of social interaction), affective flattening (lack of emotional response), and alogia (decreased verbal communication). These symptoms respond poorly to medications and are considered poor prognostic factors.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Late onset (Incorrect): Advanced age of onset (>35 years) is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia. Early onset (<20 years) is linked to poorer outcomes.
  • Option B. Presence of Depression (Incorrect): The presence of affective symptoms, including depression, is associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia.
  • Option D. Acute onset (Incorrect): Acute or abrupt onset of symptoms is associated with better prognosis compared to insidious onset.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Good prognostic factors in schizophrenia include acute/abrupt onset, later age of onset (>35 years), female gender, presence of affective symptoms, and predominant positive symptoms. Poor prognostic factors include insidious onset, early onset (<20 years), male gender, predominant negative symptoms, and absence of affective symptoms.

questions.text: All of the following are true about dementia and differentiate it from delirium, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Clouding of consciousness

 

Explanation: 

 

Clouding of consciousness is a characteristic feature of delirium, not dementia. The disturbance of consciousness is considered one of the hallmark symptoms of delirium and represents a key distinguishing feature between these two neurocognitive disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Insidious onset (Incorrect): Dementia typically has an insidious onset with gradual progression, while delirium has a sudden onset. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia.
  • Option B. Often irreversible (Incorrect): Most dementias are irreversible and progressive conditions, unlike delirium which is usually reversible if the underlying cause is identified and treated. This is a true differentiating feature of dementia.
  • Option D. Impaired remote memory (Incorrect): In dementia, memory impairment follows a pattern where recent memory is affected first, followed by immediate memory, and finally remote memory in later stages. In delirium, immediate and recent memory are primarily affected while remote memory remains relatively intact. Impaired remote memory in later stages is a feature of dementia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key differences between dementia and delirium include: dementia has insidious onset and progressive course while delirium has sudden onset and fluctuating course; consciousness is preserved in dementia but disturbed in delirium; and dementia is often irreversible whereas delirium is usually reversible when the underlying cause is treated.

questions.text: Long-term drug abuse with which of the following is associated with an increased risk of developing Schizophrenia? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Cannabis

 

Explanation: 

 

Long-term cannabis use has been associated with an increased risk of developing schizophrenia. Regular cannabis use, especially during adolescence when the brain is still developing, can significantly increase the risk of developing psychotic disorders including schizophrenia in predisposed individuals.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Barbiturates (Incorrect): While barbiturates can cause various adverse effects including dependence and cognitive impairment, they have not been specifically linked to increased risk of developing schizophrenia. 
  • Option B. Heroin (Incorrect): Heroin is an opioid that can lead to severe dependence and various health problems, but it is not specifically associated with increasing the risk of developing schizophrenia. 
  • Option D. Magic Mushrooms (Incorrect): Magic mushrooms contain psilocybin, a hallucinogen that can cause short-term psychotic-like experiences during intoxication. However, unlike cannabis, they have not been consistently linked to increased risk of developing chronic schizophrenia. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cannabis use, particularly during adolescence and young adulthood, is a recognized environmental risk factor for developing schizophrenia in vulnerable individuals. The risk appears to be dose-dependent and may involve interactions with genetic predisposition.

choices.text: Osteoporosis is a relative contraindication for ECT.
Benzodiazepines should be discontinued prior to ECT.
The most common complication is Amnesia.
Increased intracranial pressure is an absolute contraindication for ECT.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Increased intracranial pressure is a contraindication for ECT.

 

Explanation: 

 

According to current understanding, there are no absolute contraindications for ECT. 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Osteoporosis is a relative contraindication for ECT (Correct): Osteoporosis is indeed a relative contraindication for ECT because the muscle contractions during the seizure could potentially cause fractures in patients with severe osteoporosis. However, with modern modified ECT using muscle relaxants, this risk is significantly reduced.
  • Option B. Benzodiazepines should be discontinued prior to ECT (Correct): Benzodiazepines should be discontinued before ECT because they have anticonvulsant properties that can raise the seizure threshold and potentially interfere with the therapeutic efficacy of ECT by reducing seizure duration.
  • Option C. The most common complication is Amnesia (Correct): Memory disturbances, particularly retrograde amnesia, are the most common side effects of ECT. Retrograde amnesia is more common than anterograde amnesia, and recovery typically occurs within 1-6 months.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While ECT requires careful consideration of patient-specific factors, there are no absolute contraindications for its use. Earlier, raised intracranial pressure was considered an absolute contraindication for ECT, but no longer. The main side effect is memory disturbance, particularly retrograde amnesia, which is usually temporary. Modern modified ECT using anaesthesia and muscle relaxants has significantly improved the safety profile of this effective treatment for severe depression, catatonia, and certain other psychiatric conditions.

choices.text: Fear of places from which escape is difficult

questions.text: All of the following may be termed as Agoraphobia, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Fear of heights

 

Explanation: 

 

Agoraphobia is specifically defined as fear of places from which escape might be difficult. The fear of heights (acrophobia) is a specific phobia and not a component of agoraphobia. Agoraphobia includes fears related to situations where escape might be challenging, embarrassing, or help may not be available if panic-like symptoms occur.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Fear of places from where escape is difficult (Incorrect): This is the core definition of agoraphobia. People with agoraphobia fear situations where they feel trapped, helpless, or embarrassed.
  • Option C. Fear of open spaces (Incorrect): This is included in the definition of agoraphobia. 
  • Option D. Fear of crowded places (Incorrect): Fear of crowded places is a characteristic manifestation of agoraphobia. Crowded places may trigger anxiety due to perceived difficulty in escaping or reaching help if needed.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Agoraphobia is characterized by fear of situations where escape might be difficult, help might not be available, or where panic attacks might occur. It commonly includes fears of open spaces, enclosed places, crowds, public transportation, and being outside alone. Specific phobias like acrophobia (fear of heights) are distinct from agoraphobia and classified separately as specific phobias.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an endocrine change associated with protein-energy malnutrition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Low cortisol

 

Explanation: 

 

In protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), the body undergoes specific hormonal adaptations to conserve energy and maintain essential functions. Cortisol, being a stress hormone, actually increases in malnutrition (not decreases). This elevated cortisol helps mobilize amino acids from muscle tissue, stimulates gluconeogenesis in the liver, and maintains blood glucose levels during nutritional stress—all critical survival mechanisms during starvation.

The theory of adaptation in malnutrition explains these hormonal changes as the body's attempt to prioritize vital functions while reducing energy expenditure on growth and other non-essential processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low insulin - CORRECT finding in PEM. Insulin secretion decreases to minimize glucose uptake by peripheral tissues and maintain blood glucose for brain function.

 

Option C. Low thyroid hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) decrease, resulting in reduced basal metabolic rate and oxygen consumption as an energy-sparing adaptation.

 

Option D. Elevated growth hormone - CORRECT finding in PEM. Despite increased growth hormone levels, there is peripheral resistance to its action and decreased production of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), explaining the growth failure despite high GH levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Protein-energy malnutrition produces a characteristic endocrine profile with elevated stress hormones (cortisol), decreased anabolic hormones (insulin, thyroid hormones), and elevated but ineffective growth hormone—all serving to conserve energy and maintain vital functions during nutritional deprivation.

choices.text: 50 breaths per minute or more

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT suggest a possible severe bacterial infection in a young infant according to the IMNCI criteria? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Axillary temperature of 37.5°C or above 

 

Explanation: 

 

The IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) protocol uses specific clinical criteria to identify young infants with potential severe bacterial infections requiring urgent treatment. An axillary temperature of 37.5°C represents a normal body temperature and falls below the fever threshold of ≥38.0°C, which would indicate infection. A temperature between 36.5°C and 37.5°C is considered normal and would not trigger the "fever" classification in the IMNCI assessment.

 

The WHO IMNCI classification system specifically designates fever as temperature ≥38°C when assessing for possible severe bacterial infection. Without other clinical signs, a temperature of 37.5°C alone would be classified as "no fever" and would not meet criteria for antibiotic therapy or referral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50 breaths per minute or more - This is a danger sign in IMNCI assessment. The age-specific respiratory rate cutoffs (≥60/min for <2 months; ≥50/min for 2-12 months) define fast breathing, which is classified as pneumonia requiring antibiotic therapy or severe pneumonia if accompanied by chest indrawing.

 

Option B. 10 or more skin pustules - This IS considered a sign of possible severe bacterial infection. The IMNCI guidelines classify multiple skin pustules or a large skin infection as requiring systemic antibiotics due to risk of invasive bacterial disease.

 

Option D. Temperature less than 35.5°C - This IS a critical danger sign. Hypothermia in young infants strongly suggests sepsis and represents impaired thermoregulation. IMNCI classifies temperature <35.5°C as a danger sign requiring immediate referral after pre-referral antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In IMNCI assessment, normal temperature (36.5-37.5°C) does not trigger concern for severe bacterial infection, while fast breathing (age-specific rates), multiple skin infections, and hypothermia (<35.5°C) all represent important clinical signs requiring prompt antibiotic therapy and possible referral.

questions.text: What is the recommended target preductal oxygen saturation (SpO₂) for neonates at 5 minutes after birth according to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) 2010 guidelines? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 80-85%

 

Explanation: 

 

According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines, the target preductal oxygen saturation (SpO₂) in neonates at 5 minutes after birth is 80-85%. This is part of the gradual progression of normal oxygen saturation values in the first 10 minutes after birth. The preductal SpO₂ is measured in the right upper limb (right hand).

 

The normal SpO₂ progression after birth is:

 

  • At 1 minute: 60-65%
  • At 2 minutes: 65-70%
  • At 3 minutes: 70-75%
  • At 4 minutes: 75-80%
  • At 5 minutes: 80-85%
  • At 10 minutes: 85-95%

 

To remember-

 

  • Start from 60
  • THEN ADD 5 for every minute till 5 minutes, only for the last 10 minutes - add 10
  • These targets acknowledge the normal physiological transition from fetal to neonatal circulation, where saturation gradually increases as the lungs expand and the pulmonary vascular resistance decreases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70-75% - This is the target SpO₂ at 3 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Option B. 75-80% - This is the target SpO₂ at 4 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Option D. 85-95% - This is the target SpO₂ at 10 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The normal physiologic transition after birth involves a gradual increase in oxygen saturation, with a target SpO₂ of 80-85% at 5 minutes of life. These targeted ranges guide oxygen therapy during neonatal resuscitation to avoid both hypoxemia and hyperoxemia.

choices.text: Second most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children

questions.text: Which statement about Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) in children is accurate? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Second most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children 

 

Explanation:

 

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the second most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children, after Minimal Change Disease (MCD). FSGS accounts for approximately 10-15% of pediatric nephrotic syndrome cases. It is characterized by sclerosis in parts (segmental) of some (focal) glomeruli, with fusion of the foot processes of podocytes visible on electron microscopy.

 

FSGS is often associated with the NPHS2 gene mutation, which affects the protein podocin in the glomerular filtration barrier. This mutation is frequently linked to steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, making FSGS a significant cause of both primary and secondary steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome in the pediatric population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Good response to steroids - INCORRECT. FSGS is typically characterized by poor response to steroids. Most cases are steroid-resistant, which is one of the indicators for performing a renal biopsy in children with nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option C. Relapses are rare - INCORRECT. In FSGS, relapses are common, and the disease often follows a progressive course leading to end-stage renal disease in many patients if not effectively treated.

 

Option D. Renal biopsy is not required - INCORRECT. Renal biopsy is essential for diagnosing FSGS. It is indicated in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome and is the only definitive way to diagnose FSGS and distinguish it from other causes of nephrotic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

FSGS is the second most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (after Minimal Change Disease), is typically steroid-resistant, requires renal biopsy for diagnosis, and has a higher risk of progression to end-stage renal disease compared to MCD.

choices.text: He is likely to have a deficiency of the enzyme lactase.
Steatorrhea is likely to be associated.
Skim milk will make his symptoms worse than whole milk.
Hydrogen Breath test is a sensitive test to diagnose the condition.

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect regarding a child presenting with abdominal pain and bloating after consuming a milk-containing product? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Steatorrhea is likely to be associated.

 

Explanation: 

 

Steatorrhea (fatty, foul-smelling stools) is not typically associated with lactose intolerance. Lactose intolerance is characterized by the inability to digest lactose (milk sugar) due to deficiency of the enzyme lactase. When undigested lactose reaches the colon, it gets fermented by colonic bacteria, producing gas and causing symptoms like abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence, and watery diarrhea. Steatorrhea, however, is a feature of fat malabsorption disorders like pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, or bile acid deficiency, not lactose intolerance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. He is likely to have a deficiency of the enzyme lactase - CORRECT. Lactose intolerance is caused by deficiency of the enzyme lactase, which breaks down lactose into glucose and galactose.

 

Option C. Skim milk will make his symptoms worse than whole milk - CORRECT. Skim milk contains the same amount of lactose as whole milk (or sometimes slightly more), but less fat. Fat can slow gastric emptying and intestinal transit, potentially reducing symptoms. Therefore, skim milk may indeed cause worse symptoms than whole milk in lactose intolerant individuals.

 

Option D. Hydrogen Breath test is a sensitive test to diagnose the condition - CORRECT. The Hydrogen Breath test is a sensitive and specific test for lactose intolerance. After consuming lactose, undigested lactose is fermented by colonic bacteria, producing hydrogen which is absorbed and exhaled in breath.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lactose intolerance presents with abdominal pain, bloating, and watery diarrhea after consuming milk products, but not steatorrhea, which is characteristic of fat malabsorption disorders. Hydrogen breath test is the diagnostic test of choice.

questions.text: In polyarticular onset juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), the condition involves more than how many joints? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 5

 

Explanation:

 

Polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is defined by the involvement of 5 or more joints during the first 6 months of disease. This subtype of JIA affects approximately 25-40% of children with juvenile arthritis and can be further classified as rheumatoid factor positive or negative.

 

The classification of JIA is based on the number of joints involved in the initial 6 months:

  • Oligoarticular JIA: affects 4 or fewer joints
  • Polyarticular JIA: affects 5 or more joints
  • Systemic JIA: characterized by arthritis with systemic features including fever and rash

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3 - Incorrect. Involvement of 3 joints would be classified as oligoarticular JIA, which is defined as arthritis affecting 4 or fewer joints.

 

Option B. 4 - Incorrect. Involvement of 4 joints would still be classified as oligoarticular JIA.

 

Option D. 6 - Incorrect. While 6 joints would qualify as polyarticular JIA, the minimum threshold is 5 joints, not 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polyarticular JIA is defined by involvement of ≥5 joints during the first 6 months, while oligoarticular JIA involves ≤4 joints. This distinction is critical for proper classification, treatment approach, and prognostication.

questions.text: Which medication is considered the drug of choice for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Sodium Valproate

 

Explanation:

 

Benign Rolandic Epilepsy, also known as Benign Childhood Epilepsy with Centrotemporal Spikes (BECTS), is one of the most common childhood epilepsy syndromes. Sodium valproate is considered the drug of choice for this condition due to its broad spectrum antiepileptic properties and effectiveness in controlling both partial and generalized seizures. It works by increasing brain levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), an inhibitory neurotransmitter.

 

Benign Rolandic Epilepsy typically presents with focal seizures involving the face, particularly during sleep, and has a characteristic EEG pattern with centrotemporal spikes. The condition is self-limiting and generally resolves by adolescence, but antiepileptic therapy may be needed during the active phase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gabapentin - Incorrect. While gabapentin is used as an anticonvulsant, it is not the first-line therapy for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy. It is more commonly used for neuropathic pain and as adjunctive therapy for partial seizures.

 

Option C. Barbiturates - Incorrect. Barbiturates are older generation antiepileptic drugs with significant side effects including sedation and cognitive impairment. They are rarely used as first-line therapy for childhood epilepsies today.

 

Option D. Phenytoin - Incorrect. Phenytoin is primarily effective against generalized tonic-clonic and partial seizures but is not the drug of choice for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy due to its side effect profile and pharmacokinetic variability in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium valproate is the preferred first-line treatment for Benign Rolandic Epilepsy due to its efficacy and relatively favorable side effect profile compared to other antiepileptic medications in children.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the electrolyte composition of 'ReSoMal' oral rehydration salts solution used for malnourished children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Sodium 65 mmol/L

 

Explanation:

 

ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition) is specifically formulated for rehydrating children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). The sodium content in ReSoMal is 45 mmol/L, not 65 mmol/L as stated in option C. This reduced sodium concentration is intentional because malnourished children have excess body sodium despite presenting with low serum sodium levels. The standard WHO ORS contains 90 mmol/L sodium, which is too high for malnourished children.

 

The correct composition of ReSoMal includes:

  • Sodium: 45 mmol/L
  • Potassium: 40 mmol/L
  • Chloride: 70 mmol/L
  • Glucose: 125 mmol/L
  • Magnesium: 3 mmol/L
  • Zinc: 0.3 mmol/L
  • Copper: 0.045 mmol/L

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper 0.045 mmol/L - Correct. ReSoMal contains copper at a concentration of 0.045 mmol/L, which helps address micronutrient deficiencies common in malnourished children.

 

Option B. Potassium 40 mmol/L - Correct. ReSoMal has increased potassium (40 mmol/L) compared to standard ORS (20 mmol/L) to address potassium depletion in malnourished children.

 

Option D. Magnesium 3 mmol/L - Correct. ReSoMal contains magnesium at 3 mmol/L to help correct magnesium deficiency commonly seen in severe malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ReSoMal has a lower sodium concentration (45 mmol/L) and higher potassium concentration (40 mmol/L) than standard ORS to address the specific electrolyte abnormalities in severe acute malnutrition. This specialized formulation helps prevent complications like heart failure during rehydration therapy in malnourished children.

questions.text: What is the most prevalent defect observed in Congenital Rubella Syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Deafness

 

Explanation:

 

Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) is characterized by a triad of defects including sensorineural hearing loss, ocular abnormalities (such as cataracts), and congenital heart defects. Among these manifestations, sensorineural deafness is the most common and prevalent defect, affecting approximately 80% of infants with CRS. The hearing impairment is typically bilateral and can range from mild to profound.

 

The classic triad of CRS includes:

  • Sensorineural deafness (most common)
  • Eye abnormalities (cataracts, microphthalmia, glaucoma)
  • Cardiac defects (most commonly PDA)

 

The risk of defects is highest when maternal infection occurs during the first trimester, particularly before 11 weeks of gestation, when the risk of defects is approximately 90%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cataract - Incorrect. While cataracts are a characteristic feature of CRS, they are less common than hearing impairment, occurring in approximately 30-40% of affected infants.

 

Option C. Heart defect - Incorrect. Cardiac defects (particularly PDA, followed by peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis) occur in about 50-60% of CRS cases, making them less prevalent than deafness.

 

Option D. Microcephaly - Incorrect. Microcephaly is observed in CRS but at a lower frequency compared to hearing impairment. It is part of the neurological manifestations that may include developmental delay and intellectual disability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensorineural deafness is the most common manifestation of Congenital Rubella Syndrome, which is why hearing assessment is critical for all infants with suspected in-utero rubella exposure, even in the absence of other clinical features.

questions.text: Stoss therapy is utilized for the treatment of which condition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Vitamin D deficiency rickets

 

Explanation:

 

Stoss therapy refers to the administration of a large single dose or a few divided doses of vitamin D for the rapid correction of vitamin D deficiency. This therapy is specifically designed for treating nutritional vitamin D deficiency rickets. It typically involves giving a high dose of vitamin D (typically 300,000-600,000 IU) as either a single dose or divided over a few days.

 

The advantages of Stoss therapy include improved compliance (as it requires fewer doses) and rapid correction of deficiency. After the initial high-dose therapy, maintenance doses of vitamin D are continued to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly useful in situations where compliance with daily supplementation might be challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scurvy - Incorrect. Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency and is treated with vitamin C supplementation (100-200 mg/day for 3 months), not high-dose vitamin D therapy.

 

Option B. Keratomalacia - Incorrect. Keratomalacia is a condition resulting from severe vitamin A deficiency affecting the cornea. It requires vitamin A supplementation, not vitamin D. Treatment usually involves 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally on day 1, repeated on day 2 and after 2 weeks.
